Pours dark brown with minimal head. Aroma of dark fruit. Taste is plum, dark sugar. The malt here is sweet and so well balanced. The wood barrels add such an interesting and unique flavor. Hard to describe but so good.

Pours black with a very little tan head that quickly fades. The aroma is consistent with standard brown ales. Caramel, vanilla, dark malts. The taste is rich with a slight bitterness that is quickly taken over by heavy wood notes. At 12% there's only a hint of a warm alcohol presence. The palate is medium to heavy with a syrupy aftertaste. This is a big enjoyable, brown woodsy ale.

I like this a lot. Nice bitterness, great layers of the warmer fruits/roasted/chocolate things. Let down by the fact I cant pour with a head. Really nice beer though, and way to easy to drink at this ABV. Top stuff. Get in!
pours a dark brown color with a medium sized head. the aroma is alcohol, woodiness, slight vanilla. the taste was too much alcohol for me. you pick up some caramel.

Dark and malty! I felt the high alcohol really and thought that it stuck around as well. Strong! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark black body and tan small tan head. Looks like an imperial stout. Aroma is sweet, mostly malts and some brown sugar. Mouthfeel is interesting. Its a bit watery and after you swallow it feels it just dissipates away. A little bit tingly. Taste has slight bitterness and some sourness to it. Nice beer.

Delicious brew by DFH; one of their best. Huge dark fruit, plums, raisins, burnt sugar, molasses, and malts. Get a bit of that wood character as well; pours a brown slightly reddish liquor, with a small head forming in the end. Full bodied, very very sweet. Its a really big, American strong ale, which shows what DFH can do when they are not trying to be too gimmicky. Plain delicious.

Black,light head,leaves some tan froth. Aroma vannilla, malty caramel, sweet, light fruit, rich but subtle chocolate. Taste is same,  has a lot of dryness, but rich malt, finishes slightly boozie with roasty bitter and some berry notes.  It has quite a bit of berry and dry roast chocolate to it but its pretty dry in finish. It does have a wine like feel to it.  Maybe from tannins?  Im not too into it, probably wont buy it again. Its pretty good but not really my taste.
Dark color and malty aroma. Hoppy between bite cuts the high ABV so that you can drink more of this than you should.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2014 Bottled Jan 2014, Drunk March 2014
Pours black with tan, broken surface sheet.  Smells of oak, smoke and more oak, some grapes - mostly oak though, dont remember this being soo oaky.  Flavor is mostly oak, some sweet malts, but mostly oak again.  Bitterness and alcohol noted.  Medium on full bodied with high carb for the style.  Meh, not remotely as good as I recall.

Bottled: 19APR11, reviewed July 2011: 8/3/8/4/16 - 
A: Pours a dark brown ale with less than a single finger of tan head. This falls quickly and remains a broken sheet of the same. 
S: Strong alcohol, sweet wood, dates, vanilla, sweet nougat notes. 
T: Sweet, hints of iron, caramel, coffee, dark malts, vanilla, alcohol.
M: A bit thin with moderate carbonation. Dry finish for the style.
O: Great beer. Even better with a couple years on it.

Layers of dark fruit, boozy raisin, chocolate, vanilla, and wood. A big, bold, warming, commercial wood-aged ale, with good flavors.. though the carbonation, body and overall balance need some finessing to bring it to the next level. 12% alc is noticeable.. with a sharp bite at the back of the throat.. Overall, a big, wood-aged beer, with big flavor, that needs a little refinement.. Though considering the large scale production and distribution.. It's above average for sure. --- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

Bottle from local BevMo, Sunnyvale. Colour is almost black with small slightly brownish white head. Aromas and flavours: Wood, hints of coffee and hints of chocolate and roasted malts. Alcohol, where?
Dark pour with tan head that persisted to the end. Great roasted malt flavor with tinges of coffee/chocolate. The alcohol was well hidden. Careful of this one, it goes down fast!
Tap from Lazy Dog. Pours dark amber with very little head. Aroma of caramel, booze, and dark fruit. Taste again of caramel but with a more dark chocolate feel to it. With a boozy aftertaste.

Poured into a shifter. Color is dark black with almost no head. Very boozy smell. Kind of like a woody whiskey smell. Most alcohol Ive ever smelt in a beer. Oddly, and delightfully, the taste isnt boozy at all. Nice warm taste of sweet fruits like plum. Raisin and caramel too. Would have given it a 10 for taste if it was a little more carbonated, but I understand high abv beers have less. Nice warm mouth feel. Makes you smile when you sip it. Would be a great sit in front of the fireplace on a cold day kind of beer.
Super dark pour. We split a bottle in 2 brandy snifters & found the aroma very caramelized. Light feel on the tongue, not heavy. Slightly alcoholic taste, but robust & delicious.

Dark brown color with small medium brown head and minimal oily lacing. Aroma is malty, vinous, and boozy with deep fruits and roasty notes like a campfire. Flavor has sweet caramel malts, moderate bitterness and a bit of roasted cocoa & coffee. Large thick, viscous mouthfeel, full body, complex. Very good.
12oz to snifter. Very dark brown almost stout like appearance. Woody aroma. Thick and sweet. Almost like an oak aged stout. Very good.

Dark murky brown pour with a thick syrupy consistency and a very thin brown head that fades quickly. Lots of alcohol legs, this looks closer to a stout. On the nose I get big wood, smoke, coffee, mexican chocolate. The taste is much like the nose, but more chocolate and a slight dark fruit backdrop. You definitely know this a big sipping beer, but the alcohol is very well hidden for 12%, it drinks more like 8% to me. This is really unique, certainly for a "brown ale" and one of my favorites from DFH.

Comes out of the bottle beautifully thick, with a very thin head. Just the right amount of carbonation overall. Definitely some taste caramel and vanilla. The bourbon taste of alcohol also comes out strong. I also have 2 bottles of this in the cellar aging!!!
Very dark in color. Roasted malts, warm finish. High alcohol without noticing it. Gets better as it warms up a bit. Great beer to enjoy in cold weather.

Dark heavy body. Almost no head. Big complex flavors. Fig, prune, vanilla, dark fruit, smoke. Heavy roasted coffee, marshmallow, subtle spices, some brandy on a slightly boozy finish. Extra long finish, sweet but not too sweet. Good stuff

12oz bottle at home - Palo pours an intensely deep brown with a tan head that fades rather quickly. Aroma is smokey vanilla, molasses, wood, mocha, and some booze. Palo drinks smooth with flavors of cinnamon, sweet brown sugar, and earthy figs. This is one tasty big beer!

Bottle from 16 Tons, Eugene. Thought that I had rated this already, guess not. Along with Yeti and John Barleycorn, one of the best values in bigger beers. Pours an opaque brown, little to no tan head. Aroma woody, smoky, rich, licorice, booze. Body thick, rich and full with just the barest hint of warming. Just superb.

Tasted on draft. Pours a dark dark brown almost black with a beautiful tan head with great lacing. Incredible looking beer. Aroma with sweet notes of caramel, roasted malt, coffee. Taste up front is sweet caramel, coffee and chocolate. That gives way to bitter notes. The end is a slight alcohol burn but definitely hides the 12%. Huge complex beer. Pretty full bodied with a bit of a sticky mouthfeel. Overall a great beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: NOV 24, 2013 Bottle - Roasted malts, cherry and oak. Jet black with a brown head. Dark molasses, roasted malt, earthy hops. The age may have muted the coconut, but still nice.

Black in color with a thin-tan colored head. Awesome lacing that coats the side of the glass. Woody aroma. There is a citrus to the aroma with a malty finish. As the beer becomes room temperature banana comes out in aroma. Very creamy texture. There is a smokey finish. There is liquior in the taste. Average carbonation. There is a a hint of a caramel in the taste. This was a very enjoyable beer. Alcohol percentage was high but the beer hid it well.

Draft to taster. Looks good; a fairly opaque dull black with tan lacing. Smells solid; semi-sweet, malty, and roasty with a notable wood presence. Tastes like it smells with a solid mouthfeel. An interesting beer.

Im a DIPA fan. The first time I bought a single bottle of PSM I was very impressed, so I subsequently bought a four-pack. But as I go through it, I find that the alcohol tends to have a an off-putting, metallic edge to it. My enthusiasm is waning.

If you like roasty coffee and chocolate notes with a lingering sweetness, you should go for PSM. It just takes me too far afield from my DIPA tastes, of which Dogfish Head 90 Minute is the model.

FROM NOTES: August 10, 12. On tap at Fishales in Panama City, served in a chalice. 

A: Strong cocoa notes, strong malt sweetness and hints of alcohol. 
A: Pours a deep, dark brown, almost black, with a thin brown head that quickly dissipates into minimal lacing.
T: Very sweet with chocolate notes and a pleasant alcohol burn on the finish. 
P: Thick and creamy body with minimal carbonation. 
O: Im not a fan of DFH (except Squall IPA), but this is a WORLD CLASS brown!
Very good stout. I was surprised by the complexity of flavors produced while.slowly sipping this beer. It was pricey but well worth it!
Creamy dark chocolate love. I tried this particular vintage in 2010. It was awesome, but 3 years of aging in the fridge makes it even better.
On tap at Taps in Petaluma. Pours a dark brown color without much head. Lots of toffee flavor with a slight hoppiness. Slight alcohol taste.

Roasty and complex with some strong resemblance to a Cabernet. Has some nice flavors of oak, vanilla, chocolate, cherries, and subtle marshmallow.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle 12 fl.oz. Bought at Half Time (Poughkeepsie). Pours dark brown, almost black. Great mix of aroma: nuts, alcohol, malt, chocolate, dark fruits. Reminds me of a good Imperial Stout. Taste is good too. Good sweetness. Reminds me of porto. Full bodied. Not being too familiar with the American Strong Ale, I can only speculate that this one is on style. Pretty good beer, but only downside is heaviness. But after all, it is a 12% abv...
Dark pour with a beige head. Dark fruit aromas with caramel behind it. Definite caramel and cinnamon flavor with a fruity(raisin) finish. Not bad. Dogfish head is great at describing their brews.

Pours dark brown almost as dark as the night. Aroma is coffee, creamy vanilla, and hints of roasted malt, wood, and caramel. Taste is long lasting sweet, boozey and a bit of bitter notes near the finish. Creamy delicious brown ale with complex notes. Amazing beeer

Pours jet black, no head. Aroma is coffee, caramel, chocolate, raisin, and alcohol. Flavor has grape juice, strawberry, followed by some bitter hops. Texture is creamy, followed by some lingering alcohol flavor.
Very unique beer. Tasty, heavy, smelly... All in a good way. This is a perfect beer for its kind, probably the only one! Hurray DFH!

Draft at Churchkey. Pours dark brown with a small beige head. Aroma of raisins, alcohol, booze, overripe dark fruits, tobacco, wood, caramel. Flavour is heavy sweet. Full bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle from Bevarages 4 Less, San Diego. Thanks Freddy! Dark brown to black pour, creamy tan head. Aroma is roasty, licorice, fruity, bready sugar, oak, vanilla, some yeast and spicy. Flavor is quite sweet, roasted malts, some tobacco, fruits, creamy and with a very smooth texture and a thick body. Slightly warming in the finish. Nice brew.

An excellent, unique beer. Pours deep black, almost like an imperial stout. Not quite as thick, though. Enticing, sweet aroma. Strong carbonation. The wood aging on this is exquisite. It infuses every sip and is always there but is never overwhelming. Just the perfect amount. Fairly sweet but not cloying. Hint of smoke, and not much else. ABV is masterfully hidden. Great beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(4/29/13) Pours a thick dark brown, a finger of dense mocha foam.

Malt sweetness and a bit of bitterness, along with a woody/sawdust aroma from the Palo Santo wood. Very pleasant nose on this one.

Really unique. Sweet bready malt. Balanced bitterness. Creamy caramel and vanilla. Earthly, woody dryness on the finish. A bit of boozy heat comes on the finish as well, but it is quite pleasant. The Palo Santo wood adds a really unique, dry, sweet, bitter, nutty characteristic.

Medium to thick body. Very creamy.

Easily the best brown ale Ive had. The Palo Santo wood just adds to the brown ale characteristics. It tastes almost as if it is bourbon barrel aged because its got the heat, the caramel and vanilla, and the woodiness. For 12% this one goes down very easy, dangerously easy.
2/12/2010. From bottle. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Roasted malt aromas with dark fruit and caramel. A little sweet from the wood.
Pours a thick brown color with a caramel head that never leaves. Smells of vanilla, malt, and wood. Taste is roasted with some woody finish. Smooth and not too boozy. Great beer
On tap. Brown sugar and cinnamon toast aroma. Opaque pour with thick, beige head. Warm mouth feel and subtle flavor with a big flavor kick at the finish: licorice and toffee.

On draft at ChurchKey. Wow. Aroma of sandalwood and rich, dark cherries. Flavors start slowly then explode in the back of the mouth brown sugar, licorice, toasted cinnamon. A wonderfully funky achievement.

Thick rough texture and light body, average carbonation and astringent. The finish lingers with alcohol warmth, prune, vinous notes, hints of caramel, peat, brandy, liquorice sourness and tobacco. Comments: Very nice and left a glass lace. It reminded me of a Flemish sour ale.

From 12oz bottle to glass. Looks like an impy stout in the glass, dark brown/red with a dark tan fluffy head. Good looking beer in the glass. Aroma is of dark fruits, bread, toast, carmel malts and candy. Taste is somewhat sweet, with fruit flavor, not overwhelming, carmel, and vanilla. This beer reminds me of a quad style beer, although lacking in the yeast flavor. I enjoyed this and at 12%, the alcohol burn/taste in non-existent. Would recommend.
Overall a 7 in my opinion. This beer has somewhat of a strong after taste. The more I drink it the less I notice it by at 12% alcohol by volume its definitely a strong tasting beer.
Very dark with a thin tan head. Smells like a combination of smoke and red wine. Fruit and wood flavors come through. Gets better as you continue to drink it.

The most interesting American Strong Brown Ale Ive ever had. Pours dark almost cola colored with a half-finger head. Once this beer warms to 68 degrees the Chocolate, woodsy and pepper-like tones really shine through. Some licorice on the front end and oak tones on the back with a boozy finish, although that dissipates as it warms. Good stuff

Appearance: Dark brown with a cm thick tan head.
Aroma: Vinous quite like red wine, bread/toast, smoky, wood, peat, floral and prune.
Taste: Low/medium sweetness and bitterness, medium sourness and a slight saltiness.
Palate: Thick rough texture and light body, average carbonation and astringent. The finish lingers with alcohol warmth, prune, vinous notes, hints of caramel, peat, brandy, liquorice sourness and tobacco.
Comments: Very nice and left a glass lace. It reminded me of a Flemish sour ale.
Bottle. Aroma is wood, smoke, and tobacco. Taste is sweet with exotic wood and notes of leather, roast, chocolate and plums. A bit bitter and alcoholic on the finish. Unusual and complex.
Rated from backlog. Pours a deep, basically opaque brown with a thin, tan head. Aromas of chocolate and brown sugar. Flavor is big time roasted malts, some coffee and cocoa and some booziness.
Opaque black with khaki colored head. Nutty, chocolate aroma. Full/heavy mouthfeel. Some chocolate, earthy elements. Aromas and taste open up as it warms.

Pours black with a thin, dark tan head.
Vinous, raisiny, dark fruit aroma.
Syrupy, chocolate, wood flavor.
Coffee...a little spiced heat....
Very rich....
Excellent.
Pours thick and dark brown. Aroma is boozy , malty and a little bit sweet. Body is this, heavy and strong. Woody, chocolate vanilla. Excellent flavor a great sipper.

De couleur noire tirant légèrement sur le marron. Mousse presque absente.
Aromes dalcool, de vanille, chocolat, café, très légèrement fumé - boisé 
On goûte le sucre (vanille-chocolat), puis un côté légèrement anissé, la chaleur de lalcool mélangé avec un côté épicé prolonge la finale.
Dark pour with tan head. Sweet aged woody syrup aroma. A great beer for the seasoned connoisseur.

12fl oz bottle. Courtesy of Urbain from Struise. malty, caramel, wood aromas. Pours quite clear, copper, nice tan head, vanishing, poor lacing. Medium body, soft carbonation, oily texture. Taste is smooth, caramel, sweet, wood, a bit spicy. Balanced, alcohol very well hidden, enjoyable. Nice one.
Excellent American strong ale. Will definitely lay in a supply. Great with a light lunch on a summers day
This is a fantastic beer. Probably my favorite from DFH. Cocoa and coffee. Very smooth. Pours a dark brown. Absolutely great beer.

From 12oz bottle that had been aged 1 1/2 years (bottled Jan 2012) 

Pours a lovely dark dark dark brown with caramel head. Very nice chocolate and caramel aroma which carries over into the beer itself. Delicious. Best beer of the day so far (6 beers tasted).

Bottle aged for 18 months. Very very nice. Rich creamy and hides the % well. I love this beer since it mellowed.

355 ml. bottle @ home. Obtained in a trade with Ibrew2or3. THX!!! Blackish, very dark brown, basically black with almost no head, fizzes away instantly ~ high carb. First of I have no idea how Palo Santo wood taste like. Nose is thick maple syrup, wood sap, liquorish, molasses, sticky caramel, small touch of Mon Chéri. Taste is thick maple syrup, liquorish, dark lacquered wood, molasses, caramelized brown sugar, thick malts and caramel, touch dark dried fruits and 90 % cacao black chocolate, slight black chocolate roast in the back and some alcohol in the finish and obv. warming. Feels very, very strong, far above 12 % ABV. Body is like a can of Coca-Cola that has been open for a couple of hours but much thicker. Interesting and quite enjoyable.
Bière forte de 12%, amer mais ne lève pas le coeur, ressemble à une stout, très lourd!
2011 Bottle had this weekend. Pours dark, dark brown with tan head. medieum palate with chcoclate and perppery taste. Peppers come through on the back, Really good and with the aging experiment.

Bottle.
Pours dark brown with a thin dark brown head that leaves no lacing. Full body, average carbonation, sweet, heavy, a bit too much alcohol, long sticky finish. A long slow sipper but a bit cloying.
Bottle. Pours black with beige head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, licorice and fruitiness. Flavor is sweet licorice with some caramel, chocolate and alcohol. Full body, average carbonation.

Bottle, 12oz. The beer is next to black, topped by a dense, finger-thick light tan head. The aroma is roasted and woody, with a touch of salty licorice and molasses. Some chocolate too. Full-bodied and warming on the palate, with a soft carbonation, at appropriate level. Lots of flavor, with molasses, salty licorice notes, roasted malts, chocolate and a good sweetness. Some bitterness. Lasting sweet and roasted finish with a faint woody touch. A bit sweet and warming maybe, but its most certainly a nice one. 130809

Bottle 355ml @ Hotel Room, Quality Inn Santa Ynez Valley, Buellton, CA
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, alcohol, licorice, wood and fruits. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and medium bitter with a long warm, roasted, chocolate and licorice finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Thanks to willy for sharing! Dark black pour with minimal head and lacing. Smell is sweet roasted malts and wood. Taste is smoke, molasses, a bit of sour and smooth finish rounded out  with a bit of heat.  Tasty but a little cloying.

Bottle, thnx to Ed5388. Pours a pitch black beer with a brownish hue around the glass. Small amount of tanned, beige head on top. Aroma is woody, dense molasses and chocolate and has roasty and boozy notes as well. Flavour is quite sweet, very complex. The wood has given off many flavors, caramel, vanilla and chocolate. Quite boozy as well, but not disturbing. Great sipper to enjoy for a long a time.

This one is for the beer lovers. I thought it was too strong and whiskey flavored. I felt like I supped straight whiskey. Not sure why it is so high rated.

Caramel, dark fruit, chocolate, and smoky wood in the aroma. Sweet, chocolate flavor with chocolate/coffee bitterness and a little smoky wood in the finish. Im usually not a big fan of "barrel aged" stuff, but in this beer the wood aging adds to the flavor instead of dominating it. The result is really tasty and surprisingly drinkable given the abvs.
Bottle. Pours very dark with tan head. Smells smokey, sweet. Tastesnpt as heavy as Id of thought, creamy, chocolate, fruity, smoke, interesting. Its okay..,

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2014 09.01.2013, 0,35l bottle sampled @ BBGTC tasting:
Lett fyldig sødmerik lukt med preg av mørk malt, humle, tre, umoden banan, alkohol, mørk tørka frukt, sjokolade, karamell, gras. Lett tørr fyldig smak med preg av mørk malt, humle, tre, alkohol, mørk tørka frukt, umoden banan, gras, kakao, karamell. God bitterhet som set godt. Grei, for tørr og masse tre.

Pours black. No head but a thin ring and some loose bubbles floating on top. Wisps and waves of light film. The head comes up upon a tilt of the glass and leaves beautiful legs and quickly disappearing faint lace. Pretty. Nose is roasted coffee, and bitter chocolate with a coldness right out of the fridge. A little grass on top. The roasted coffee is strong and deep. Then a woody aroma that is pure wood. Smells soft and bends around the nose, very supple. Roasted malt, caramel but brown sugar. Not sugary, sugar. So authentic. Theres some nutty accents and a tiny bit of vanilla that smells very fresh. A  bit of alcohol on the nose and a light grass. The nose continues to deepen and evolve. The coffee and the chocolate marry one another and become entwined in sweet harmony. The one is never without the other in the drink. The chocolate sweetens and the malt deepens. A bit of cherry develops and it compliments the wood and earthiness. The taste is unexpected. Your first taste after smelling the coldness right from the fridge is a warming sweet brown bread. Theres sugar, and sweet creamy chocolate. The roasted coffee glides over the palate as easily as your morning cup. The vanilla excites the richness of both the coffee and the chocolate and the malt is smooth and mellow. The wood notes translate into the drink and lend to the overall freshness. The hops stay grass like. The tiny bit of alcohol is simply warming in the drink and pokes its head out only on the finish where you meet those cherry notes one more time. Finishes dry. 

This a beer that continues to develop in the glass and in the drink. Its smooth and yet it enlivens the palate and the senses. It grows on you and you like it more and more as you drink. The flavors are deep and perfected. The malt in this is superlative. It flows smoothly as the flavors become unbounded and always near at hand.

Taster at the brewery, very dark brown, small tan head, subtle aroma, nutty flavor with smoky notes, could pass as as a stout... Very good!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A- pours a dark brown with a 1- 1 1/2 brown head. leaves a slight lacing on the glass.
S- A little malty with a woody note. off of the smell i would not be able to tell what barrels were used.
T- Strong brown ale with a nice boozyness and wood aged character going for it.
M-medium to thick body with an oily feel, has an average carbonation with a long finish.
Delicious strong brew. Pours pitch black with a nice brown head. Taste is chocolate and burnt malts.

If you like wood-aged beers, and I do, this hits the mark. Very complex like a rich dessert. Strong sweet malty aroma with wood permeating through. Dark syrupy color with a small brown head. Nice thick and oily palate that coats the mouth. Carbonation may have been a little high. Big flavors centered around the strong wood character. Caramel malts and balanced by hops but neither overpower the other. Alcohol is definitely present. Great sipper for the end of a day.

12 oz. bottle 6 months on the shelf. Pours a syrupy jet black with a thin tan head and minimal lacing. Definite alcohol legs. Smell is ridiculous, woody, piney, bakers chocolate, espresso, caramel, vanilla, biscotti, booze. Taste is of wood, chocolate, hops, vanilla, espresso, pleasant alcohol burn. Brown Ale nuttiness and flavor with all these other variables thrown in. complexity of an imperial stout. combination of sweetness, woody hops and slight alcohol in between sips. Nice thick stout-like mouth feel, swirling it your mouth in between sips like a fine wine is a great way to enjoy this big beer which is definitely a sipper. One of my absolute favorites as you wont find another like this anywhere. Although this ages well, the fresher ones hold on to more of the Palo Santo wood characteristics which is what I think sets this brew apart. A must drink for any beer geek.

Bottle. Pours a gorgeous black with dark tan head and brilliant lacing. Aroma of malts, oak and bourbon. Taste of wood, malt, bourbon. Brilliant!!

----Hop out
UPDATED: JUL 1, 2013 Pours pitch black, tan head. Aroma is roast, taste is sweet roasted malt with some oak, nice!

Pours a deep, basically opaque brown with a thin, tan head. Aromas of chocolate and brown sugar. The force is strong in this one. Flavor is big time roasted malts, some coffee and cocoa and an alcohol burn that let my belly know whats up. Since this beer was aged in "holy tree" barrels, perhaps I should have waited until Sunday to down this behemoth over a few hail marys, in Madden 2013 of course. Good job DFH, yet another stellar offering.

Dark woody taste with a sweeter aftertaste. Very thick and dark. Pours heavy. Overall a good beer.

Dense mocha head over opaque black body. Looks like a great stout. Aroma of roast and dark caramel, liquorish, alcohol, wood, coffee, chocolate. Taste of roast, caramel. wood, plum, alcohol. Very dense and sweet, almost chewy, definitely a slow sipper. Palate roasty and sweet, with warming alcohol. This beer is the bastard child of a Russian Imperial Stout and an American Barleywine.

Not certain what makes this a brown ale and not a stout, or a malted beverage and not an ale. Had heard a lot of hype about this one and certainly found it enjoyable. Thick, creamy texture with subtle wood flavour and booze well hidden. Drinks like a stout to me, but smoother than a big imperial stout despite the abv
Tap- Pour is dark with a tan head..Nose is wood, fig, alcohol, plum, caramel, bitter..Taste is Chocolate, oak, candy, dark fruits, cherry, sweet..Dry and bitter
Deep dark beer with minimal head and bold nose. It is rich with chocolate notes, booze and wood. Very rich taste, with hints of bourbon, cherry, chocolate nibs and oak. Great beer!

2012 bottle from June..pretty dark brown almost black hue..dark brownish filmy head sticks on top..more carbonation than expected on this at edges...aroma of boozy bourbon..espresso infused maple syrup and vanilla bean..fairly smooth and almost creamy..aroma is the highlight of this as the mouthfeel is a bit weaker than the nose..tastes likes this a bourbon barrel aged offering..the tanks that age this at dfh are massive and this is one of the better offerings from dfh..12 is disguised quite well...a bit disappointed that the nose was far better than the rest..overall pretty good and 2 of these could be dangerous...

Bouteille de 12 oz. Merci Patrick. Bière brune très foncée avec une mousse brune, crémeuse et durable. Le nez est boisé, cerises au chocolat, lalcool est perceptible au nez. UPDATED: NOV 30, 2013 Bottle poured into snifter. Pours a deep, dark brown with almost no head. Light lacing that doesnt stick. Smells oaky with light fruits, toasty malts and some vanilla. Flavors are booze up front, malts, roastiness and a very subtle sweetness on a long, almost bourbons finish. Amazingly complex palate, well balanced, with the 12% ABV hidden underneath the flavors. A delicious beer that I could easily get lost in. Worth cellaring.

Shared bottle courtesy of GhostDrinker. Pours a deep deep brown, minimal head. Aroma is wonderful - big woody presence, vanilla, forest fruits. Taste is superb, too - wood, caramel, vanilla, stewed fruits and a little chocolate, with an almost tart finish. Ridiculous. Thick mouthfeel, hint of alcohol warmth. Wonderfully balanced - a sublimely ridiculous cracker.

La robe est impériale et sa mousse est une couronne royale.  Son nez paraît riche avec ses malts noirs et même brûlés qui suintent la mélasse, les dattes et les raisins.  Il y a un parfum vraiment unique qui me fait énormément travailler.  Je sens de la réglisse et/ou des épices et/ou de la vanille et/ou autre chose dassez indiscernable.  Serait-ce la présence de ce bois sacré, le palo santo, cet arbre de la famille des Zygophyllacées qui donne cette touche unique?  Il me semble bien que oui.  Enfin, pour moi, la surprise de cette singularité est totale.  La première gorgée surprend tout autant.  Je suis ici en présence dune bête férocement intense.  Des malts totalement ténébreux qui sagitent dans un alcool poivré, floral et résineux.  Quelque chose aussi comme une liqueur de prunes noires qui, dans son élégante puissance, chasse les quelques signaux de fumée qui apparaissent ici et là.  Véritablement, une tempête de saveurs dans une barrique vaste comme un océan.  En bouche, fort heureusement, les bulles développent un système efficace qui confère une belle agilité à ce corps tout en rondeur.  La texture, visiblement liquoreuse, rappelle à mon cerveau que cette dégustation doit avancer avec lenteur.   En finale, je note plusieurs choses mais finalement je ne retiens que lessentiel.  Beaucoup de saveurs boisées et un alcool chaud qui semble porter toutes les déclinaisons possibles de lamertume.  Décidément, cette chose inusitée est une brute qui me fait un effet monstre.

Bottle. 4/6/13. Pours dark brown-black with a thin, bubbly brown head. Aroma is creamy, lots of fruit, vanilla, booze, wood. Something smells like aquavit in here; which I like. Taste is fruit, booze, vanilla, chocolate, roast; nice sweetness; finish is sweet, fruity with a light bitterness. Some light lacing. Medium carbonation. Chewy mouth feel. Really excellent. While some alcohol is present, its still very well hidden. Very tasty. Nice balance. It would be easy to get carried away with a few of these.
absolutely awesome. molasses, caramel, rich alcohol and perhaps a bit of whiskey coming though on the aging. extremely thick. brown ale? rather intense for that genre, surely. delicious.

Passed on this more times then I can remember, then received one as an extra in a box. I am ashamed to say I passed on such a great beer. Pours black with hardly any head. Aromas are minimal with some light wood, a  metallic undertone and molasses. Tastes are big while also being subtle. Very deft wood is present throughout the entire sip, with vanilla and caramel, just a hint of booze as the aftertaste comes on which is chocolate and cola. Mouthfeel is perfect for a big beer like this, silky-smooth and perfectly heavy on the tongue. Overall a really good sipping beer closer to a BA Stout than any brown, imperial or otherwise, that I have ever tried.
Dogfish sure knows how to make genre bending interesting beers.  Wood aged is present with this strong imperial brown.
Black and thick. Hardly any head. Roasted aroma, faint soy-sauce. Dark flavors, pepper, also sweetness, Moderate bitter finish. Syrupy texture.
Aroma is deceivingly uncomplicated, the taste leaves behind a surprisingly unique taste of wood and sweetness, mostly caramel.
12oz bottle. Pours pitch black with a brownish creamy head. Aromas of chocolate malt, oak, and booze. Taste is dark roasted malt, wood, chocolate, and alcohol.

Pours a fairly dark brown with a quick, stout-like brown chocolate head. Nose is also a bit like a cream stout, with fairly low hops, some dairy and sugar, and a touch of bourbon. Flavor is like a strong stout with modest hopping and a slow fade to wood and slight sourness; the roasted quality of the beer lasts from start to finish. Alcohol is well hidden for 12%. Not my favorite type stuff but a good beer and a quick way to get buzzed.
36cl, American brew, from De Bierkoning Amsterdam, very complex brew, woody/roasted and slightly spicy/alcoholic, not too heavy, balanced, hazy, good head, very good brew, yet expensive!

Very underwhelmed by this.  Pours a very dark brown, almost black - looks like an imperial stout, and very promising.  The aroma is that of a spicy coffee porter - nice but no complexity and barrel character.  The taste is very similar - kind of syrupy chocolate in this, pretty bitter but with a coffee molasses sweetness.  Feels very this for a 12abv beer, amazingly well hidden in every way.  This is not a terrible beer, a decent one that left me wanting a hell of a lot more.
Bottle bought in London. Creamy lightbrown good mostly lasting head. Black colour. Heavy malty and moderate hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate.
Pours a dark dark brown with tan head. Aroma is toasty dark fruit. Cherries and plums and alcohol. Flavor almost has a bourbon quality to it. Very woody but still sweet. Very strong.

Uploading old ratings that were missing comments. Nice big boozy brown ale. Woodiness comes through with some dark fruit and nuttiness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

One of the best beers Ive ever had. Poured dark with a red hue. Little head. Split between three of us, couldnt determine which nut, but I say an almond, fruity aroma. Taste delivered a real malty, nutty bomb with some vanilla in the mix. Heavy alcohol is not coupled with boozy palate wrecker. Something else! Must try.
Bottle. Another impressive showing from Dogfish Head unlike any beer I've had in recent memory. They achieved a complexity and balance that can be very hard to come by.

Quite sprightly, and belies the 12% abv in its laid-backness. Lots of dark sugars with honey, oak, liqourice and chocolate. Very well balanced and superb!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Light sweet burnt aroma, black light brown, light sweet light bitter medium soft nicw finish
Bottle.  Black colour with virtually no head. Weak aroma. Sweet spicy flavor. Oily palate.
Nose is dark fruit raisins. Color black dark brown. 1/2 finger khaki head. Thick like syrup sweet and can taste the alcohol. Great beer .

Bottled on 8/13/12.  Enjoyed this several times before, but finally getting around to rating it.  Pours pitch black with a medium, creamy, light brown head.  Rich, roasted malty aroma of caramel and chocolate with vanilla, woody, and alcohol notes.  Sweet toasted flavors of chocolate and vanilla, with slight woody and umami notes.  Very full body, without being syrupy.  The 12% definitely shows up on the finish with a slight alcohol burn, but it complements the toasted, woody flavor nicely.  Looking forward to the other two aging in the cellar...

Completely opaque black pour with light brown head. Medium lacing. Aroma has coffee, chocolate, vanilla and dark fruits. Very thick syrupy body. Starts off very complex like an imperial stout. Roasty chocolate and coffee. A little bit of alcohol burn up front as well. Leads into a nutty middle and nice sweet finish. Great winter beer. Too bad it's spring. 

---Rated via iPhone

Beautfiul opaque black color with a medium, persistent, creamy mocha head. Aroma is some plums and ripe bananas. Flavor is tobacco with some burnt notes and ripe fruits (bananas and plums), liccorice as well with a bitter finish. Full palate, silky mouthfeel, warming and full of flavor.
UPDATED: MAR 17, 2013 An absolutely beautiful beer, amazing flavor, quite thick and heavy, good for winter, lighter meal, tried later at pumphouse and was a bit too much, like a liquer

My 200th rating. 0.355l bottle. Very dark brown/ruby body, light brown head. Aroma of coffee, cherries and vanilla. Taste chocolate, loads of vanilla, cocoa and hazelnut. Ceramy texture. Very complex, truly amazing beer.

Great complex fast wee beverage.  
Pure black poor with thin tan head.
Aroma of superb roasted Malta molasses and slight coffee.
Aroma follows through with the flavours being the same but bigger and slightly more complex. There is added rasin and dark fruits, the wood aging becomes apparent with just a subtle interesting hint of something woody? I know there is a better word. 
The taste is very syrupy, very smooth. Nice heat on the back of the throat from the high abv. 
Brilliant beer that I will be revisiting in winter. Currently 34 degrees and I think this beep would taste even better on a day when temperature is closer to 9-10 degrees and its shit house outside.

Aroma: Smoky wood from the bottle blooms into cardamom, cola, vanilla, and a subtle but ever-present caramel scent in the glass (I poured into a Brandy glass.) Appearance: Deep, deep auburn with a creamy cocoa-powder colored head; head is minimal. Taste: Medium-sweet vanilla cola balanced by a light to medium sarsaparilla bitterness. Has a pleasant but lingering wet-wood aftertaste. Very unique, this Palo Santo wood. Palate: thin and not very carbonated.

Delicious beer whose wood character is as complex and pleasing as some of the best bourbon barrel aged beers out there.
UPDATED: MAR 6, 2013 Wood, and lots of roast on the nose. Pretty massive beer this one, with big roast flavours, hints of vanilla and some interesting wood like flavours. Pretty dam good beer

12 ounce bottle into signature tulip glass, bottled on 10/22/2012.  Pours almost pitch black color with a small foamy dark tan head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers.  Light spotty lacing clings on the glass, with a good amount of streaming carbonation retaining the small head.  Aromas of big caramel, brown sugar, molasses, raisin, fig, toast, dark bread, roasted malt, light char, wood, light vanilla, and roasted earthiness.  Damn nice aromas with good balance and complexity of malt and wood aging notes.  Taste of big raisin, fig, molasses, brown sugar, caramel, toast, dark bread, wood, roasted malt, light char, light vanilla, and roasted earthiness.  Lingering notes of dark fruits, molasses, brown sugar, toast, dark bread, wood, roasted malt, and roasted earthiness on the finish for a while.  Damn nice balance and complexity of very robust dark malt flavors with fruitiness; and hardly any cloying flavors present after the finish.  Medium carbonation and full bodied; with a very creamy, slick, and thick mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is well hidden with only a small warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is an excellent imperial brown ale.  Very nice complexity and balance of flavors; and quite smooth to sip on.  A very enjoyable offering.

Original batch 2008, 5 year old bottle. Lost the hotness, maintained the flavor, brilliant. The beer pours thick, dark and unclear with a definitive burnt sienna glow and big creamy dark beige to cocoa head. The aroma brings sweet roasted malts, a bit smoky, and unique woody notes of the palo santo, which I love. Big roasted notes and some light coffee lay on the tongue so nicely leaving the palate delighted.
Black with a brown head. Aroma is malt, roast and wood. Taste is booze and malt. This one reminded me of Struise Pannepot a lot, but without the complexity.

0.355l bottle shared with The Tasting Crew. This is a as good as black one. Yeah, lets call it a black one with a small bubbly and quickly sidesticking ashy beige top. On the nose its really nice with sweet raisins, glazed sweet fruits with a plushy soft roastiness combined with wood that in a way reminds a lot of bourbon. Also some chocolate thingy here. It smells really nice this. Its small prickling and gentle on the carbonation and it has a good thick mouthfeel. Great roastiness thats just tasting dark and almost black. Its dark fruity and just really really tasty. If kept in the mouth long enough you get a soft trace of smoky whisky. It ends light mouthdrying and almost woody with a dark chocolaty, roasted and slightly fruity finish. Oh, yeah! I could drink this again. And again. And perhaps even a couple of more times after that. 09.01.2012
Pours very dark with a thick head. Has a caramel like aroma and Chocolate notes are present when tasting. Very smooth going down. Delicious and satisfying brew.
I never thought I would enjoy drinking wood but I did. Unique wood flavoring have never had before. Like chewing on a pencil as a kid if the wood tasted great and wasn't coated in yellow garbage.

Aroma of dark roasted malts, wood, and notes of yeast. Pours an opaque black with a mostly diminishing dark tan head and fine lacing. The taste is mildly sweet. Roastest malts, wood notes, and hints of dark fruit, along with some hints of alcohol. A bitter finish and aftertaste are present. A very complex brew. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Overall, a very complex beer worth sipping and exploring - quite robust and enjoyable s a sipper.
I am vary suprised, more of a porter than a brown ale. Vary rich color dark brown to black, it has  more of a  porter quality IMO vary drinkable no alcohol taste, will buy this one again.

Bubblegum & Oak in the nose.  More intrigued by the aroma than usual.  Flavor betrays the youth (Aug12), and maintains a lot of sweetness, but such is not overwhelming.  Tickles the palate enough to throw some in the cellar.  And I will say, probably my favorite bottle cap yet.  

Awesome, awesome aroma.  The rest... good things to come.

Dark brown/black opaque beer with no head.  Aroma is alcoholic, burnt malt with very strong chocolate/coffee notes, also woody. Taste is a bit burnt/bitter and quite sweet. Palate creamy and thick, soft carbonation. Trends more toward the stout/porter than the "strong American ale" which is kind of a catch-all category anyway.  This is quite good!

UPDATED: APR 13, 2013 A wonderful smoked beer. Draft. Gorgeous pour of very black with deep tan head. Little lacing. Aroma of wood chips, oak and prunes. Smooth taste with raisins, wood smoke and malt. Very smooth finish with hint of cocoa.

12 oz bottle.  Pours very dark brown, almost black with a small brown head that doesnt last or lace the glass.  Aroma is wood, roasted and smoky malts, caramel and spiced hops.  The flavor is similar.  Pretty smooth for 12%.  Medium to full body with a slick oily texture and average carbonation.  A nice warming beer for a wintry day whilst sitting by the fire.
UPDATED: SEP 24, 2013 strong as hell, 12% beer, dont do anything except drink it slowly, big brown ale dedicated to getting in your system for life

Bottled - Pour is a deep dark brown with a persistent dark tan head. Aroma is lots of roasted malts and syrup. Taste is of burnt wood, not in a completely bad way, but its a very dark roasts beer. You can definitely tell it was aged in wood. Overall it's a nice selection for someone who likes this type of brew but not for me.

-optemoz

Very dark, strong stout-like taste. Smooth, rich taste with minimal bite. Very good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 Oz. Bottle poured Black with small tan head (that dissipated quickly). Aroma: Strong wood notes, roast malts and molasses. Taste is a very complex, roast malts, some very light fruit notes, wood... But overall a strong kick from the alcohol; dry kick towards the end. Again a very Complex beer, very nice.

Black pour with a small tan head. Aromas of roasted malt, wood, and coffee. I can already tell this is going to be a complex brew. I get a lot of the roasted malt and coffee character on the palate the wood character is more of a finishing note. It all mingles together really well. That 12% abv is also so well hidden it is almost unbelievable. Gotta give props to Dogfish Head, they consistently make respectable products and are always trying new things. Great job with this one!

A thin tan head on a black body.
The aroma is something else. Woody, roasted malt and nutty.
The taste is rich, roasted malt, heavily sweet and a little burnt wood. 
The texture is smooth with a little alcohol heat, low carbonation and heavy body.
A really good ale. At 12% it is almost too easy to drink.

Excellent dep penetrating nose when first opened and stoutlike to the eye. Head struggles to avoid diappearing ealy on but a really gogeous nose of morish molasses, brown sugar, wood and prunes. In the mouth its like two beers in one. On the bottom a thick full smoothness with a lean zesty spritziness on top. A bit of a faint metallic quality too. Even more alcohol than expected. Pretty good but not outstanding

Like a sweet stout, or porter, nothing like a brown ale or strong ale, very tasty, super strong, and bitter in the end, hits you in the mouth on the back end, super complex beer, very solid.  2012 vintage, drank fresh.

On tap at the abbey. Pours dark amber to brown. Aroma is strong alcohol with a sweetness. Bready taste, slightly thin with a strong kick. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Brown with ruby highlights and clear.  Smells of chocolate and dark fruit with savory character.  Same in taste with sweetness and wood character.  Good beer with porter character.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours dark brown with very little head.  Aroma is savory with dark fruit and some chocolate.  Taste is roasty with some cherry and malt with slight alcohol warming and burn. Also some sweetness.  Mouthfeel is slick and full. Good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled ~6 months ago. Been awhile since my last PSM, and I forgot how intensely the barrel shines through in both the aroma and on the palate. No hiding the booze here: it's a big, complex brew. Hands down the most flavorful (and, arguably, best) Dogfish beer.

very dark opaque body with a small bubbly film if tan foam. aroma resembles a bananasplit, with icecream and chocolate topping. very peculiar, but likeable. also some roastyness there and something that i presume comes from the palo santo wood. taste is sweet and roasty, fruityness is medium and finish is dry with aftertaste of coffee, liquorice and leather. slick, oily mouthfeel and low carbonation.

Different than the usual beer and I give Dogfish Head credit for pushing the envelope...but I don't love it.  Nice nose of cola, dark fruit and wood.  Very heavy, with notes of raisins and burnt coffee.  Finish is bitter with the alcohol coming through.  Worth trying, but not for me.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
From bottle. Pours ruby red with thin head. Aroma was sweet  with a smoked earthiness. Taste was deep dark fruit and smoke with booze.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2014 Pours near black with khaki fizz. The aroma is roasted grains with an alcoholic fruitiness. The taste is rich thick roasted grains with a robust chocolate malt and a rich dark fruit alcohol mingled with some drying bittering roasted grains with a touch of earthy herbal hops and a very light amount of smoked malt. -- 2 year 2010 Aged bottle produces more dark chocolate and smooth fruity flavors, the alcohol warmth turned into robust smooth natural flavors while still keeping the extra thick body round the beer. A very supreme brew. --
Bottle:  Pours a dark ruby with a thin tan head, big smoky aroma, starts and ends lightly sweet with a roasted booze ending, full bodied with ample carbonation.
Wow the smoke just billows off this one! Pours dark brown to almost black with a smooth mouthfeel. I will definitely be having this again if possible!

Dried fruit, malty, boozy aroma. Very dark pour with thick tan head that dissipates evenly leaving nice thin lacing. Sweet dried fruits with a hint of tartness. Cocoa bitter finish. Effervescent down the sides of the tongue. Very pleasant mouthfeel with alcohol warmth in the throat. This is a very nice well balanced beer.

Cola brown pour, almost no head. Sweet barrel smell with dark fruit, brown sugar, smokey. A sweet plum, prune, brown sugar, medicinal tones, toasty and smokey, anise. Overall, interesting taste, a lot going on with the sweet and smoke. Good barrel taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Antioch Fine Wine. Pours a purple-black with a reddish brown head that fades to nothing quickly. Interesting and surprising color in the pour. Aroma has sweet caramel, brown sugar, dark fruit and wood. Taste is of sweet brown sugar, raisins/figs, licorice and a woody earthiness. A bit rough. Definite alcohol presence. Finishes very sweetly with some salt - brown sugar & licorice. Curious if this will mellow with age, although at Antioch it probably is somewhat already.

Pours a deep mahogany brown color with a finger of off white foam. On the nose its got a lot of earthy wood notes; vanilla, caramel,raisin and hints of chocolate malt. On the palate its big and full of woody earthy notes. Nice touches of sweetness ride the earthy vanilla and dark fruit notes. Very well hidden booze and a solid example of what wood can do !
Pours thick and black with a thin tan head. Aroma of wood, vanilla and raisins. Warming mouthfeel. Heavy smoked wood flavor with an aggressive alcohol finish.
Bottle pours dark brown with nice brown head.  Aroma of vanilla beans.  Flavors of black licorice, molasses, burnt sugar, and earthy goodness.  This is great stuff.
Nice, dark, flavourful beer. Extremely smooth with a good head. Full of malts and the wood flavour.

dark, syrupy pour with medium tan head.  flavor is mainly roast with some definite character from the wood.  finishes with chocolate, coffee, and some vanilla notes; hard to tell that its a brown ale lurking under all of those big flavors. thick, but hides the alcohol well.  enjoyable.

12oz bottle fresh from the brewery. Pours a dark black brown, opaque and unfiltered. Nice half finger tan head. Great big beer, smells like wood. Crazy spicy Palo Santo wood. Definitely a lot of roastyness and dark sweet brown sugar. Earthy hops and a little dark fruit. Boozy and sweet. Tastes excellent, smoky sweet roasted malts and spicy woody character. Sweet and woody, lots of vanilla and dark fruit. Nice crisp hoppy finish and a warming tingle on the way down. The unique flavor added by the palo santo wood aging tank adds a ton of depth, and sweetness to this beer. Heavy sticky mouthfeel, nicely carbonated. Head has stuck around. Could definitely develop the woody, vanilla sweet character over time as the hops and alcohol subside. Brilliant and unique strong ale. Wouldnt have more than one at a time lol

Look: Black body with dark brown hues, big 2 1/2 finger frothy khaki head. Smell: Cabnet aroma, roasted barley, dark fruits, toffee sweetness, spices, brown sugar, alcohol. Taste: Roasted malt, fruits ( maybe some cherries), brown sugar, vanilla, toffee, alcohol warmth. Feel: Full bodied mediocre carbonation. Overall: This brew has alot of Imperial Stout qualities to it. When warms, the wood characteristics pull through nicely. This is a nice after dinner treat. Alcohol plays a roll in it, but its not offensive (atleast it wasnt offensive to me). The carbonation could be more lively that is the only thing I found fault in this brew. Other than that, this is tasty and Recommended.

Bottle, dated may 2010. Jet black and thick, with small brown head. Tasted of concentrated liquidised raisins, and quite boozy but the alcohol was reasonably hidden considering. Very intense like a liqueur; nice in small quantities but I found it difficult to finish the bottle.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft at alehouse.  Black with tan head.  Aroma is spicy and woody.  Tastes of dark chocolate, tannins and spices.  Very very good.

Pours dark black with tan head. Aroma is roast and chocolate. Dark roasty malts, chocolate, little vanilla. More sweet than I expected, in a good way.  Lots going on that i cant really put my finger on. The wood started to come through more as it warmed up. Covers up the 12% remarkably well. Yuummyyyy

Interesting take on a brown ale: big, boozy, and syrupy, with underlying brown ale notes. Good!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Rich, creamy, thick and smooth. Big dark fruit flavors throughout. Wood and roasted malts show up as the beer warms. Finish is sweet with a light boozyness. Tasty.
Found this to be a rich and complex beer.  Not much aroma, taste is a little roasty/smokey and almost has a creamy/thick finish.  Really good beer!

Rich color, with a brown head. Rich and complex aroma. Taste of smoke, wood and caramel.  Slight astringency. Lingering sweetness/maltiness. Little hop bitterness and almost no aroma. Overall a very intriguing beer. well worth the try.

12oz bottle purchased long ago, bottled 7/24/08.  Pours a deep, dark brown color with a very thin, tan head.  Just a few bubbles around the edge of the glass.  Aroma is dark fruit, raisin, a little roasty, a little boozy.  Heavy on the palate with light, soft carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, Malty, brown sugar, earthy, woody, a little bready, with a sweet, boozy finish. Different, for sure.
Aromas intriguing.  Spicy wood with thorough roast on the nose. Super dark with brown head. Taste is month roast, wood, and some nuts. A bit boozy, nice and thick. Great beer.

Bottle. Pours clear dark brown to black with a medium head that dissipates with decent lacing. Aroma is dark roasted malt, molasses, coffee, dried fruit, spice. Flavor is quite sweet and spicy/woody with mild coffee bitterness. Body is medium to full, creamy in the mouth. Alcohol is apparent in the warming finish, but well masked otherwise. This was a nice beer, and could pass for an imperial stout.
Nice and complex. Some brown sugared sweetness, vanilla, bread, and dark fruit.  Wood aging is a dominant characteristic of the beer, but not overwhelming.

Excellent beer that reminds me more of a good porter. Smooth, easy to drink, great balance. Dark chocolates and espresso followed by brown sugar and a nice, earthy spiciness. Not overly sweet at all. Finish is bits of vanilla, heat from the alcohol, and something like the bite of cinnamon, without the body of it. Interesting.

Bouteille 12 oz. 12%. Couleur brune très foncé, presque noire, mousse brune. Très épaisse, onctueuse, belle robe. Arôme de bois, sucre, malt. En bouche, torréfaction, espresso, un peu de choco, bois, vanille, chêne, houblon. Wow...excellente.

12 oz bottle poured into wine glass. Dark brown color with a small hazel colored head that laces well on the glass as you sip. Aroma is slightly sweet with vanilla, smoky and brown sugar notes. Taste is delicious: smoky and sweet with a hint of alcohol on the finish. This beer is a winner and probably my favorite brown ale

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured opaque black, with a big, tan head.  Very appealing.  Aroma is mostly winter fruit.  Taste is wood, chocolate, and raisin, with a little bit of cherry.  Kind of a blend between a barley wine and an imperial stout.  Great beer.

Instant "must have". Nice brown/red color, funky little beige head. Very roasty without the overly burnt notes. Dark cherry/plum.woodsy aroma. Carried through in the taste with maybe even a hint of prune. Creamy, a bit thick and sticky, not highly carbonated. Smoky/oaky/woods flavor. Great drinking beer, but the ABV does sneak up - I dont find it obvious that this is a 12% beer.

Bottled on 5-20-08:  The pour is a deep syrupy brown with a thin mocha head that doesnt leave much lacing.  The aroma is quite flavorful with some underlying hints of a true brown ale but predominantly powered by a semi-sweet booziness.  The taste is very rich and complex.  The balance is perfect as traces of wood are present throughout.  This is big but not over the top bold and exceptionally smooth at 12%,  Absolutely incredible!  I feel that the 4+ years of aging turned a very good beer into a great one!

Aroma of oak and cherries. Pours 
Black hue with a beige fluffy head. Scotch, oak, cherries, and smoke on the palate. Sweet cherries and alcohol on the finish.

12oz bottle.  Pours black with a thin cocoa coloured head.  Aroma is boozy up front with dried cherries, cocoa, espresso, and molasses.  The taste.  Dear lord the taste.  This beer is incredible, huge flavour, lengthy finish, and mouth coating.  Molasses, and lots of it, dates, dried cherries, alcohol, faint smoke, espresso, and a bitter earthiness in the finish.  I love this beer.  Seriously amazing stuff.  Stop reading this and buy it right now!
Aroma is strong dark fruit/vinous and other fruit from the wood aging.  The flavor is dark fruit, almost wine-like, notes of coffee and toffee and malts and warming alcohol in the finish.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2012 12 oz bottle. Pours an opaque red black with almost no head. Aromas of light wood smoke, dark fruit, and roasted malt. Very similar flavors, heavier on the wood smoke but with a nice smooth fruity undertone. Alcohol is well hidden. Very nice.

Pour is jet black with a big dark tan head. Aroma is vanilla, chocolate, cherry, molasses, earth, sweet fruitcake, port and oaky cask wood. Flavour is a heavy sweetness up front, an explosion of fruity woodiness, some alcohol then big roasty coffee. Mouthfeel is quite slick, flat carbonation. Complex and incredibly tasty.

Draught Breukelen bier merchants.  Deep brown with tan head and legs. Looks a stout. Almost tastes a stout but with more caramel, barely. Aroma is very sweet with earthy hops, and boozy rich fermented dark fruit.  Flavor is more pronounced alcohol, some more heavily roasted malt, and strong sweetness and bitterness. Wood is  present in flavor and feel, which is us fairly thick and syrupy though drying at the end.  Rich big and luxurious though not so much that you couldnt drink it often.

Aroma: chocolate and malt
Appearance: very dark brown with a medium to light head that has a dark appearance.
Taste: definitely taste a burntness with a slight metallic tone.
Palate: malty on the front, acidy on the end.
Overall: I am usually not a dark beer drinker, but this beer is very good.

Roasty and bold. This is a big beer folks. The flavor profile is so complex that I find it almost impossible to express everything going on.  It is a heavy bodied very dark brown ale that pours a nice 1 or so mocha head  into a snifter.  On the nose dark raosty malts and fragrant esters can be a bit overwhelming, if you are not expecting it.   Mouthfeel is heavy and tends to lend to a bit syrupy, but not to degrade the experience.  Favor is off the charts from sweet and malty to a bit bitter, not from hops, but the dark malts, to a very pleasant after-taste that hangs around for a good while.   I would recommend this beer to anyone other than the beginner.

Very dark brown, almost black, liquid with medium to big, thick tan/mocca head. Nice lacing. Aroma is malt forward with notes of dark fruit, toffee, wood, chocolate, a hint of booze, bread and maybe some port. Taste is light sweet and medium bitter with dark fruit, chocolate, espresso and wood. Full bodied with soft carbonation and smooth mouthfeel.

This is pretty much a stout, with dark brown almost black pour. Aroma of roasted grain, dirt and some light chocolate. Taste is bitter chocolate with serious booze. A strong sipper, but very noce. Full bodied and crazy strong for a brown ale.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very dark, near opaque color and dark head. Loved it-complex, toasty, and very drinkable.
I really like this one. Very full of a good wood flavor. Easy to drink. It has a lovely aftertaste that is not over strong but lasts awhile.

Dark brown body.  Thin medium brown head that forms a nice collar.  Light lacing.  Nose is predominately roasted malts and caramel.  Some chocolate, dark fruits, earthy hops, and wood is also present.  Flavor is similar, but with the dark fruits (mostly raisin) increasing their presence.  Medium to full bodied, lightly boozy, mellow carbonation, lingering finish.

POurs very dark brown almost black. No head (in small sampler glass though). Aroma is nice and chocolatey, spicy, woody, vanilla, almost no alcohol in aroma. Taste has a very earthy woody flavour to it aswell as, vanilla, chocolate, sweet liqourice. This is a very unique and interesting beer on many levels!

Oh boy, was this fantastic!  When I picked this up from my local bottle shop, I wasnt sure what to expect.  I had had my fair share of bland and unenticing brown ales, but I figured with an abv of 12%, this was worth a try.  The beer poured out thick and dark with a nice roasty, cappuccino-colored head.  Smells of sherry, dark oak, bitter chocolate and roast wafted up from the glass as I took in this massive beer, admiring it.  On the palate, it was very chewy with a lot of rich dark chocolate, deep oak, and a twinge of roasted coffee, and a LOT of malt.  The alcohol heat was present, but worked well with the malt bill and the good kick of thick roast and dark chocolate.  The heat was put out by a drying, sticky finish and the mouth was left with a slick coating.  Overall, this redefined what my idea of a brown ale could be - another phenomenal effort from Dogfish Head

Caramel, toffee aroma, dark brown in color. Taste like an imperial stout but the vanilla and toffee flavor disguise the bitterness. Palo Santo has a very strong flavor, but it has the adequate amount. Very high in alcohol. Good beer even thou It is not my style, I like it. But two 12 oz are enough for me

Tap. Pours dark dark brown, thin sticky tan head. Roasty aromas, some dark fruit, notes of chocolate. Big dark fruit and cocoa flavors, present alcohol, some vanilla. Silky mouthfeel, medium high carbonation, maybe even a little to much considering the high alcohol and sweetness.

aged for two years.
very thick and black, almost like a stout.
nice strong aromas of roasted malts and alcohol.
same on taste, with some dark fruits as aftertaste. you can taste the strongness of this beer

Bottle - not much head, black color, roasted malt aroma and flavor with
some wood and very mild coffee notes

Drank two bottles in a stemless wine goblet in front of the outdoor firepit last night, thanks Tom! It poured a mostly clear dark brown color with thick beige foam, lasting with nice Belgian lace. Magnificent aromas of caramelized malt, freshly-baked brown bread, vanilla and woodsy undertones, and some fruity ale yeast esters and citrusy/flowery hops combined with the smooth alcohol to become perfume. Taste was as delicious as the aroma: perfect balance of malt sweetness and tangy hops bitterness, toffee, light molasses. Medium-heavy body, and moderate carbonation. Well-rounded, "chewy" mouthfeel with multi-layered bittersweet aftertaste. Somewhat boozy and warming, but no ragged fusel alcohols whatsoever. Double the alcohol as Bud Light Platinum, folks, which tastes like jet fuel, but this was flawlessly balanced. Reminiscent of a hoppier English Old Ale or Belgian Dubbel plus incredible wood-aging. So, so tasty. Again, thank you Tom!

Bottle sample.
Opaque brown, small mocha head.
Perfumy nose, cherries, chocolate and wood.
Vanilla flavors, with figs, cocoa, and juicy maltiness. Low bitterness.
Full body, thick, alcoholic and heavy. Long finish. Cool but hard to drink.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2013 From a 33cl bottle. Pours a black and oily with a. Dry thin brown head that disappears fast.  Raisins and dark cherries in the nose. Alcohol mellowed by wood chips, notes of bitter sweet chocolate. Bitter alcohol finish.
10/7/13: in draft at the brewery.  Nice fresh.  Should be sublime with some age.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2016 Malt Beverage Aged on Palo Santo Wood. 12% ABV. Syrup-black, sparkling color, dark-brown, loose, very tall, short-lived head. Coffee, Madeira wine, balsamic vinegar, intense, well defined nose. Full body, over-alcoholic, burnt-sugar taste and bitterness, texture not as silky as it appears on pouring, sweet-alcoholic character and after-taste, decent length but not lingering. Comfort food class, not very elegant but delicious all the same, Malt Beverage Aged on Palo Santo Wood. 12% ABV. Syrup-black, sparkling color, dark-brown, loose, short-lived head. Coffee, chlorophorm, definite nose. Full body, silky texture, but not as much as one would expect from the pour. Over-alcoholic, intense burnt-sugar taste and bitterness, sourish. Sweet-alcoholic and medicinal character and after-taste, balanced by roast bitterness, decent length but not lingering. Comfort food class, not very elegant, good as way to end a meal, with cheese or like a port. ood as way to end a meal like a port. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone Malt Beverage Aged on Palo Santo Wood. 12% ABV. Syrup-black, sparkling color, dark-brown, loose, short-lived head. Coffee, creosote, alcohol, iodine, tar and smoke smells in the assertive nose. Full body, moderate flavor, hot alcohol, silky and frothy texture, but not as much as one would expect from sound of the pouring. Balanced, avg length, sweetish finish. Sweet & sour, some roast bitterness, over-alcoholic, intense burnt-sugar taste and bitterness. Sweet-alcoholic, pleasantly medicinal character and after-taste, balanced by roast bitterness, decent length but not lingering. Coffee, hoppy, dried cherries, prunes, balsamic vinegar, tar, vanilla, coca-cola syrup, Comfort food class, not very elegant but very enjoyable, good as way to end a meal, perhaps with cheese (worked well with a Stilton) or like a port. Practically a stout. A favorite of mine in this style.
Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. A big chewy beer. The Palo Santo wood is spicy,earthy, musty, and yup woody. It is a nice compliment to the big malt character, raisin, toffee, prune. A solid beer.

12 oz Bottle. Pours brown, almost black with a very thin tan head, good thick lacing. High roasty and malt with dark fruit aroma. Nice taste of raisin, plum, cherry. Very full body, creamy sticky texture, soft carbonation. Excellent paired with a cigar.
Nice beer, pours black with a yellow small head. Nice aroma. Coffe and malt. Tastes like the famous wood, and bitter but sweet. Nice complex and robust
Holy crap this is one potent beer. Defintiely a sipper. Very much a black licorice beer with a bitter finish. Enjoy it with a nice dark choclate, no more than 72% cacao.

This was not at all what I was expecting. Year old bottle. This pitch black with thin tan head. The body of a stout. Smells like whiskey and wood. The taste though is very complex - vanilla, chocolate, raisin and wood. Really boozy, but a great sipper.
Great for a high gravity brew which usually isnt my thing. Sweet flavors balances with good hop bitterness. Coffee, creamy, boozy. Tasty and complex, warming.

At the brewpub in June.
A nice, strong beer. The wood used with this is the densest wood in the world, according to the brewery tour. Great flavor from the wood with some fruit as well, possibly raisins. Bought a few for the ride home.

2012 bottle served in a trappist glass. Pours an opaque black with a thin tan head and minimal lacing. It looks like a RIS. Aroma is roasted barley, wood, alcohol, dark fruit, and cognac. Flavor is malts up front. Nutty, roasty, and woody. There is dark fruit there, namely cherries, as well as a black grape flavor. The mouthfeel is heavier and sticky with lots of alcohol there. Really excellent sipper.

Poured from 12 oz bottle into pint glass.  Great flavor!  The raisin notes and rich flavor make this a unique beer.  It almost has a brandy-like quality.  Quite good for a 12% beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with a small head. Can definitely smell the wood in this that reminds me of a whiskey. Strong smell, but easy malty taste. The aging makes it a tad harsh to me, but not bad.

Bottled. Thx to SS GT2.  Pitch lak coloured. Dense Brown head. Aroma of tar, roast, chocolate, smoke, oak, Cocoa. Flavour of chocolate, roast, Brown sugar, oak, Spice and a ad of ar and smoke. Medium to full bodied. End on a Roasty light bitter note. Loads of Warming on lips and Palate.

Bottle (12 oz). Black with a medium quickly diminishing creamy brown head and some lacing. Aroma of wood, roasted malt, vanilla, caramel, dark fruits and nuts. Taste is sweet with roast malt, vanilla, caramel and dark fruits. Slight bitterness and slight acidic presence. Mouthfeel is creamy and oily but leaves mouth dry. Full bodied. Heavy and interesting beer.

Bottle at home - 10/06/12. 2009 aged purchased from the brewpub in Rehoboth.
Dark oliy brown in colour approaching black with a good tan head.
Roasted malts, sweet tones, hickory, wood, creasote, coffee, slight metallic nose.
Taste as nose perhaps a little sweeter than the aroma indicated and a bit more wood and some spice.
Medium bodied, not too much carbonatin, slick and creamy on the mouth.
Id had a fresh bottle of this a few years back but cant give any great comparison between fresh and aged suffice to say this was excellent and certainly as good as!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
12 oz bottle poured into a snifter.

A: Pours an almost pitch black color with very little light coming through. Very little head to speak of, aside from a very thin tan-colored collar. A brown ale that thinks its an imperial stout? This now has my attention. 

S: Caramel, chocolate, vanilla, dark fruits, booze, and oak comprise the aromatic qualities. Faint, but forgivable given its lack of head.

T: The flavor sees an uptick in the nuttiness befitting a brown ale, especially on that first sip. Caramel, roasted coffee, licorice, toffee, and vanilla make an appearance on the midtaste and finish, but it could stand to be a touch more complex. The aftertaste has a good amount of darker fruits and anise, but otherwise, the general flavor profile gives off a vibe of spiked hazelnut coffee. Pretty damn boozy and tannic. Honestly, this could pass for a fruitier imperial stout along the lines of Stone IRS, rather than a rinky dink, run of the mill brown ale. Id call it out on not having enough in the way of roastiness, but you know, brown ale, and stuff...

M: Id call it medium bodied, perhaps ever so slightly erring on the side of light. Weakly carbonated, like I expected. The finish and aftertaste tries to strike a balance between tannic dryness and sticky wetness, and just about pulls it off, right before the tannins fade a little on the palate. Booze isnt particularly stealthy, so sip this one, preferably at a higher temperature. EDIT: It actually becomes quite hot at a higher temperature, so Im lowering the score here. Yeesh, this is practically burning.

O: Ive heard of porters that think theyre stouts, but a brown ale that thinks its an imperial stout? In its current state, its pretty damn enjoyable, but still too young and hot. This could become great with a year of age, and its readily available/cheap-ish enough (for what it is, $15/4 pack isnt chump change) to make picking up a 4 pack to age a worthy endeavor.

10oz glass at Tylers Apex. Real good.aroma, sweet, roasty. Nice malty cocoa chocolate notes, marshmellow, dry wood taste.  dark Orangy brown color, nice initial head that faded quickly to a ring. Bittersweet flavor. Medium body, thick creamy mouthfeel, sweet roasty finish. Real tasty, surprised I havent rated this.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Deep oak, rasin and molasses aromas. Very dark shade of magenta with no foam whatsoever. Flavors of dark maple, caramel, dates, anise, alcohol and some other flavors I cant pinpoint. Deep syrupy malts with a nice alcohol finish. Overall, a very complex and dark brew boasting some intense and balanced flavors. Well done, Dogfish Head, well done. A rating.

Fantastic. The nose is full of woodsy notes mixed with alcohol and sweet malt scents. Deep brown with a tight beige foam cap. Sweet with alcohol sensations and notes of wood and caramel with just the lightest bitterness. Full and warming with a sweet finish.

Black pour, dark brown head,  a lot of complexity going on with this one.  caramel, chocolate, roasty aroma, heavy cloying sweetness (Im guessing because o fthe high abv, which gives the sweet taste), , full body, thick feel, average carbonation, long finish, I felt the beer actually got better as it got a little warmer as as the drink went longer.
UPDATED: FEB 17, 2013 Bottle pour. Dark brown, thin beige head. Oak, some smoke, burnt roasts, vanilla, chocolate, booze, wild fruits, slight vinous notes.

i saw the brown ale part.  didnt see the 12 percent abv part.  easily the strongest beer ive had so far.  holy crap.  
here we go
smell is actually not very harsh.. brown ale but not unlike that of a sierra tumbler.  small film of head on the top.. extremely dark beer.  ok the taste on this one is reminiscent of black cherry medicine if there ever was once a thing.  nyquil kinda.  i dont know if i can dig on this.. belly just got real hot.  bugs are trying to jump in my glass.  I get it.. this is an east coast brewery.  they have a show on tv.  i just never fell in love with any of their beers.  punkin probably the only one i would drink and ill probably never buy another flavored beer again.  This beer gets great ratings.  i guess im just kinda novice when it comes to 12 percent brown ales.   eck.
Dark pour with dark tab head. Nose is dark fruit forward and a bit malty. Soft mouthfeel, boozy, malty, dark fruits and an unusual woodiness that must be the palo santo. Really nice!

Another extraordinary beer on tap at Aces. Pours black with a foamy tan head. Aroma of bread and nuts with small amounts of chocolate. Very complex body of dried red fruit, oak, and caramels. Finish is slightly fruity. Different and delish!

Bottle from Super Jrs, San Diego. Very dark brown, almost black, liquid with medium to big, thick tan/mocca head. Nice lacing. Aroma is malt forward with notes of dark fruit, toffee, wood, chocolate, a hint of booze, bread and maybe some port. Taste is light sweet and medium bitter with dark fruit, chocolate, espresso and wood. Full bodied with soft carbonation and smooth mouthfeel. Nice stuff, but I cant really get my head around it. Its almost like an Imperial Porter, but also a bit quad-ish... Weird style wise. A bit boozy.

Smells of dark and roasted malts- a little sweet, a little semi-sweet chocolate, a slight twinge of booze. Taste is full and rich- lots of roasted malt (almost like an imperial stout), some brown sugar, nice round wood notes, a little booze, and some hops towards the end. Mouthfeel is all right- full body, mild soft carbonation. Long semi-sweet finish. This is a good beer- it is very expensive and I may not get it again, but it is worth trying.

Bottle. Pours dark black with chocolatey brown head. Nose is chocolate and toasty malts. Taste is really great--taste is the same, plus tons of wood. A great beer given its wide distribution.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with thin brown head. Roasty, woody, and chocolate aroma, can also smell the alcohol but curbed well for 12%. Medium sweet flavor. Full body, texture on the thick and creamy side, alcohol taste at the very end. Overall a unique strong brown ale with a pleasant taste and a kick.

Bottle. Aromas of sweetened espresso, vanilla, and wild fumes. Very pretty dark black coffee color with a dark tan head. Initial is smooth rich coffee, some sort of spice / mid flavors same but steadily intensifying / final blends with some alc. burn. As creamy and smooth as can be. This is a brown ale "plus alpha," (as they say in Japan). Could be served as a dessert beer in small tea cups with petite madeleines or marshmallows.

Pours black with thin tan head. Aroma of port wood, brown sugar, dark fruit and alcohol. Taste is sweet with a huge warming alcohol finish. Body is thick, rich and creamy. The perfect beer to finish the night with.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

It poured a dark brown color with a small tan head. The aroma was of sweet malts, mostly chocolate, a little vanilla, some toffee and wood. The taste was rich and complex with smoke, booze and some dark fruit. Very good.

12 oz. Bottle. I loved this beer! Wood, roasted hop scent with vinous, cherry, taffy notes as it warmed. Black pour, red tint, dark brown head that quickly dissolved to a ring. Thick bodied, creamy texture. Woody, roasty, cherry, vinous taste to an alcohol burny finish.

Dark pour. Small head that vanished quickly. Smells of roasted malts and coffee. Chocolate taste turns to molasses with faint alcohol afterwards. Very heavy. Very good and vet potent. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

26/VII/2012 - 12 Fl. Oz. bottle (I presume, was not printed) @ Klaas place - BB: n/a - (2012-755) Thanks to Jeremy for the bottle!
Dark brown beer, clear small irregular head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: rum raisins, alcohol, sugary, mocha, red forest fruits, dark chocolate, ripe black cherries, dried fruits. MF: soft carbon, full body, thick viscose texture. Taste: mocha, lots of dark chocolate, little sugary, dried fruits, some liquorish, alcohol, bit earthy. Aftertaste: mocha, dark chocolate, raisins, dry earthy touch, sugar, caramel, little bitter, cocoa powder, some chocolate, ripe fruits, cherries.

I initially tried Palo Santo Marron at a tasting hosted by Sam Calagione. He introduced it as "one of the best beers I have ever made." If that isnt intriguing to a beer lover, and especially a fan of Dogfish Head, what is? I was blown away with the quality of my one inch beer ration, and also mournful that this brew would not be available for the forseeable future. Now, much to my delight, it is here at last.

This review is from the original bottling date Feb 11, 2008. Taken from my cellar.

A: Very dark brown and rich, almost black, like an imperial stout

S: High abv% slightly evident in the nose, though much less so than a fresh bottle. rich brown ale and wood aromas

T: Delicious. Although the alcohol is present in the aroma, it is well disguised in the taste. I think the time spent in the cellar has mellowed this beer out. The Palo Santo wood creates a pleasant lingering aftertaste.

M: Smooth and easy, perhaps too easy!

D: A great beer to share with someone, although, since it does go down quite easy, considering it is 12%, you could enjoy one all to yourself, as well.

12 oz into dixie cup
A- black with dense brown head, looks delicous.
S- Coffee, malt, sweet
T- Sweet but not cloying, roasty but not stouty, amazingly little boozyness, absolutely delicious.
M- Medium consistency, good tingly carbonation that fits the beer well.
O- Really nice, beer, would drink again in a heartbeat.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-05-2012 01:38:16
