The sweet of chocolate and the biterness of coffee come thru in the aroma. The color is black with a small light brown head. The taste right off the bat i get the alcohol taste/feel. I get a malty taste hidden by the chocolate malts. Long in the aftertaste i get almost a banana taste on the back of my tounge. The body is surprizingly a full body but a light full body.  Overall not bad for a strong basically all i expected minus the body. Worth a buy

Very pleasant aroma and brown pour leads to a smooth taste and balanced mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft received in a stemmed tulip. Thick light brown foam that slowly melts to a nice film. No lacing. Aroma is fruity caramel, malt and a bit of coffee. Nice. Very smooth. Sweet malt and coffee taste. Theres also some other flavors I cant place. Some fruit? Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. Fairly heavy. This is a great beer. Deep and complex. I assume it will change as it warms. Definitely belongs on the "get some" list. More beer please...

** update - much more wood after it warmed. Smoother and a definite molasses tone. Excellent!

Poured black with off white head and medium bubbles. Aromas of strong maltyness with coffee and dark fruits overtones, with undertones of a roastyness and wood.  Malt flavor with coffee, fig and cherries with notes of wood.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2017 2017 Rating 3.7

Nose is malty.  subtle.  Lots of alchol.  Very balanced and enjoyable.  

2015 Rating 3.5

Thin head super dark big alchol hit.  Light nutty aroma.  Taste is like an imperial stout without the hops side.  Okay, toasty..  Easy on the palate.  not bad in general not top notch though.

Bottled. Pours pitch black with a small beige head. Nose of slightly roasted malt, wood, caramel and alcohol. Sweet flavor with caramel, chocolate, vanilla and overripe fruit along with some spicy notes. More dry finish with a little malt bitterness and alcohol. Excellent and an enjoyable sipper.

2011 bottle poured in snifter.  Very dark brown color, almost black, with a very thin beige head.  Pretty thick lacing on the glass.  Big candy like aroma.  Lots of chocolate, toffee, caramel, vanilla, booze, and licorice.  Taste is pretty sweet up front with lots of chocolate and caramel flavor.  Some moderate bitterness.  Pretty smooth finish with a very slight alcohol burn which is really nice.  The candy taste lingers a while.  Still tasting lots of chocolate, toffee, and vanilla.  A really great sipper.
Awesome flavor and incredibly enjoyable. Definitely my new favorite brown ale. Their 90 minute IPA is wonderful as well!
140217. Bottle at beer mongers, Portland. Pours dark brown/black with a small head. Aroma chocolate, roasted malts.Slightly soapy texture. Full bodied. Not Bad.

Black pour with medium brown head. Poured into a snifter at Kalamazoo beer exchange. Sweet scent paired with chocolate. Super light mouth feel. Sweet on the tounge. Chicory taste, mostly malty. Super crisp dry finish. Leaves chalky film in your mouth reminiscent of the silt at the bottom of a cup of French pressed coffee.

Draft at Fermentation. Deep, dark brown pour with a thick tan head. Big chocolate malt up front on the nose with oak and earthiness. Flavor comes with more mixed berries, bittersweet chocolate, wood, booze and ends on a slight bitterness. Not too shabby.

Draft into a snifter at The Dash Inn in Ft. Wayne, IN. Apparently they bought a keg and then kept it in the basement for three years. 

Beautifully dark beer with medium body and light lacing. The 12% abv is veiled behind sweet chocolate an cocoa flavors all held up by smokey wooden undertones. The finish lingers with dry smoke. 

All in all a very good beer.

Bottled 5-16-2012.

A: Pitch black with a fine tan coating on top. Absolutely perfect in my snifter.

S: Whoa, this is one unique aroma, mildly sweet of a woody earthy aroma, roasted malts, caramel, vanilla, honey, and nuts. This is complex and very appealing and unlike anything Ive ever experienced thanks to the Palo Santo wood, while being strangely familiar.

T: A mildly nutty brown ale flavor makes the intro hinting at honey and vanilla as an interesting wood flavor makes the mid-taste, the finish comes on strong with alcohol hitting, but mainly warming the throat. This is incredibly easy to drink for the alcohol.

M: Thick with hints of fizzy carbonation.

O: This is simply a fantastic beer. The aroma is one of the best Ive ever smelled and the only downfall, which may be a positive, of the flavor is the warming alcohol on the finish. Fuck this is good.

On tap half pint at Gillys Craft Beer ANC Fine Wine in Rockville, MD. Opaque, brown black with 2-finger tan head and excellent lacing. Beautiful to look at. Aroma of dark fruits, wood, caramel, toffee, vanilla, cocoa powder, and molasses. Taste of vanilla, molasses, wood, caramel, coffee and dark fruit. A touch ad alcohol burn at the very finish. Full body and medium/high carbonation yields a rich, foamy mouthfeel. A fabulous beer! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Splendid beer. Has the complexity of a dark beer, but a nice drinkable light beer quality all with a woody undertone. An extremely dark brown pour with a large tan head. Aroma had wood presence, alcohol, vanilla, burnt sugar. The taste was just as complex with a wonderful burnt wood profile that was smokey and sweet with the background of big malts. Still drinkable even the big and noticeable booze. Fantastic stuff.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2013 Have had a few times but found a 5 year old keg on draft at Eulogy. Very dark brown with a foamy brown head. Wonderfully thick syrupy brown ale. Maple malty sweet. Burned caramel. Vanilla bean. Coffee. Raisins. Leather. Ash. Campfire marshmallows on fire. Remarkably smooth finish, at least in the aged version. Has a slightly creamy palate. Deep and complex. Very very nice! Update: Having a 2008 bottle in August 2013. Aged very well. Thinner but smoother. Very sipable. Great stuff!!!

Wow really good smooth dark brown ale. Dark like stout or Porter but light and smooth like a lager but an ale. Definitely my favorite draft at dogfishhead brew! My first recommendation here. Try it and you wont be disappointed!

Pours coca cola with a thin head. Aromas of roasted malts, wood (a distinct "palo santo" ester), slight vanilla, some raisin, and carmel in the back. Flavors of coffee, roasted malts, wood (no distinct ester noticed), raisin, fig,  alcohol through the nose and slightly in the flavor. Alcohol carries though the flavor and in to the finish but does not come out as much of a flavor in itself. Leaves only a slight bitter finish and malted aftertaste. The wood is delicate in the nose before you consume then harder to detect after a few sips. Thank you dogfish head for alternatively creative beers!

35,5 cl bottle @ home. Rated on 18.06.2011
Aroma has burned licorice, some berries, ash and tobacco. Flavour is rather unusual with ash, bilberries and licorice. Unique and good.

02/02/12, 12 oz bottle into a DFH signature glass.

A - Pitch black body, a two finger high mocha head forms. Moderate lacing and retention, has some alcoholic legs to it.

S - Wood. But not any lumber yard special, no, no. This is some fancy wood. Im not exactly a wood connoisseur so Ill just leave it at "pallo santo wood". This "wood" has a certain sweetness and spice to it that works really well on top of some traditional brown ale notes. Brown sugar and caramelized bananas is what really stands out though. In the background there is coffee, vanilla and cocoa powder against lightly roasted malts with a slight mineral thing going on. The aroma is so complex and unique, but its coming off like a barrel aged bananas foster themed beer. 

T - It starts off very stout like with roasted malts, coffee, vanilla, oak, and chocolate. But then comes this mildly bitter yet sweet wood favor that is fruity yet smokey and dense. Again, bananas foster. Just as complex and unique as the nose, but less satisfying. It does leave an aftertaste in the mouth that is woody. The mouth feel is medium bodied and syrupy with a high level of carbonation. There is a touch of complimentary warming alcohol, but it doesnt interfere at all.

O - Dogfish Head is just so damn unique. Ive had this beer a few times, including a bottle that was about 3 years old. I think I prefer it fresh. So much is happening, and the aroma is just perfect and so enticing. World class example of breaking the mold in the beer world.

12oz bottle - pours black with dark brown head and decent lacing.  Nose is caramel, brown sugar and alcohol.  Flavor adds roast, and floral hops.  Very sweet and ends bitter.  Full body and flat.  Dry lips and sticky on the back of the throat.  I bet I could use this instead of oil in my riding lawn mower - not that I would.  The aftertaste is wood.

355ml bottle thanks to Blairgus. Pours opaque black with a nice crema head. The nose has dark chocolate with liquorice, balsam and smokey spices. The taste has loads more of the sweet wood spices, then a little chocolate and liquorice, The palate is rich and full bodied with a gorgeous creamy texture and a long creamy texture on the end. What a beer!
I was surprised with the aroma and appearance, looks like a stout. I wish it had a little more chocolate or caramel taste to it, but I really think it is a good beer.

I will have to re rate this when its not summer ,90 and humid, and when I have it not as chilled. Wrong beer and wrong serving temp . But for now : Poured very dark dense brown with a tan full head. Nose is fig, mollases, vanilla, and sherry.  Mouthfeel is heavy full, take small sips and let swirl around and it feels like more volume. I get a strong alcholol tatse which isnt maked very well. Flavors of sherry, smoked wood, molasses, dark rum, dates. Not balanced , too much burn for me, but again i am drinking this out of season. Should be had on a November rain/snow day in front of the fire, not in 92 degree weather with humidity. Would pair well with a pot roast.

Pours a dark blackish brown with beige head. The nose is fig, red fruit, leather, wood, and vanilla. The flavor starts with boozy sweet plum and vanilla. Followed by a light fig and anis. And    finishes with bitter chestnut, leather, and wood. Overall a very complex and delicious beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours ruby black with a reasonable chocolate head. Aroma is sandalwood, oak, chocolate, raisins, cherry, brown sugar. Creamy mouthfeel, full bodied, smooth, slightly umami finish with lots of wood and some roast. Taste is cocoa, toasted malt, oak, aniseed, dark dried fruits. Really enjoyed this beer.

black color, aroma of roasted malt, dark fruits, wood, vanilla, flavors of roasted malt, coffee, semisweet chocolate, dark fruits, vanilla, smokey wood, roasted nuts, toffee, booze, full body, slightly dry finish, rich and complex, and easy to drink at 12%, will definitely be getting this one again

Pours dark brown with a decent foamy head. Stout-like characteristics: roasty malts, caramel, toffee, rich chocolate, and perhaps some vanilla. Very creamy and smooth, with mild carbonation. Alcohol is noticeable, but vastly diminished by the complex flavours.

Holy is not how to describe this brew. Sinister smokey mixed aroma of vanilla, caramel, licorice and butane soaked charwood. Thick and oily and dark brown. Starts slightly bitter and transitions to an alcohol infused liquid smoke. Combines elements of smoked lagers with much heavier porters and stouts for a dramatic and very filling effect.
12 ounce bottle pours a brown color, aromas of chocolate, ash, caramel, and molasses.  Flavors are same with some vanilla thrown in and some booze.  Light wood aftertaste, interesting beer.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2012 Bottled 2011 when I grabbed one at the store.  Very dark brown with a small tan head.  Smell of sweet malts (mostly chocolate, , vanilla, some toffee) and wood.  Taste is rich and complex adding smoke, booze and some dark fruit.  Pretty sweet but no alcohol burn at all, very much enjoyed sipping this to the end.

Dark black pour released every aroma in the bottle into the room. The gravity is almost too smooth, as a person could drink one down before they knew what they were doing! Rich character and a fine finish mark this as the next age of brewing, just like the bottle says :)

Drank from a 12l ouncer. Poured to a deep chocolate brown,  almost black in color. Nice roasted malty taste with subtle burnt wood as well as vanilla and raisen flavorings. Very sweet at the top, but very enjoyable. Tasted like a fine porter.A very smooth and well balanced ale.

Third beer at the Bottleworks Cellar Tasting for Seattle Beer Week. Batch 1. Pours black with no head. Smell is toffee, coffee, licorice, tobacco. Taste is wood, nutty, coffee, roast. Amazing to get two different beers in smell and taste, completely masks the 12 percent. Great beer, aged or not.
Tap. Very dark with cocoa dissipating head. Smells very syrupy and a little chocolaty and warm. Liqueur like- sweet. Thick and warming.

A - Pours a dark brown-black color with a finger of frothy chocolate colored head. The head fades down fairly slowly leaving behind some nice lace.

S - Aroma is a mix of molasses, vanilla, smoke, roasted chocolate and caramel malts, black licorice, wood, a touch of dark fruit, and a bit of booze.

T - Starts off with some molasses, vanilla, roasted chocolate malts, and a touch of sweet dark fruits. Through the middle, some smoke and licorice come through with some wood and some more roasted chocolate malts. The finish is a mix of smoke, licorice, vanilla, wood, cocoa, coffee, dark fruit, and a touch of booze.

M - Full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feel smooth with a slightly thick sweet, smoky, and warming finish.

D - Very drinkable. Different and excellent take on a big brown ale. I like the smoke and wood flavors in the beer with the complexity of the rest of the flavors.
dark brown with small head. sweet and boozy. there is quite a bit of flavor, but unfortunately, most of it is alcohol. harsh.

355ml bottle.
Pours a very dark brown, with a brown head.
Massive aroma, chocolate, coffee, tobacco, licorice, tar, smoke.
Sweet, full bodied, high bitterness, creamy CO2.
Solid, rich taste, licorice, dark chocolate, spices, coffee, ashes. (2012-05-05)
Pours thick and viscuous. Opaque brown with a tan head. The barrels are evident on the nose showing a nutty aromatic. Full bodied with tobacco and coffee flavors. Too much heat on the finish.

Over a year old bottle. Poured a dark brown, bordering on black. Thin dark brown head, went to a thin film and collar. Nose is wood, vanilla, carmel, dark fruits, and sweet malts. Port like nose.  Taste follows nose but the brown ale does appear more. Just more beefed up.  Medium feel and heavy body. More port or sherry like. Dry wooded finish. 
A bit too sweet but nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle poured into a large Duvel tulip glass. Had this stashed away for the last 9 months or so. Pours a dark stout like black with a cocoa colored head with a slight hint of lacing. Aroma is wood, cherries, yeast and some caramel. Smooth taste along the same lines as the aroma with a hint of chocolate. No alcohol burn at all, at 12% abv this can sneak up on you and put you out.

Dogfish es para mí una cervecera muy atractiva en sus planteamientos de la que lamentablemente por motivos de producción podemos probar pocas cosas en Europa. Su máxima es hacer cervezas fuera de lo común y por lo que se comenta  no lo puedo juzgar porque por los motivos comentados no tengo la posibilidad de probar muchas  su técnica es excelente.

Esta cerveza en concreto, que adelanto que es maravillosa, es de un color marrón muy oscuro, con una espuma densa marrón persistente.

En seguida se perciben aromas tostados y de chocolate, muy agradables, así como las notas del envejecimiento en madera.  Al probarla es una auténtica explosión de sabor , con todo ese chocolate, caramelo, madera, dulce y amargo.

Es una cerveza con poco gas, como pasa con las envejecidas en madera, aunque esto no es un problema. De textura masticable, pica un poco en la boca si la dejas ahí, que es cosa de cada cual , porque alguno pensará que para qué vas a dejarte una cerveza en la boca en vez de tragártela.

El sabor es tan intenso que un rato después de beberla todavía persiste ahí la muy ladina. Un cervezote en toda regla, para los amantes de las emociones fuertes, sobresaliente.

Bottle pour.opaque mahogany scant espresso crema head. Dark syrupy nose, sweet molasses and alcohol sweet smell like a barley wine (it is 12%). Chocolate flavor, heavy finish but not as sweet add I expected.long dark roast finish. Coffee.
Very nice!  Has aromas of licorice, brown sugar, and freshly baked bread.  Tastes like vanilla, wood, brown sugar, and alcohol.  Very similar to AleSmith Speedway Stout but better!

Try this again, rated the wrong one. From a 355 ml bottle, pours a black, oily, slightly syrupy. Thin tan head, aroma is interesting, with prominent cedar, chocolate malts, black pepper. Thick creamy mouthfeel with a sharp bitterness, warm alcohol feel. It is 12% after all. Intense.Earlier Rating: 4/29/2012 Total Score: 3.6From a 355 ml bottle, pours a black, oily, slightly syrupy. Thin tan head, aroma is interesting, with prominent cedar, chocolate malts, black pepper. Thick creamy mouthfeel with a sharp bitterness, warm alcohol feel. It is 12% after all. Intense. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma of coffee bean and chocolate..pitch brown with very thin tan head..a little carbonated on the tongue. Taste of toffee, chocolate and a little boozy.

Bottle.  Pours very black with no light coming through.  There is a finger and a half of uneven tan head.  Aroma has vanilla, caramel, and a little mocha.  Taste is very sweet vanilla bean with some alcohol burn on the finish.  The palate is full and a little chewy. Overall, this is a home run for DFH.

Bottle poured, very dark complexion with minimal head,smell is sweet and caramel, after the appearance and aroma the label is right... I do have wood, flavor is sweet right from the start with caramel and vanilla notes leading to a woody finish, mouth feel is satiny soft

Pours black coffee head.
Aroma: Surprise!  Woodsy, coffee, toffee.
Flavor: Bitter, 
Palate: Super thick, chewy, malt heavy, bitter finish.

Bottle. Deep brown, near-black mahogany body with a tiny beige head. Nose is nuts, wood, leather, almonds, alcohol and something Ive never tasted before, so maybe its the Palo Santo factor? Nice, regardless. Taste is licorice, dark malts, hints of leather, the undefinable (Palo Santo?) flavor, and hints of red berries in the finish. Full bodied, but rather drinkable. A very original and nice strong ale from Dogfish Head.

Pours an opaque brown with reddish brown head that is very small leaving no lacing. Boozy aroma with caramel and roasted malt. Dark chocolate. Raisins. Herbal hops. Medium sweetness up front with a little tartness that builds to a moderate bitterness and then settles into a mild sweet/bitter combination for a long finish. Soft carbonation full body with chewy palate. This is a big beer. Fantastic, but prepare yourself.

Excellent beer. Pours jet black with minimal head. Lightly carbonated. Aroma and tastes of coffee, chocolate, malts, alcohol, vanilla and dark fruits. Feels more like an imperial stout, especially at 12%.

12oz bottle into a snifter. Beautiful brown color and complex smells, including a noticeable alcohol hint. Perfectly lightly carbonated - Goes down almost like a fine wine - but finishes smoother with a brilliant foreign aftertaste .


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
@HallingHansen tasting, thanks for sharing. Pours black with a light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, oak, vanilla and dark fruit. Flavour is roasted malt, coffee, oak, vanilla and fruit.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a brandy snifter. Appearance is dark brown with a thin, tan head of foam. Aroma is supremely complex with notes of chocolate, raisins, wood, cinnamon, coffee, and vanilla. The wood notes in this beer really round everything up and makes it just a delicious beer to sip. The alcohol strength in this beer goes pretty much unnoticed until you stand up. Taste is earthy and mildly sweet. Chewy mouthfeel with a somewhat stickiness on the tongue. Im pleasantly surprised at how tasty this beer is.

Poured into chalice. Very dark brown almost black in color. Nice roasted malty taste with subtle burnt wood as well as vanilla and raisen flavorings. Very enjoyable. Tasted like a fine porter. A little alcohol burn kept it from being the "perfect" beer but other than that, a very smooth and well balanced ale.
Wow!  Tastes like a delicious Porter with a hint of raisen.  For such a strong alcohol content tastes very smooth.  One of my favorites from my favorite brewery.

12oz bottle poured into my snifter. extremely dark brown bordering on black with no head. Aroma is charred mash-mellow, blackberry reduction, licorice and freshly split logs of wood.  Taste is deep malt, vanilla and dried fruit, light alcohol finish. lil syrup texture but light enough to invite more and more sips. really impressive.

Pours very dark with a thin foam head.
Nose is powerful and complex: chocolate, date, vanilla, candied malt.
Bitterness give freshness to this 12% ABV malt beverage and give it a well balanced taste and palate.
Very nice bodybuildied American strong Ale. I love DFH range !
UPDATED: JUL 19, 2012 Rating pertains to a bottle with about 6 months age on it. This was a decent malty beer all around. Nothing that elevated it to the next level though.
Wow! Tasty and potent, great look a it poured, deep brown to black with a small brown head. Aroma has hint of cocoa and coffee, strong alcohol presence, sharp on the palate. Not sure I want another.

Le nez est digne dune grosse brown ale bien rôti avec des notes de cuir et de dattes. En bouche cest riche et onctueux presque lacté. La finale de bois humide donne du tonus au chocolat, café et fruits trop mûrs déjà bien en place.

Bottle.  Pours a viscous deep brown, almost black, with a bit of brown head.  Sweet caramel aroma, with a bit of coffee.  The flavor is very complex - a lot of alcohol, fruit (cherries?), bright wood notes, and rich malts.  Not an easy drinker, but a nice beer to sip on over a couple hours.  Gets better as it goes along.  Still, I remember it being better on draft.

Viscous, deep dark drown to purple appearance as it poured out of the bottle. There is an aroma of alcohol soaked wood chips. Its thick and creamy on the tongue. Burly malts striking a balance between sweet and bitter. It tastes how it looks.
Looks like molasses. Dark brown-purple color. Nose is raisins. Straight-up malts with hints of dates, prunes. High abv not too noticeable.

Pours a very dark brown with a dark beige two and half finger head. The smell of wood, light roasted malt, and subtle dark fruitiness are present. Fig and plum with a bit of wood on the nose transitioning to toasty malt and boozy slightly sweet syrup with a hint of vanilla. The finish is dry with malt and warm booze. Exceptional mouthfeel, gentle but abundant carbonation which blankets the inside of the mouth, very full-bodied. Really an extremely original and very enjoyable brew.

355 ml bottle.
Rated on 20110618.
Pours pitch black color with light head. Aroma of lots of ash, berries, especially bilberry, raspberry, liquorice and syrup notes. Flavor of sweet syrup, berries, spices and liquorice, sufficient amounts of vanilla also present. Slick and oily palate with a spicey and bitter finish. Quite interesting and exiting brew. Excellent.
4326

Dark, strong, and delicious. Thick malty flavor and smooth mouth feel. An all year beer with bold yet unobtrusive flavor 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From notes.  First reviewed 11/26/2011.  Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a DFH signature glass.

While it was pouring out of the bottle I could tell that this was going to be a thick and viscous beer. The color is a mahogany or ebony, nearly black with almost no light getting through. A dark tan cap rests on top of the beer and retains very nicely for a beer of this ABV.

The aroma is full and deep, but it is not overly complex of out of. The roasted malt gives off caramel, burnt brown sugar, roasted grains, cocoa, and a bit of alcohol.

The flavor starts with a combination of caramel and burnt brown sugar, twisting the sweetness in a different direction. Toasted grains and cocoa come through next. A bit of vanilla precedes the nice dry woody flavor toward the end. A little bit different than oak, this must be the influence of the Palo Santo wood. Just a bit of booze peaks through toward the end. The finish is lightly sweet and a little woody at the same time.

There is no doubt about the fullness of this body. Slightly sticky, with a bit of oily residue after each sip; both of these sensations are quite common for big ABV beers, so no lost points there. The carbonation is creamy and contributes to the smoothness, although it is a bit understated. 

I thought this was another good take on the American Brown style from Dogfish Head. Indian Brown is a better beer, in my opinion, but there are not a lot of 12% brown ales out there. Its definitely a compliment that Sam can brew a big, tasty beer in a category that normally sees more mild releases.

Pours a solid black, no head to be found. Alcohol is very present in the smell, along with a warming wood aroma. Taste starts off sweet with the carbonation, and fades with a spicy and licorice flavor. Alcohol is felt in the mouthfeel, a little burn. Would be tough to drink this more than very occasionally, but for the style it's good.

Impenetrable black colour with tinges of deep russet brown. Nothing much by the way of head, some mocha coloured largish bubbling. The first aromas (its straight out of the fridge and needs a few minutes to warm in my hand of course) are of herbal licorice, molasses, rosewood and spice. It smells of dessert, ripe figs, coffee and all sorts of lush good things. Full bodied and woody. More spice comes out upon tasting in this big, remarkable beer. Beers like this make the market wonderful and it is a delight to be able to taste it.

impresionante,un color negro intenso,a la nariz suave con tonos de caramelo,malta y palo de rosa,al paladar intensa,corposa,con tonalidades de malta lupulo cafe chocolate y una sensacion taninica tipica del vino. Te deja un after taste a cafe persistente es una tremenda cerveza muy recomendada para tomarse sola despues de una comida
user_location: SANTIAGO DE LOS CABALLEROS, DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

text:
Very dark, almost stout like color with a thick and creamy dark tan head. Aroma is  dried fruits, molasses, cocoa, smokey, wood, and vanilla. 
Taste is very rich with caramel, and vanilla pushing through the oaky woody type notes.
Pours totally black with a brown head. Aroma is sweet malty with notes of coffee, chocolate and wood. Taste is also sweet with coffee, chocolate, woody notes and some alcohol. Really awesome.
UPDATED: DEC 23, 2012 Tastes of bourbon, port, and charcoal with a sweet and sourness that bring them all together. Pretty unique and well done. Nice as a 4oz pour.
Very rich , unique and interesting. This offering from Dogfish is what makes drinking craft beers so much fun for me. Much apreciated and will enjoy again!
Pitch brown in color, head completely dissipates after a while. The smell and taste are really unique. Bourbon, smoke and whiskey like flavors. You can feel the alcohol getting into your veins!

At HallingHansen Grand Tasting, thanks for sharing. Pours a pitch black beer with a chocolate head. The aroma is malt, licorice and chocolate. The flavor follows the nose with additional alcohol. The palate is sweetness. Overall a good beer.
One of my all time faves by Dogfish. Woody flavor comes out in the aroma and flavor. Coats the mouth with every sip. Very rich and interesting.

Sweet spicy aroma.  Chocolatey toasted flavor well balanced with the woody overtones.  Sweet molasses and vanilla after taste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

DELICIOSO! I squealed after tasting this heavy brown ale. I dont know why, but I was compelled to get Italian. This beer isnt Italian. Its definitely a hoist up the stars and stripes American, with cedar undertones and a ballsy, robust flavor. I kept wanting another sip to sort out the complex profile fully.  A very interesting brew that I hope to revisit soon.

12 ounce bottle.  Pours almost black with a small tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, dark fruit, and wood.  Taste is roasted malt, caramel, dark fruit, chocolate, wood, and alcohol.  Rich, complex, heavy, and unique.

Dark, dark brown in color with a thin tan head.  Smells quite sweet.  Lots of brown sugar, molasses, and toffee.  The wood is prominent and gives an almost spicy aroma.  A hint of vanilla in there which balances some of the roast nicely.  Mildly spicy with lots of dark sugar notes--molasses, burnt sugar, and caramel.  Light vanilla flavor and a subtle roast flavor.  Really well balanced.
Strong as hell, tasty in some ways but nothing amazing here. Actually wait this is pretty good Im drunk

Nose features bits of raisin, earthy notes, candied sugars, hardly any discernible booze.  Pours a near pitch black with a healthy finger of mocha head that dims down to dimples.  Nice lacing.  Taste is very, very intriguing.  Really like nothing that I can remember.  Sweet fruit and malt initially.  You really get the woody characteristics right in the middle and it makes for a perfect transition into some sweet heat.  No complaints with the mouthfeel.  Overall, this is absolutely splendid.  Really wish I could get this one in MN.  Oh well - to my wants!

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2015 The aroma is very special: mellow, yet assertive, with mostly roasted notes, a bit of vanilla, some caramel, some chocolate, and old, dried woodlike a piece of wood soaked with bourbon and left to dry out for fifty years. The taste is a bit less complex, perhaps, albeit still quite compelling, with roasted malts and gentle hops providing some bitterness, and the wood notes giving it a faintly sweet and almost boozy-sour character. The palate is reasonably thick, with prickling carbonation. The alcohol is more implied than tasted or smelledyou can tell this is a big beer, but it doesnt bite. Theres something almost melancholic about this beer, but I love it.

12 oz bottle; dark brown color, but not opaque; small, quickly fading head; slightly sweet smell; pleasant hint of fizziness on the palate, not too sweet; Im not a fan of vanilla or caramel, but their subtle use here works; no boozy taste from the high ABV.

Although Ive found it on tap, this one was poured from a bottle. It pours a deep brown, almost black with a thin tan head. Lacing is minor and like the head, dissipates quickly. The aroma had rich molasses, dark fruits and woody vanilla. Alcohol was present in both the aroma and taste. The flavor was sweet, malty and roasted with vanilla coming through.Grorgeous  thick, oily mouthfeel and only a mild feel of carbonation. This is an outstanding beer, one not to be missed when you can find it.

Dark brown/black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, chocolate, oak/wood, & dark fruit; Flavor of roasted smoky malt, caramel, chocolate, dark fruit (notably plums), raisons, and some licorice; Warm finish; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, excellent brew.

Pours a deep dark brown, almost black with a thin tan head that dissipates quickly. Looks very stout-like. Aroma is filled with caramel and chocolates, a bit of vanilla and oak-like flavor, some alcohol it there too. Tastes Great. Lots of roast and dark fruits, vanilla, more wood flavors and alcohol burn in the finish. Very creamy in the mouth. Thick and full bodied. Light carbonation. This a damn fine brew, but Im not sure Id label it a brown. Got this as an extra, so I will leave my 4 I have cellering alone.
Black of color with a brown head. An aroma of roasted malt, liqurice, tobacco, sweets and port notes. A flavor of liqurice, tobacco, leather, raisins, syrup, roasted malt and a nice oily flavor.

Bottle @ Hallinghansens US Tasting, Odense. Pours black with a small creamy head and lacings. Dark fruit, syrup and caramel. Very sweet. Ashy and vaguely roasted flavor. Sweet and quite cloying. A heavy one.
Pours dark and has strong aroma with smoke and malt.  The taste is of roasted malt and the special wood really comes through.  Very special.

Poured pretty much black, with a beige, lacing foam. Strong wood aroma, which mixes with vanilla, plum, alcohol, caramel, and honey. Oily, dense body with medium carbonation. Sweet, roasty taste with a strong alcohol taste and a dark fruity kick. A bit strong on the palate, but not too bad considering how strong this brew is. Sweet, lasting finish, with plenty of the Palo Santo wood aroma lurking. Unique, strong, an outstanding one!

"Purchased in November in Delaware. Cellared at 50 degrees on my basement and poured into a Snifter in January at 45 Degrees F after a few minutes in the fridge. Paid $12 or a 4-Pack
A - Poured a single finger head but subsided to a thin head after 2 minutes. The head was a light brown color. The beer itself looks like a porter and pours like one as well. Its very dark.
S - Lots of tobacco and molasses. Its a very dry scent and some sugar aspects to it. Im getting some whipped cream as well.
T - Wow. Super malt taste and lots of that molasses coming in the taste.Its a very sweet beer that Id love to pour on a pancake! Theres some caramel but not much. So glad I bought a 4-pack of this!
M - Its a heavy beer. nice carbonation, pleasurable to drink and throw back. 
O - This was a pleasurable beer and I may have a 2nd one tomorrow. Its very delicious and so great to drink! I love it!"

(Bottle) Pours near black with a small brown head. The aroma is heavy and complex with tones of sweet fruits, maple syrup, mild chocolate roast, fresh vanilla-ish wood, fat caramel, nuts, dark plums, sticky dates, dark cherries, ripe blue grapes and sweet blackberry jam.  Undertones of plant sap, sweet liquorice, sweet tar, banana and glue-like alcohol. The flavour is medium to heavily sweet and light bitter with notes of maple syrup, vanilla-ish wood, liquorice, dark chocolate, dark fruits, caramel and light banana. The mouthfeel is fat, soft, bit smooth and tiny sticky. Light peppery. The finish is sweet with a light bitter sting from the hops. Near full bodied.

Bottle from Kris Wines. Dark dark brown colour with small dark golden head round the edge of the glass. Very thick when pouring. Aroma is ultra roasty, bit of booze there too. Some herbal element/medicinal and some nuttiness. Taste is sweet boozy, bit of coffee bitterness, and something which I guess could be the smoked wood. Lots of dark fruit too and some vanilla. Texture is quite oily and thick. Goes down very smoothly. Bit of a knockout beer, and so much going on it is a bit hard to pinpoint stuff. Really nice.
Dark brown with tan head. Wood is not too strong on the nose, toasty malts rise above it. A bit of coffee, floral hops and smoked wood. Nice brown ale!

Very thick, malty and dark ale that has a smokey, spicy and woody flavor. It has a bitter smell  of raw choclate, but a nice sweet and smooth taste. I would buy it again if I wanted a more chocolate/coffee/caramel and toasty flavor. I agree its earthy and leathery.... I can sort of get a cough drop, licorice and ginger flavor as well. Its very complex.
Fantastic Brown; nice roasted malt, full thick head nice dark brown color, woody flavor and nutty nose

Cerveza color negro, lo cual se explica por el hecho de que no esta filtrada, parece una stout; en el aroma tiene notas de malta tostada, de madera y de vainilla, cuerpo muy robusto, el verdadero cuerpo completo, sabor complejo, un tanto raro, pero rico; tiene notas de madera, lo cual le da un sabor muy exotico, no me parece una gran cerveza, pero es una buena cerveza que debe ser tomada al tiempo.

Pours black with a thin tan head. Aroma is full of chocolate and dark fruit scents along with some liquorice and a little alcohol kick. Taste is rich and sweet with a slight dryness in the finish. Full bodied, soft mouth-feel, average carbonation.

Malty dark fruit aroma.Black with little head at all. Rich malt bitter with a nice warm feeling on the palate. Has clean fruit finish. Has caramel and vanilla also. Woodsy peppery feel on the tongue. Unique and tough to describe. Certainly one to be savored not gulped.

12oz bottle in pint glass.  Pours very dark, little to no head.  Aroma and first taste, to me, imply a malty Belgian double or quad, with a roasty bite.  Back end is a bit fruity as it spreads out on the palate, then a bit of alcohol bites.  This is a pretty complex taste, and there is overlap with stout IMO.

Bottle. Pours a beautiful oily dark dark brown with moderately thick tan head. Rich aroma of dark chocolate, cedar wood, and top shelf whisky with hints of raspberry and smoke. Flavor has more of the smokiness with coffee and some wood spice. Full and oily body with soft but predominant smoky chocolate in the finish. There is a ton of DFH for me to still try, but at this point this is the best beer Ive had from them, hands down.

Aroma, Wow spicy and very Malty, Vanillia, Carmel, and woody, pours very dark small longer stay, white head,taste, so much here you rellay have to slow down to get it, First the spicyness of the beer being aged in wood, comes out, almost a slight peppery taste, well balanced by the sweetness ,of the malt, vanillia and carmel notes, then it all just smooths together on the end, overall, Awesome Brown Ale I would say my favorite, I think Iam getting some tonight!
user_location: @RED BHUT JOIKIAS!, Paulsboro, New Jersey, USA

text: Draft at Alehouse.  Strong, almost like a barley wine.  Deep black, thick with nice tan head.  Alcohol is warming.  Very good for this type.

Dark and thick pour with not much head.  Chocolate and citrus nose with a woody, tangy first sip.  If its too cold, it bites a little in the back of the mouth, but smooths out as it warms up.  The wood is definitely there, almost like a rich bourbon and a little of that bite.  In the realm of barleywine but not nearly as sweet as those Ive had.  Big plus for a high alcohol brew: almost no clingy feel on the tongue after!  It pairs great with red meat and chocolate.  Dont try this one out on your "Miller Lite" friends.  They just wouldnt understand.


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Wow. This beer tasted like eating a tree. I could taste nothing but wood. It tasted like woody whiskey.

Pours out like jet fluid.  Solid black and very thick looking.  The pour created a decent tan head.  The aroma is sweet and boozy.  Im picking up lots of caramel along with some roasted malts in the nose.  The taste is suprisngly smooth for such a big beer.  I can pick out the roast malt and some astringency from the wood.  There is a warming sensation that comes from the high alcohol at the end.  I wish that I could pick out the wood notes a little better.  Great beer!

Poured about black with a chocolate brown ring of head. Sticky lacing.	Aroma is very sweet, chocolate and caramel with some alcohol. Taste is very roasted, a little nuttiness, some sweetness, and alcohol. Slick mouthfeel. Very good, but definitely to be enjoyed slowly.

Dark brown almost black with a dark tan head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is slightly smoked wood, raisins, and maybe a little coffee. You can definitely taste the wood. Palo Santo Marron wood has a taste all its own. The taste keeps reminding of a barbecue. It blends well with the rich malt flavors. You can taste the age, as well. Everything in it has mellowed and blended quite well. This would pair with cheeses and barbecues. Awesome.

Bottled. A hazy dark brown beer with a medium sized beige head. Aroma is dark malt and caramel, notes of dry fruits and wood. Taste is also malty, notes of coffee, cocoa and wood. Very nice texture and alcoholic mouthfeel. Bitter and spicy finish. Very good beer

Pours almost oil black, giving a little tan head if poured aggressively. Laces nicely. Smoky dates, figs, prunes, caramel, and I get the wood too. A little marshmallowy sweetness. Taste is the same smoky dark fruits plus a resiny almond bread concoction. Hops are present waaaaay on the back end, and pretty mild. Not my thing but admittedly very good.

pours opaque black with a tan head.if i would have just looked at this beer i would have guessed a stout or porter.smokey and chocolate nose.chocolate carmel and dark fruits with upfront alchohol.lightly carbonated and lacing dissapates quickly.its 23 degrees outside right now and im really liking this alcohol thats warming me up.i will definitely buy this again.

Pours black with a thin brown head.  Nice aroma of roasted malts.  Flavor follows with hints of chocolate and some wood.  Overall pretty malty and sweet.  DFH says its 50 IBUs but Id probably prefer a little more hops bitterness to balance.  A good beer none the less.

Bottle.  Opaque black pour with tan head.  Aroma is that strong wood aged aroma that is hard to describe.  Taste is the same as the aroma.  It is definitely dark, roasty, and malty, but there is a lot more to it than just those flavors.  Body is heavy and carbonation is low.  A complex brew.

Bottle. Very dark brown with medium brown head. Aroma is malt, light roasted malts, chocolate, caramel, hops and dark fruits. Flavour light roasted malts, caramel, fruit, yeast, dark fruit, plume, medium sweet, hops and medium bitter,

wow. che dire. Non amo molto le strong ale, ma questa è una grandissima birra. E complicato descriverla perchè tutto è intenso ed equilibrato sia al naso che al palato (caramello, liquirizia, legnosa). Da provare assolutamente!

Trade by Beerbill, thanks. Black with a dark brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, coffee and dried fruit. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and roasted rather bitter finish. Smooth and soft. 271211

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2012 Updating this review from my previous critical review; hey my palate is changing. This tastes a lot more like a stout than an American Strong Ale. But it also tastes like a good stout. Not really roasty, more chocolate and woody, with very strong alcohol burn. Really tasty, does great with a few months of cellaring, and can also hold up in the cellar for long periods.

Update: sampled a 2 year old cellar bottle. Compared to a fresh version the aroma was much better. Flavor was drier overall, softer carbonation, more alcohol taste, and a more prominent spice note from the wood. I like the cellared version better, but its not really worth aging.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration.Color is  black. Aroma and taste are rich caramel, fruits, candy sugar, wonderful head and hops.

12oz pour dark and complex aromas including the Palo santo tree. Aromatic at its best. The flavor is deep malty dark and an alcohol burn that is not over bearing. Drank it on the warm side and the flavors are quite intense. Superb!

12oz bottle. Pours dark brown with thin beige head. Aroma is dark fruits (plums and raisins), toffee, and roasted malt. Flavor is sweet matching the nose with alcohol notes throughout. Medium mouthfeel and light carbonation. Great beer with a strong taste upfront which balances out great with a smooth finish.

On tap at Michael Symons Bspot: good looking brown pour. huge, bold nose of cedar, burnt wood, caramel malts, chocolate and toffee. once on your palate, sweet milk thistle, chocolate, toffee and permeating with long, alcohol heat finish. rich mouthfeel. a meal.
Aged one year in bottle.  Pours black with a small white head.  Very roasty flavor with a sweet sugar finish.

Bottle. Pours black with a tan head. Smells of chocolate, roast, wood, and spices. Tastes of a medium sweetness and mild tart. Full bodied. Medium carbonation. An excellent beer, if a bit strong on the alcohol.
12 oz bottle aged one year pours a dark brown/black color with a small tan head.  Aromas of wood and booze.  Full bodied, very complex, with warming booze at the end

Had this months ago just never rated it (need to find my notes). Aroma and taste: big complex mix of raosted malts, dark rich fruits, mild sweet notes, all over a mellow haze of booze. Full body. Very nice finish. Will buy more of these.

Smells like grain alcohol.  Lots of malted barley and molasses.  Finishes a  bit tart with a sharp alcohol like bite....but the taste that hits you up front is more than enough to keep you coming back for another sip.  Amazingly powerful and complex.  A wonderful, unique beer.

35cl bottle from my beer cellar aged from 2008.
No head or carbonation.  Great deep dark pour.  Interesting woody taste.

Pours a nice dark brown with 2 finger white head with strong lacing. The smell is bourbon barrel.  Strong alcohol and molasses. You can taste the ABV up front but it is surprisingly balanced and tastes great. Good carbonation but a little syrupy. This was a great beer with my steak and would drink again, but could not have more then 1 or 2 in an evening.

Poured dark, almost black, with minimal dark brown head.  Strong aroma of bitter chocolate, and alcohol.  Some really nice flavors, chocolate, charred wood, coffee, but overshadowed a bit by the alcohol.  Would be a fantastic beer at 9%ish.  Will be interesting to see what age does to this.
Pours black with a thick but small brown head.  Smells of chocolate and dough.  Taste is strong - malty, bitter but un-hoppy
draft, caramel, nuts, roasty, alcohol, woody, brown, tan foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, full body, average carbonation, astringent,

WOW this is one hell of a beer. Strong astringent aroma of wood chocolate, toffee. Very dark brown with a very deep khaki head. Slightly sweet with toffee and biscuity malt. Syrup llke on the palate  with an alcohol finish. Im saving one to age. I would recommend it to a fan of stouts and high alcohol brews. Perfect for a snow day.

Dark brown with a light, toffee-colored head. Well carbonated in appearance. The aromas strongly of smoky wood, alcohol, aniseed and sugar. The taste is hot, the alcohols definitely there. Sweet flavors. The mouthfeel is quite acidic, but not damagingly so. The textures a bit oily. Overall, this is a very good beer. Id love to age a bottle for a year or so to let the alcohol mellow a bit.

Pours a nice dark body - smells like dark fruits with a hint of hops and spices. Alcohol is in the nose as well, and makes for an overall mellow scent. Tasted a tad roasty upfront, but came down to a nice mix of cocoa, raisins and molasses. Finished with a slight warmth and woody, not really hinting the high ABV but rather satisfying.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours opaque black with small dark brown highlight with small light brown head.  A little lacing, thick body, low carbonation, and aroma is roasted malt and molasses.  Taste is complex roasted malt, molasses, some chocolate, a little coffee, a little wood, finishes good bitter hops, a little vanilla as the beer warms, and hint of alcohol.  This is half brown ale and half porter.  Good beer, but the alcohol peaks out.

Aroma of roast nuts, caramel and a little coffee.  Pours dark with a brown head.   Tastes of caramel, dark fruits, roast coffee and alcohol (dfh duh).  Not the smoothest thanks to the booze.
Very dark brown body with a foamy tan head. Smoky aroma. Hints of licorice, caramel, and spice. Very strong, with a high alcohol content!

Pours black with a small brown head. Licorice, dark fruits, caramel, and burnt chocolate are all present in the aroma and taste. Leaves a sour taste in my mouth. I think the 12% alcohol is well hidden, but itll catch up to you... Unique and fun to try, but not really my style.

Aroma- huge hits of vanilla, dark fruits out the ass, massive woodiness, booze, black licorice, herbs, bourbon
Appearance- black as hell, tan head, sexy alcohol legs
Taste- monster woodiness upfront, followed by toffee sweetness mixed with vanilla, some bitterness follows, with lingering dark fruits
Palate- nice carbonation, relatively full-bodied
Overall- Super potent, incredibly rich.  This beer is diesel.  Overly complex and insanely drinkable, this is one of my 5 favorite beers and will always be a personal DFH favorite.
Delicious! Dark color, no head, lots of smokey vanilla-ey, and strong tastes. Slight taste of alcohol.

Video review at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4mjT2IH2vyY

Appearance: Jet black, 1-finger dark khaki head, average lacing

Aroma: Vanilla bean, fresh mulch, cinnamon, molasses, nutmeg, red oak

Flavor: Full body, milk chocolate, cocoa powder, vanilla bean, warm apricot, carmel pecan, candy sweetness, grenadine sweetness, black cherry, blackberry, cinnamon, orange citrus, sweet carmel malts, chocolate malts residual (espresso + bitter chocolate), light carbonation

Pairings: Cheesecake

Intriguing nose of plums and caramel plus vanilla as it begins to warm. Dark black-brown beer with dense, thick coffee foam head. Rich and warming, at first sweet and dried fruit, vanilla wood, a hint of charcoal and a long chocolatey finish.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2011 Aroma is rather attractive. Very heavy in the dried fruits. I wish there was more a hint of roast is the sniffer tho. Great looking beer - nothing like a brown if that what you are expecting. Taste is too sweet. Chocolate, raisin. The palate leaves me feeling like I took cold medicine at times. Other times I get the woody aftertaste. Overall a beermuch more like an imperial stout; however I have had many imperial stouts that are better at blending the higher ABV without over sweetening

Bottle, from Ds Six Pax & Dogz.  Pours black as the midnight of my heart.  Well, not my heart, but someones heart.  Tastes peppery, oily, spicy - not a dessert beverage, but somehow sweet in its spirit.

ud sort uklar mørk skum tæt langh malt alc tømmer chokolade vinøs støvet citron lidt apps
sød moderat bitter moderat 
blød cremet 
f33cl 27/-10-11
synd at alc fylder så meget

vanilla with caramel on the nose,dark brown with a large off brown head 
sweet with huge depth of flavors, full body and think on the palate 
took a while to get into this beer but i have to say its a grower the more you drink it

Sample @SBWF
Aroma: Banana, caramel and burnt.
Taste: Banana, caramell, coffe.
Mouthfeel: Funky

Wow!  Unique.  When they said, "Big brown" they meant it.  Lots of body.  I mean the pour was stylish but the aroma sets the stage for something special.  The taste/palate is rich and elegantly robust.  In my book this is one of the 4 or 5 by which all others are compared.

Rating #1600. Bottle from Mondial de la bière, a deep dark beer very syrupy with huge brownish head. Nose is intense on dark, caramel and coffee malt, notes of licorice too. Aroma is very nice on caramel cream and tobacco notes, marvelous vanilla perfume associated with oak notes. Finish is sweet and caramel like not acrid at all not acid, alcohol is properly hidden, a great brew, very creamy.

355ml bottle poured almost black with a small off-white head which left a little bit of lacing.  Aroma is roasted malts and a little alcohol.  Taste is dominated by a roasted malty sweetness with a little hop bitterness underneath and a trace of woodiness.  The alcohol is hidden well in this beer.  A heavy body and mild carbonation.  This is a strong brew which is not for the masses.  Highly recommended.

Bottle I acquired from daknole over 2 1/2 years ago. Pours a deep, opaque brown with a thin cocoa head that drops quickly to an island of bubbles at the surface and spotty lace on the glass. The nose is big and malty with a sweet spiciness, vanilla, creme brulee with some cinnamon, and a sweet woodiness unlike cherry, oak or any other wood addition Ive encountered. Medium-bodied and oily slick with a sweet finish transitioning to a woody, and just slightly hoppy bitter finish/aftertaste. The flavor is quite sweet, possessing many of the same sweet and spicy complexities found on the nose with the addition of a pronounced ashiness and a significantly drying woody finish. This is some really interesting stuff. The wood helps to counterbalance the significant sweetness, but overall, I found the otherwise pleasant wood note to be a bit overbearing after the swallow. Among the DFH "experiments" that Ive tried this one fall into the success category. Unlike any other beer that Ive tried it also possesses the admirable quality of being pretty tasty. Thanks again, Dak. :)

Excited to try this one as it is one of the few DFH beers I have yet to sample.

Bottled on 2/2/11 poured into a pint glass.

Pitch black with a small, quarter inch head that fades to a thin covering.

smells like dried fruit; raisins and plums. Some wood and maybe a slight bit of alcohol.

Definitely a roasted flavor that I did not pick up on in the smell. Also quite a bit of dark fruit and not as much wood as I was expecting. It is there but not to the degree I have tasted in other wood aged beers. Alcohol is fairly well hidden.

Mouthfeel is full-bodied and a bit sticky but not to the point of being cloying.

Overall a very good beer and Im glad I was able to try it. Not sure it is worth the price, though.

Bottle - over a year old. Pours very dark and thick. Nose: molasses, licorice. 
Taste is similar to nose with a little bit of bitterness and dark chocolate notes. Leaves a velvety mouth feel. Nice alcohol warmth.

bottle; black with small dark brown head; aroma-coffee, dried fruits, raisins, caramel, roasty; taste-medium sweetness and bitterness, moderate carbonation, coffee coming through. Warming feel of alcohol.

Deep dark brown with minimal head.  Aroma roasted malt, coffee, wood.  Full body, a little boozy, syrupy.  Flavor is quite sweet, sugary malt, bourbon, all kind of toasted with a wood almost tannic background.  Interesting and well made but not all that easy to drink, will have to save a bottle for a couple years and reassess.

Bottle.  Pours almost black with splatter tan head.  Sweet vanilla and caramel on the nose with some chocolate an ripe fruits.  Get big roasted malts, raisins, ripe funky fruits, dark chocolate.  Very boozy to me and wood starts to peek through as it warms.  Good, but a bit too boozy for the taste profile to me.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2011 A - Pours a deep, dark  brown/black with a brown head. 

S - Has aromas of chocolate, strong coffee, and  strong palo santo woody tones. 

M- heavy chewy body with no carbonation. Boos are well handled and noted only on the end. 

T - Begins with subtly sweet flavors of  molasses, carmels, and chocolates. Has beautiful smoky wood midtones and finishes on lightly fruity molasses. 

O - A wonderfully complex and well balanced beer. 

8+
Solid, but not great. Big boozy a bit woody. I was expecting more from this beer fresh I found it to be a bit of a let down. Should balance out a bit with age.
Bottle at SBWF 2011. It poured a dark hazy red-brown liquid with a minimal head. Taste and smell of oak, wood, whisky, booze and dark malt. But the taste was better then the smell. Very nice.

What a magnificent brew to get introduced into the Dogfish Head line of brews! This brew poured up a deep, dark mahogany colored body with a two-finger thick tan colored head with amazing retention and lacing. Deep dark aromas of roasted malts, robust coffee, dark chocolates, thick-n-rich molasses and smoked/charred wood. Flavors reflect those same in a very well-balanced brew. Full-bodied, thick-rich-n-creamy, ultra smooth and very easy on the drinkability scale with a crisp clean finish and lingering flavors of chocolate and caramel. In my opinion, any food would just undermine this fine brew. Have it all by itself as a well-deserved dessert! You can thank me later!
Whoa .. what a beautiful beer. Dark brown with a thick tan head. Very well balanced. Lovers of Imperial Stouts will find this to be orgasmic.

bottled on 8/17/10 very dark chocolate, raisin, roasty aroma. wood aromas sneak through, especially after warming up a bit.  super dark brown color with nice puffy tan head at pour. very complex flavors of raisins dark chocolate wood, wow. alcohol has mellowed over time and it is much smoother than a fresh bottle.  slick, viscous feel on the palate. have another bottle from same batch and will save it for another year! age some if you can resist temptation!!
Pours velvety black with tiny tan head. Wood, raisins, Christmas cake fruit in the aroma. Balanced sweetness and full body. Lingering fruity finish.
Pour is black with brown head. Aroma is wood, leather, chocolate, tobacco. Taste is sweet. Palate is thin for a beer with so much flavor. Overall its good and would be nice on a cold evening.

Bottle. Pours very dark, almost black with a brown head. Probably one of the most complex beers I have ever had so far. Definitively can taste the maltiness with overtones of burnt caramel. Very heavy over the palate.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2012 I cant find one fault with this beer! Its not a beer you want to guzzle down in 20 minutes or less, its most definitely a beer you want to drink over an hours time. Let it warm up to around 57-60 degrees and you will hit peak performance of taste with this beer as it gets warmer. Cant go wrong!
I had this beer once and it stole my heart.  Ive been looking for it ever since.  Dont miss the opportunity to try it if you get the chance.
This is awesome. It has a lot going on. Choclatey, wood, roasted malts. Excellent for sipping. Will have again.

On tap at bradys pub. Jet black with a beautiful tan head. Incredible aroma of chocolate milkshake, woodsy, coffee. Taste is strong alcohol, woodsy.  Super thick and creamy.  Chocolatey.  The alcohol ruins this a bit.

Poured a deep black-brown with a hint of red.  This is a very intense high alcohol brew with a subtle effervescence. The beer had a silky feel.  The flavors are loaded with chocolate, coffee with slight cherry notes.  All in all a wonderful experience!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle from Dutchs for $3.75 (bottled 7/19/2011). Pitch black color (completely opaque), brown head around the edge, just like a stout. Mountainous lacing. Very roasty aroma, and a strong bitter taste in the nose. Very warm alcohol aftertaste, somewhat like wine. Perfect amount of carbonation and nice texture, but has a sort of acidic texture through the finish. Very interesting, and certainly big brew though.

Coffee and chocolate with a slightly fruity quality. Full bodied with dried fruit. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark brown with a thin beige head. Intense malty nose with hints of brown sugar, sherry and roasted nuts. Deep, full body, really smooth for its 12%, really nice woody character to this one, very long sweet malt/wood aftertaste. Nice sipping beer.

Ive had this one in the fridge for a while because I wasnt sure when to have it.  I wasnt sure what it would go with or when Id be able to just toss back a beer at 12% ABV (Im a light weight).

It poured a dark black with a brown head and had a far less strong alcohol taste than Id have expected.  Very malty.

I enjoyed it with some slow cooked ribs which was actually a very nice compliment.  Id highly recommend this one with barbecued or grilled meats.

Date: August 6, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Total Wine, Las Vegas, NV Appearance: Opaque black, slight amount of head. Aroma: Woodsy/oak, molasses, slight alcohol. Flavor: Consistent with aroma though not as sweet as would be expected from aroma, medium bodied, hint of alcohol in finish. Other: Wow, this was amazing, how do they blend 12% alcohol in this but you can barely taste it.  Seems a tad under-rated to me.

This beer is excessive on almost every front. Pours nearly black with a brown head. Almost syrupy in viscosity. Initial punch of wood is strong, which leads to a small varnish sensation.  Mid-palate has soy sauce like effect. Roasted caramel and sugar permeates finish.  

Best complement is that little alcohol burn despite being 12% abv. 

With some more restraint, this couldve been a great beer, but is quite lacking due to fundamental immaturity of approach. No doubt the "Im 23 and like unconventional beer" crowd loves this, hence the abnormally high ratings. But in reality its a fairly disconnected and inelegant offering. But one that couldve been great......
Same bottle as pictured. Poured an interesting dark black with no head. Flavours from the wood are definitely present with roasty malt backbone.

From the bottle at WineStyles.  OK... not a big connisseur of Dog Fish Head, but this beer is GREAT!  Im a big imperial stout lover and this, to me, had all the markings.  It was creamy, coffee, chocolate wonderful goodness.  I know, I know... the description says vanilla... well... cant say I really tasted vanilla, but it was really great to me and if you are an imperial stout lover, you will like this one, too!!

Pours dark dark brown slight frizzy and a rather high head.
Aromas and taste of oak, burned sugar, nutmeg, chocolate and coffe.
Round and smooth in the mouth.
Short finish.
Slight taste of alcohol.
If it walks like a stout and quacks like a stout, than its obviously an American Strong Ale. Very nice beer though, lots of roastyness. The alcohol was surprisingly well hidden.

Bottle, pours dark black, surprising this one isnt a stout, sure tastes just like a stout, it smelt like a stout tasted like one too, it had the smell of dark malts, it tasted very chocolaty and it was pretty good, drinkable
This beer will knock your socks off. Its so good. Really thick and bitter but has a great taste. For beer lovers, I think youll enjoy this one.

12 oz bottle. Pours opaque black with a thin tan head. Aroma is coffee, cocoa and vanilla, hints of brown sugar and raisin, alcohol. Taste is vanilla and oak, toffee, cocoa, nuts, raisin, with definite spicy alcohol presence. Finishes with coffee, oak, alcohol, sweet and syrupy. Mouthfeel is smooth, heavy body, low carbonation, sticky.

Pours black with thin off white head. Nose is pungent wood smoke, oak wood, roasted red meat, liquorice and sarsaparilla. Not to my taste at all. Overpowering roasted sweet smoky beer. Tastes of smoky bacon, with sweet brown sugar malt and something even more sweet and cloying. This feels like one of those beers where you chuck everything in and try to make it complex but instead its horrible.

12 oz. bottle. Pours dark brown, almost black with practically no head. The aroma is nuts, toasted malts, honey, cinnamon, black pepper, and vanilla. The flavor is very sweet, roasted bitterness, and a touch of sourness in the finish. The palate is heavy, sticky, and syrupy. The finish is long and sweet, spicy and warming. Overall, a powerful and smooth beer.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2011 Incredible beer. Bottle from Chris Liquor in OB. Awesome nose of wood, char, malt, and a touch of soy or teriyaki. The flavor starts sweet, big roasted malt flavors, and then depths of wood dominate. The wood flavor is complex, rich, and the last few notes are molasses and almost like steak, or red meat. This beer is so complex, so big, with the perfect balance of sweet and bitter, with a gorgeous wood tone. RE-RATE:  All of what I said is still true, but there is a cloyingly, syrupy sweet quality which is just overdone, and really drags this one down a bit, for me.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2013 drank at mondial 2011 in mtl. very dark brown, almost pitch black with a dark beige head, excellent retention and lacing. aroma is smoked and malted, oak, red port wine. molasses, raisins, tons of roastiness, cherries, bitter chocolate, alcohol, spices (not quite belgianesque). medium to long grassy finish. full body, soft carbonation. wow. (will re-rate eventually)

pours dark brown with a thin coffee coloured head that quickly fades, leaves good lacing. aroma is loaded with wood, molasses and alcohol. taste begins sweet, very malty, very rich. notes of caramel develop as the beer goes down the throat, and then a whisky like finish. virtually no hops. mouthfeel is full bodied, and the alcohol definately makes its presence known! an unbelievable beer, gotta give this one a perfect score.

355ml bottle from Steamworks Liqour Store, Vancouver, BC
Bottled 11/10/10 - Pours black with a small smooth head. Aroma has notes of wood, chocolate and malts. Taste is smooth but quite complex with notes of alcohol, wood, oak, malts, dark fruits and syrup. Finish is pleasant with notes of malts. Alcohol warms nicely in the end. Great beer.

Poured from 12oz bottle into tulip.  Pours very very dark brown, almost black with two fingers of light tan head.  Aroma is coffee, some chocolate, plums/prunes and a bit of something almost medicinal.  Taste is dark chocolate, some dried fruit (Prunes?) and coffee.  This hides the alcohol well.

Dark brown with minimal head.  Aroma with rich chocolate, coffee, and an almost chemical smell (spray paint?).  Has smooth body, chocolate, malt, a little dark fruit, anise, and finishes mildly alcoholic.  Dry finish.  Pretty interesting

Beer pours deep brown nearly black with small brown head.  Aroma is dark fruits, chocolate, booze.  Taste is Sweet and oaky with notes of chocolate and plums but quite a bit boozy.  Palate is very rich and velvety smooth.  Fantastic beer that maybe could use a bit more time in the bottle to smooth out some of the boozyness.

Tap on 2 occasions over the past 2-3 years.  My first experiecne with this beer was at a small beerfest just outside St Louis.  I drank WAY too much of this stuff and barfed all over my living room floor after passing out on my couch.  No bueno!  THe last time i had this i only had one and i STILL barfed in a friends car.  not good.  Ok, however, this beer is unbelievable.  pours deep brown with a small soapy tan head.  nose of roasted nuts sugary barrel aging with some chocolate and spicy-hazelnut-awesome nose!  i love this brew it so deceptive though it 12% its easy to drink for its abv.  long finish of nuts roast and toasted malt.  Awesome beer just wish i didnt barf after the 2 times i have had it.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2014 355 ml bottle. Bottled 30.7.2009.
Pours a only slight transparent, almost black colour with a small beige head on the edges. Aroma of salty licorice, syrup, dark fruits and ash. Flavour of roasted malts, ash, wood, licorice, syrup, chocolate and dark fruits such as blackcurrant. Full bodied with a thick, slightly sticky mouthfeel and a warming, fruity, woody finish. Very pleasant. 8-4-9-4-16 4.1
355 ml bottle. Re-rate.
Pours a dark brown colour with a beautiful creamy thick head. Aroma and flavour are both very, very rich; the base beer is recognizable, wooden notes are strong, some raisin, rich sweetness and strong roastiness. Full bodied, most definitely. Luscious. 8-4-9-4-16 4.2.

Pours black with a tinge of brown. Has a nice inch of khaki foam. Nice aromatics of perfumed wood. Mellow and balanced on the tongue with a nice sense of effervescence. . Its hard to believe this ones 12%. Finishes clean. This would make a fantastic digestif.

Poured into a snifter the beer has a dark color with a thick pour. Unique beer. The aroma is licorice and molasses. The flavor hits you with something totally different. Again licorice is the first thing I think of along with vanilla and cappuccino. The wood that is used in the aging process gives it a flavor that is very hard to describe. Just go out and buy some or find it at one of your local pubs.

Bottle, pours a rich chocolate-brown with capuccino-like brown head that leaves sheets of lacing on the glass. Nose is filthy rich: vanilla, caramel, some hazelnut, nutmeg, slight cinnamon and brown sugar. Flavors are powerful: more vanilla and big caramel sweetness, with hints of earthiness. Creamy mouthfeel, throat-coating texture. This tastes like someone brewed an imperial stout with brown ale ingredients. Big, syrupy, and strong. Right up my alley, but be sure to savor this one for as long as you can.
alot of alcohol in this one in flavor.  but very toasty when it warms up a bit in your glass. not something i would drink a lot of but good

Bottle. Feb 2011. Pours black; not brown, with tight creamy tan head, decent lace. Big med-dark malts, cocoa, wood, light smoked, grain, vanilla, nuts, choc, pine grass hop aromas beneath the big complexity of aromas. Med-full body, med carb - black, acidic malt, but sweet burnt toffee comes through, anise, vanilla and earthy with a chalky body some red wine and pitted fruit. Bitterness and piney hop flavour coming through the long complex finish. very warming., yet a touch hot on the finish. Would love to experience an older one of these.

12oz btl poured into tulip glass. Dark copper brown in color with minimal tan head. Aromas of chocolate, caramel, vanilla, sweet dates, brown sugar and a slight woodsy smell as expected...grain alcohol smell really apparent. Sweetness at first then goes into way more complexity. Obviously, not your typical brown ale...really shouldnt be classified as one. A great beer if youre looking for a strong ale for a quick effect...Not really a beer to drink multiples of at one time.
incredibly silky smooth in the mouth and crisp going down. Sweet malts with nutty caramel and vanilla flavours. Full-bodied, toasty and potent.
Bottle. Pours cloudy mahogany. Aroma and flavour of syrup, molasses, dark fruit, roasted malt, caramel, toasty. Sweet and smooth

12oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours very dark brown with a thick, lacy, tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, nuts, wood, vanilla, floral hops, and some alcohol.  A very complex flavor, with the barrel aging evident.  Smooth texture.  A really good beer, and one of this brewers best.

Malziger Antrunk mit semiger Bananennote, danach fruchtiger werdend. Das Malz wird dabei immer kräftiger, die Bananennote zieht mit und stiegert sich ebenfalls. Leicht schokoladig, extrem röstig und voluminös. Zum Ende blickt  ein getreidiger Ton durch den Alkohol. Danke an kappldav123! /12/12/13/11/13

I want to like this beer, since Dogfish put so much damned effort and money into producing it, but I cant seem to get on the wagon.  The pour is expectedly ugly, viscous with little head, but the smell sets you up for the boozy ride ahead:  peppery, malt, and grain alcohol all collide in your nose, failing to ease any trepidation.  And, while the unbelievable amount of sweet and decadent flavors are produced by this dark, thick liquid, their lack of subtlety eventually kills their appeal.  Theres a nutty base underlying everything, while raisins, bread pudding, caramel, and vanilla ice cream float across your palate. Everything is accompanied by an alcohol-and-pepper mouthfeel, huge and filling, to the point of overload.  I feel Ive drank this beer much too early; for now, the alcohol heat and massive sweetness poop upon this party.  (4/29/09)

Aroma: Appetizing roasted and bread malts, with hints of wood and smoke.
Appearance: Black with thick, tan head.
Taste: Light sweetness with a light bitterness and slightly sour finish.
Palate: Medium-heavy body, oily texture, soft carbonation with a long, alcohol laced finish.
Overall: Dogfish is known for their experimentation, and this brew is no exception. It feels like a rich, heavy wine as opposed to a beer with a heavy alcohol finish. AT 12%, Im not surprised, but its a bit off putting. Still, its a rich and well balance beer, well thought out and crafted.
Pours a deep dark brown. Almost black with a thin tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt. Toasty. Taste has a hint of alcohol. Very Roasty and  Coffee like. Has a very nice feel in your mouth.

Bottle from BoE. Very dark brown near black with a slight beige scum round the rim. Aroma has sweet wood and ancient leather with traces of dates. Thick, oily taste of sweetness mingling with earth and ash together with  hints of wormwood, rocket and alcohol. Sharp, lingering bitterness. Very interesting rather than intensely enjoyable.

This beer has a pleasing appearance, dark and completely opaque. The aroma is heavy with dried fruit and wood. It is a very complex beer as far as taste is concerned, with rich coffee and caramel malt characteristics. Overall this beer is truly enjoyable and well worth purchasing.

On tap at TJs. Pours dark brown with thin head. Caramel, earthy, spruce, burnt. Somewhat acidic. Cant detect the alcohol despite the high content. The wood adds an interesting flavor underlying everything. Enjoyed this more than I thought.
Pours a midnight black with a faint tan head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, vanilla, caramel and dark fruit. Sweet flavor dominated by roasted malt. Very smooth body. Awesome brew.

3 May 2011, bottle. black and think looking. gorgeous nose. serious alcohol. hints of raisin that are dominated by burnt molasses and resiny wood. full body, faintly fizzy and seriously syrupy. there is a sweet, almost bourbon aged barley wine in the background but there is a very drying, vanilla and oaky foreground. absolutely gorgeous!

12oz bottle, at least a year old. Pours a dark brown, almost black with a light brown head, quickly settles to light lacing. Aroma of roasted dark malts, nuts, anise, some smoke, dark vanilla and alcohol. Strong taste of alcohol, sweet at first, mellows a bit, finishes with a nice balance of sweet and bitterness - vanilla with alcohol and some hops. Has definitely become sweeter with time, curious if the alcohol will mellow out more or become more prominent - would be nice if the alcohol mellowed without the sweetness becoming too cloying - we shall see.

Just a faint light brown slick of a head floating atop a liquid the color of the blackest heart scheming during the darkest night.  Fizzy mouthfeel that blends away to a chalky coating that lays on the tongue, hugs tightly, and settles in for a long while.  Dark notes of darkness in the flavor which really bring out the color of darkness (which is totally not descriptive, I know, but thats what Ive got at the moment).  Pretty good.
Bottle. Black with a thin offwhite head. Vanilla syrup aroma. Flavour is intense, wood, roast, treacle. Finish is very long lasting. One for special occasions.
Another excellent brewski from Dogfish head. Very dark beer, with an excellent taste, not harsh, not sweet, makes me want to open another bottle. At 1 abv, I think Ill stick to one for now.
Bottle.  Pours brown with thin cream head that retains.  Aroma is wood and smoke.  Flavor is vanilla, wood, brown sugar, and coffee.  Delicious.

This is just a little bit of crazy...strong brown ale that has so much wood exposure it tastes like its been in a bourbon barrel.  Pours like hersheys syrup only a little thinner with a faint brown head.  Extreme flavor across the palateto include oak, and a ton of vanilla.  A little boozy but not nearly as much as it should be given the abv.  Finish holds hard.

Neat experience, but I wouldnt want to dig in to this one too often or in high volume...pretty intense.

Pours an opaque black.  Aroma is very boozy and somewhat sweet.  Taste is very much like a porter combined with a stout and bourbon, can get a sense of the wood aging in there.  . A really enjoyable beer.
What a great story this beer is and it tastes great.  The is definitely some syrupy/sappy notes apparent.  Some vanilla notes from the wood but sweet and very roasty.  Brown sugar tastes found too.
Sampled at a beer tasting, more comments to come as I organize my notes from the session. Aftertaste was quite heavy, packs a punch.

What looks like a thick, black opaque beer is actually a very dark garnet colored brew (when viewed with an extremely bright light) thats not very thick or syrupy at all.   Dark roasted malt and woody aromas with a strong vinous scent that would have made me guess this was aged in wine barrels.  Milk and dark chocolates hit the palate first and then a spicy, white pepper tingle the back of the tongue.  Im assuming this is from the Palo Santo wood and its just an awesome flavor!  Theres also an earthy mustiness and woody dryness that completely tames the lightly prune flavored sweetness and balances it perfectly.   Its really hard to believe that this is 12% ABV.  Everything here is so balanced and flavorful that the alcohol even at this level is almost an afterthought.   This is such an awesome beer and so delicious and easy to drink given its "extremeness".

poured from 12 oz bottle. Dark brown/black with a small head. Aromas of molasses port wine coffee and smoked wood. Tastes of roasted malts vanilla expresso ripened fruits and hints of whiskey. Bold and robust.A contemplative brew with a definite presence of the alcohol. Sip this one to enjoy.

12oz poured into a shifter.  Aromas of toasted marshmallows, molasses and some spice.  Pots a dark brown, near blak with a this brown head.  Taste has roasted malt notes, burnt sugar, like creme brûlée.  Very bold flavorsbthat hide the alcohol well.  Palate is full bodied.  Overall, another great DFH beer, and a sneaker for sure.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2011 Pours a deep dark brown with a ful smooth creamy head.  Wonderful sheets of lace cling to the glass.  Smells of licorice, anise, sweet dark fruits.  There is also a noticeable amount of smoke and tobacco.  Rich, creamy, and heavy on the palate.  This is rather robust and full flavored with tastes of anise and molasses, rich dark sugars from fruit, and cocoa that really come together well.  The finish picks up the wood and a touch of smoke.  These flavors are heavy and rich, but they intermingle well and this is a really good beer.

Bottled 12 fl. oz (Utobeer, 6£)
Commercial description at RB talks about adding wood to the tanks, but DF homepage says that they are using wooden tank. Opaque black color, small brown head with some lace. Aroma has toasted sugar, some licorice and strong vanilla&oak. Full-bodied, soft almost creamy palate. I cant say that "it is hiding alcohol very well", because this IS very strong, but strong in a good, powerful way. Sweetish and roasted flavor with licorice, brown sugar, portwine, vanilla and oak. Aftertaste has coffee, oak and sugar with lingering alcohol. Warming, extreme and interesting sipping beer.

Poured into a Dogfish head glass.  Color is jet black with a thick tan head.  Aroma is roasty with chocolate and coffee notes as well as some alcohol.   Flavor is roasty with some dried fruit flavors and alcohol.  The wood flavors dont really come through until the finish, but then they keep coming.  Overall a good beer even if it is completely confused about its actual style - Id call it a porter or a stout, but nobody pays me to do this...
Very good. Brown cream head.  Really, creamy, coffeeish, not too bold, nicely balanced. Thick but smooth. Designed well and you could have a few and I dont think it would be overboard on the tongue

The beer pours a very dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma is very strong and very spicy. I get a lot of woody notes, which I presume is from the Palo Santo wood. I also get some dark fruit notes in the aroma. The flavor is very similar. I get a lot of oaked and wood notes, as well as some caramel and roasted malt, vanilla, spices and dark fruit. The alcohol is definitely present, but it is not overpowering. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very well done beer.
