Poured into a snifter. PSM pours a deep rich mahogany, if not almost black. Nice tan head on top, with a decent retention level. Mild lacing. Oaky, very sweet aromas, figs, plums, some dark spices, along with some dark fruits, vanilla, and caramel. Vanilla and caramel tastes up front. Not quite the flavor I expected from a brown ale, which sets this one from the rest. It almost starts like an oak aged imperial stout. Some bourbon as well. Mouthfeel is creamy, with a great carbonation level. Very complex palate. Extremely smooth for 12%. Very nice drinkability and its a sleeper. Absolute greatness which is expected when drinking DFH.

Poured into my DFH 12oz. glass. Colour is really really deep dark brown. Head is light brown, with thin lacing all the way down the glass. This one definitely lets you know its 12% in the aroma! Other detectable smells would be a slight roastiness/ chocolate aroma, a dried fruit type aroma. The flavor is of roastiness, and fermented wood. But honestly now that Im toward the bottom of the glass the alcohol is kicking in pretty strong, especially on the finish. Overall I dont think this is much of a brown, but more of a imperial stout, or as its classified here an American strong ale. But it is good drinkin, reminds me of Lagunitas Hairy Eyeball, and if I had drinkin this first Id say Hairy Eyeball tastes like Palo Santo Marron. So its a good beer, even at $15.99 for four!! Sam is REALLY proud of this one!!!

Bottle. Not a huge fan of brown ales but I wanted to give this a try. Nose was full of vanilla, alcohol, and some sweetness. Definite hint of wood/roast. Taste was similar with a sweet, roasty malt flavor and some hints of chocolate/caramel and wood. A little hoppiness going on in there too. I find this beer somewhat complex but drinkable even with the alcohol coming through on the finish. Nice tan lacing, too. Not bad for a brown ale.

Pleasant aroma of milk chocolate and vanilla sugar. Reminiscent of an imperial stout when smelled. The overall experience is a very tasty beer that is markedly bitter and has a character that is woody in essence. One to recommend

Had it on Bottle. Pours oil black with a thin, light grey-brown head. Aroma has chocolate, nuts, and roasted malt notes present. Flavor is mostly sweet burt whit a nice tast of hops: Rich, sugary caramel malt. Mouthfeel and finish is where its really happening. Full bodied. Slick, creamy, and slightly fizzy with a malty sweetness in the aftertast.

12 oz bottle bottled on 12/06/10.

IT pours inot my snifter a dark brown, pretty much black with a foamy tan head that sticks for a nice bit of time and leaves delicate lacing.

The smell is a bit alcoholic with a good whiff but it also has some unique wood tones to it. I love exotic wood aged beers and this one in particular has a nice quality to it. There is also some roasted flavors and chocolate in the smell.

The flavor also has a major dose of wood and alcohol. The wood provides some tannic and almost spicy notes. The alcohol meld with the sweetness of the malts for a warming overtone. In between thsi is loads of dark chocolate with a moderately sweet dry finish.

They packed a lot of flavor into this one and although it is a bit sweet and cloying, the wood mellows it and it becomes a fine beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-06-2011 23:02:52
12oz bottle. Pours dark brown almost black. Roast aroma, roast sour tongue, big beer feel.

355ml bottle (Bacchanalia, Cambridge)
3 Burnt ashy aroma, noxious volatiles too, boozy. Generally quite unpleasant.
4 Very dark red, small tight head settles to a tan ring.
3+ Retronasals so hot that I think if I were to sniff out onto a naked flame Id be like a flame-thrower. Taste very ashy, and solventy too. Not just alcohol, but acetone.
2 Sticky palate, OK carbonation. Godawful finish, very ashy and astringent. Drying. Burning in my mouth from the combination of pure booze, astringent ashiness, and unbalanced bitterness. This isnt unbalanced - its the exact opposite of balance. Anti-balanced.
7 A way for idiots with too much money to get drunk. Sorry, but even your average eastern european malt liquor is way more drinkable than this. Utterly devoid of anything which I recognise as essential to a beer. For a laugh, I poured out a pissy pale lager, to see which one I prefered to drink, and, to be honest, this was better than the really bad pale lager. For even more of a laugh, I blended different ratios of the two, and at about the 50/50 mark, it was an almost tasty drink (2.4-ish).

Pours viscus and black.  Lots of roasty notes, vanilla, alcohol, some wood.  Very low carbonation.  Head was small and very dark khaki.  Tastes of velvety chocolate cake (quite rich) some cedar notes in between the alcohol burn.  Finishes seltzer like and a bit tart.  Having a hard time describing this one.  Unique and very well done.  After drinking one of these, I am not sure I am on earth anymore.  Has the effects of smoking an entire crippie joint by yourself.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2012 I am so glad I retried this beer. Scent is powerful wood notes and light roast. Taste is big and bold of wood and oak like, nice and smooth vanilla flavor. After taste gives a long lasting wood flavor, pretty killer beer.

Tasted in late February 2011 from a 12oz bottle purchased at Plaza Liquors, bottled on 2/11/08.  Pours an opaque dark thick brown with a tint of amber and an average tan head that recedes very slowly to a thin but even lace and collar.  The nose is fruity with cola, chocolate, very malty with some roast, vanilla, and light coffee.  The flavor is much darker and more roasted.  It is fruity and cola up front, moving to dark chocolate, coffee bitterness, vanilla, and more roast on the back.  The body is full and creamy with lighter carbonation and a long roasted and vanilla finish.

Bottle shared at RBWG 
Appearance: Dark brown with a medium sized tan head and good lacing 
Aroma: Toasted malts, woody and dark fruits 
Taste: Toasted malts, nutty, dark fruits and vanilla 
Very nice.

Pours like a stout but with a thin head.  Not as black as a black lager, but thicker so appears as dark with more of a mahogany darkness.  You can definitely smell and taste the use of the wood.  Not a typical brown ale, thats for sure.   Alcohol is not over-whelming but am a fan of high ABVs.  Great caramel notes and great overall taste.   Would buy again.

Pours a very dark, oily brown with thin to medium-sized head. Complex mixture of flavors, with a very pronounced licorice in the forefront. Some vanilla and caramel also. Rather sweetish, very thick beer with a high alcohol content. Certainly worth a try.

Certainly an interesting drop, but not sure Id have another. Like a woody "old style" porter (lightly soured, and a little acrid in a nice way), but with a little liqorice. Surprised to see so many very high ratings for this beer here. Maybe I just dont get it.  Anyway, good, but just this one bottle for me I think.

This may be one of my favorites from the Dogfish crew, the other is Burton Baton. This beer has an almost sweet caramel and vanilla aroma.  Semi- sweet start with some serious woody acidity. An under current of booziness throughout.. This stuff is well worth trying.

They have this beer on tap in Heaven.
This tops my former favorite beer, New Belgium 1554.  Yes, it looks like motor oil, but it tastes like paradise.  Very heavy.  Almost syrupy mouthfeel...but if you know that going in, it doesnt matter.  Alcohol kicks you in the head after about three sips.  Maybe thats why my review is glowing so brightly!

Pours very dark brown with a brown head. The aroma is prunes, nuts,  noticeable acetylhyde, and a little bit of fruit cake.The flavor is sweet, alcoholic, and fruity with the woodiness coming through in the very finish, but in a strong way. Theres a slight nuttiness that reminds me of a rich pecan pie for some reason, but not as good as that sounds. This was a little rough and sloppy for me.

never had anything quite like this before.  kind of looks scary, like transmission fluid.  at 12% A.B.V. it initially frightened the mouth.  sampled one, and didnt have another brew that session.  I couldnt.  more wood than a forest.  dont get me wrong.  it was very, very different.  if only i could get the slivers out of my mouth.  be brave.  this one is definitely worth the experience.

Pours a midnight black in color with a tan head. Head fades quickly leaving a slim wisping of cover behind. This is much darker than you would expect a brown ale to be. I would say more of an imperial stout in color, except darker.
Slightly phenolic. A little sour and sweet at the same time. Hints of dates, caramel and molasses. Nicely done. But not a brown ale.
Sweet, a slight twang from the sour aroma present. I assume from the wood it was aged in. Big alcohol presence. A bit of the caramel and molasses comes through again. And a bitterness not to be confused with the sourness. A bit of roastiness. Not too bad. Again, not a brown ale.
An oiliness left in my mouth. But soon cut through by the bitterness and sourness. That is what is left until I take another drink. Especially the sour twang. Still not a brown ale.
Fairly drinkable given the super high ABV for a brown ale. Good thing they mislabeled this thing. Because it is definitely not a brown ale. If you want a lighter imperial stout, then this is what you would reach for. If you want a brown ale, youll confused. Not a brown ale.

Woody Wood Pecker got a woody when he tried this beer! The Paraguayan Palo Santo wood was sent from above down to earth for those who demanded nothing less than WOODY BEER! Yes sir I will have another!

This beer pours a brown color with a small tan head. Lacing sticks to my glass. Smell of wood, caramel, and vanilla. Sweet brown sugar taste throughout the beer. Very smooth and easy drinking, the 12% ABV can sneak up on you.
There is a very unique profile to the oak aging in this beer, not the typicaloaks vanillin. It works very well, highly recommended

Holy fuck 12%. They call it a brown ale... but this shit is completely opaque. Very, VERY strong malty flavors, along with vanilla, cinnamon, and woodiniess that I usually only get from fine red wines and old scotch.

Camel and coffee aroma that pours bold and dark almost black with a minimal head.  The first sip is medium sweet that borders a port followed by a creamy smoothness for the rest of the bottle.  At 12% one or two is enough to get you through a nice omega 3 fish dinner.

Some of the best lacing Ive seen. Pours a deep and dark brown with a very thin tan head. Aromas of rich, dark chocolate surroundded by very sweet malts. Obvious smell of alcohol. Very rich flavour. Lots of burnt coffee, dark cocoa, sultanas and grapes ? Definitely a hint of banana. The alcohol really warms as it goes down. Perfect palate. Great beer but not for the light hearted
Lovely lush nose with chocolate, coffee, raisins, vanilla. Creamy and full-bodied, loads of flavor, distinctive sweet finish lingers, warming but not overheated, delicious. Really excellent.

aroma is a strong coffee with some sweet chocolate and slight soy sauce aroma, which i never thought I would like but it goes pretty well slight fig and grape like aroma, dark brown appearance, first taste is slightly alcoholic, mid tongue is slightly fig like with some coffee in there as well and finishes sweet malt

On draft @ Sunset Grill.  Deep brown/ nearly black. Amazing head with lacing that coats the glass in sheets.  The wood barrel taste is very intense. Flavor and nose makes me think Im in a South American Rain Forest.  This beer is meant to be sipped slowly.  Not for the light hearted. You can really pick up the 12% ABV as it warms up.

Aroma is dark and sweet. Like sticky toffee pudding with rum...or banana fosters. Definitely banana. I believe this is one of my favorite smelling beers. Taste is sharp. Sweet malty. Coffee. A ton of toasty. Slight smokey. Pleasantly bitter on the end. Super sweet in the middle. I love it. Id enjoy this everyday. I love the dry finish with the smokeiness. Pitch black with lasting head. Fantastic brew. The mouthfeel is perfect. Great.

Pours black as black is with a miiinimal brown head. Aroma is fullbodied malty, vanilla, tar, meaty, alcohol, sweet, raisins and fidges. Fullbodied fruity mouthfeel. Malty sweet, acetone, alcohol, tar, licorice and coffee in its fullbodied flavor. Nice mix indded. Fantastic good palate. Finishes fruity sweet and still very pleasantly tart.

Bottled 2/2009 - bottle shared by lagunitasfan.    Pours really dark..thin tan one-sided head.  Boozy, just slightly smokey malt-forward nose with nicely aged malt and underlying port-wine elements and some pretty evident licorice tones.  A little oxidized in flavor...a touch of flabbiness...but otherwise..licorice, licorice, and some more licorice...and maybe a touch of chocolate...and some more licorice.  Let m3 mention that I quite enjoy licorice, so I am surely not upset.  Not too shabby actually...has held up decently, but...even though Im sure Ive had it fresher but dont remember, I dont think its going anywhere from here.

Aged 2 years by lagunitasfan and busted out for Dasilkys birthday tasting. Pours a deep brown with little bubble lacing. Smells like wood, caramel, malts and alcohol.  Taste is sweet caramel, molasses, malts, dried fruits, and wood. Nice finish, dry and bitter with warming alcohol.

Pours a deep dark brown with a huge rocky tan head. The taste is unlike anything I have had before. Starts with sweet vanilla and caramel followed by wood. Finish is long and dry with a bit of cherry and alcohol warmth. Superior lacing.

Bottle. Finger of tan head deep chocolate brown that verges on mahogany. Chocolate, light woodiness, nutty, and dark fruits in the aroma.  Flavor is a bit sweet at first, then moves onto dark fruits, and a bit of a dry woody finish.  Lots of warming alcohol, but doesnt show up in the taste.  Medium to thicker body with bubbly carbonation.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Oak, chocolate and sherry aroma. Dark brown, tiny brown head, fair lace. Sweet, very malty, salty, licorice wood, hint of vanilla. Sticky and full, alcohol hidden. Flavourful, yummy.

pours dark brown almost black with a thick tan head, smells roasty with hints of chocolate and caramel. taste starts sweet with a slightly woody taste and a nice smooth finish with a bit of an alcohol after taste but for twelve percent you cant notice it as much as you would think. very thick and creamy, great beer as always from dfh, aging one for a year or so ill let you know wat i think then.

Pours a dark, opaque brown with a thin, fading caramel head. Smells woody and earthy but slightly fruity. Taste is much of the same, leaning towards the earthy and herbal with a slight hint of chocolate on the way out. Goes down nice and smooth but the ABV is definitely noticeable.

Pours a dark brown, virtually no head. A slight aroma of wood that I barely catch, tastes like malt to start, with an overwhelming taste of fresh-squeezed orange juice with a little bit of alcohol at the end. I wouldnt drink this every day, but its definately worth the $10.99 I paid for the 4-pack.

Ive had this on draft before (but this rating is for a bottled version) and I have to say that the wood flavor is much more subdued in the bottle.  The aroma is not as strong and there is a good opportunity for all of the roasty flavor to come out behind the wood.  On draft I thought it was overpoweringly woody, but in a bottle Id say its a nice mix.

Nice dark pour with a small brown head. Not getting much of a wood flavour coming through. Aroma was fairly consistent with an imperial stout. Love dogfish head but this is mid pack of their portfolio.

Bought a case in march 2009 and kept half in my celler.  That really mellowed it out.  Love the brown head.  The strong soy sauce aroma I disliked before has really mellowed out to more of a heady, roasty earth blast.  It seems to have more of a nutty overtone now.  Before it was definitely sweeter, I would say merlot-ish.  Now I suppose it could be like a victorian stout or something.  Glad I let it sit down there and get dusty because it was kinda overwhelming at first. That time-out behind the furnace really let it calm down.  Well, thats life, I didnt care for her two years ago and now were dating......

Pours a dark brown, almost black with a thin tan head that dissipates quickly. Looks very stout-like. Aroma is filled with caramel and chocolates, a bit of vanilla and oak-like flavor, some alcohol it there too. Tastes wonderful! Lots of roast and dark fruits, vanilla, more wood flavors and alcohol burn in the finish. Very creamy in the mouth. Thick and full bodied. Light carbonation. This a damn fine brew, but Im not sure Id label it a brown. Defiantly not what I was expecting, but great nonetheless.

Very toasty and roasted, earthy smell. Strong wood and smoke. Doesnt give away the intense strength. Pours pitch black with a thin head but solid lacing. Taste is nothing amazing, but its balance is amazing on its own for a 12% beer.
Very good dark beer. Thick and full of taste. I like the bitter taste that kicks in after each drink.
BLECH! All you beersnobs can have this one... a murky black brew, looks and smells like well used motor oil, strong,heavy, beastly and boozey, for the Lagerboy this beer has undrinkability.

Bravo. Motor oil pour, dark brown beer with an off-white head. Looks like an imperial stout. Smells like one too, coffee/bitter chocolate on the nose accompanied by powerful notes of Santo Palo wood. Very nice aroma. The taste is beastly, huge roasted notes with some dark coffee along with massive woody flavors. High ABV is present here and makes itself well known. Another must try beer from Dogfish.

Bottle; Pour is a dark brown with tan head. Retention is on the average side. Very light lacing in this snifter - On the nose there is at first a mineral feel. What is obvious is the Palo Santo wood as well - Its obvious because its clearly not oak. This brew had a metallic taste initially;  it disappeared as it warmed. It was nearly cloying as well - which also disappeared as it warmed. The wood as well as a general earthy feel is very present, there is a sweet yet bitter acetic cherry note, a chocolate note rears its head, and the brew tends to end on the bitter side while coupling with a boozy feel as well. I appreciate the unique experience here; it didnt quite make it for me, however.
Very smooth in taste and inviting in aroma.  Pours a dark brown and is a great beer but you can only have a couple due to the high ABV.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2012 On tap and 12 oz bottle.
Pours a dark brown, smells slightly of oak and cherries.  Incredibly inviting both in colour and aroma - the taste doesnt disappoint.  Slightly sweet with a smooth, creamy taste.  I love this beer but can only have a couple due to the high ABV.

Bottle. Pours ruby brown with a nice biege head. Aroma of wood, cherries, vanilla. Flavor is rich, woody, sweet (but not sticky) with the cherries and vanilla shining through and no booziness despite the 12% abv. Excellent.
A small head when poured from the bottle to the pint. Very nice cherry like aroma. Has a bit of a wood flavor. Very full in body.
caramel, toast, roasty, basement aromas, raisin, vanilla, black, tan foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, full body, sticky, lively, long finish,

12fl oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  Very dark brown, almost black, with a small diminishing brown cap.  Aroma is vanilla, cherry, alcohol.  Flavor is wood, vanilla, strong alcohol.  Full body, lively carbonation.  Finish is short bitterness and lasting alcohol.  A very bold, in your face brew.

Bottle purchased 11/18/2010. Colour is as black as midnight and thick as heck...surprisingly little head. Nose: Woody, with acetone, forest smoke, hot rubber, crayon. Taste: Light sweet, medium bitter, medium sour. Burnt embers, black liquorice, Buckleys cough syrup, slight citurs note. Finish is surprisingly light and not overly long, but the power of the alcohol probably masks it. To high an ABV for me, it just doesnt allow the body to truly open up and the thickness of it masks the wood influence.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2011 Bottle. The pour was a murky dark brown almost black with a small (less than 1 finger) light brown head that dissipated rapidly and had fair lacing.

The aroma was quite robust with the scent of roasted caramel malts and a mild sweet yeast with hints of vanilla and coffee with a mild alcohol odor at the back end.

The taste was a malty creamy sweet with notes of coffee, caramel and was a tad woody at first and finished sweetly-bitter and had nice notes of coffee and vanilla with mild alcohol aftertaste. The flavor lingered for a little while which let one enjoy the sweet woody coffee taste just a little longer.

Mouthfeel was just a bit under full in body and slightly syrupy yet a little creamy in texture with a mild ticklish carbonation. 

Overall an absolutely fantastic Brown Ale that sits on the palate and lets one enjoy the complexity of it, without a heavy alcohol presence.

Bottle. Pours a dark bron with 2 finger head that quickly dissipated to a very thin head.  Licorice, vanilla, woody taste.  The malt and hops come through incredibly as it warms.  Alcohol mostly hidden.   Roasty goodness from Dogfish Head.
Bottle. Smells of oak cherry and wood. Darl back color with no head. Tastes sweet with a maltyuy stout and ipa aftertaste.  Theres a lot going on here gor a brown ale

Rusty, low visibility as carbs quick to return. Sticky legs.  Shook it a few times to maximize the cedar and molasses florals.  Easy up front  with a quick blast of nasal gases as it spreads out on the tongue.  Vannila-Cherry Coke has met up with tumeric-whiskey at their cool local bar.  Uniquely hidden tones.

Smell is sweet raisin, mollasses, cherry. From reading the description I assume I smell the Palo Santo as it is woody and just kinda similar to oak but not. Alcohol present. Very complex. Appearance is almost black with a hint of dark brown. Very small tan head. Syrupy pour. Taste is raisin, mollasses, coffee, chocolate, caramel, cherry, ashy. Definate tartness that goes well with strong syrupy sweeetness and roasty darkness. Pronounced woody flavor that I will again asume is the Palo Santo. Palate is thick and very complex. Hot and kinda harsh. This guy would really benefit from some aging. Overall an interesting beer. The wood is very different and I think what makes this beer unique. Overall, while this beer is nice, Im not in love with it as it is almost cloying and the alcohol is a little harsh. Again though, I think with age this would improve greatly.

I can absolutely understand why this wood is used in wine-making.  Thankfully, I like beer better than wine.  One could definitely anticipate the malty impact-the aroma is one of (dark) chocolately coffee (guess that would be mocha?).  lt is dark black with a tan frothy head, that sitcks around as long as you would like a good date to do so.  Nice lacing, which remains so you know you are drinking a good beer to the very last drop.  Very nice palate, though a bit too sharp?  Perhaps if it could be reduced by a few hundred bubbles, It would smooth out to the perfect palate for the beer.  Buuuuut, I wouldnt work too hard to try and change this for fear that it would overcorrect.  

I always get insecure in trying to describe the taste because there is so much too it...many of which I know I will miss.  I will at least give this generalization, its great!  A detailed bouquet of malty-ness.  Roasted coffee with a smooth dark-chocolately (but not too high cocoa content) intro.  It lingers on your tongue like a nice chocolate bar would!  

If it gets too warm, there is a slight after taste of "wet dog."  That sounds a whole lot worse than it is though.  It is still in my top 5 favorite beers.  Perhaps top 3 as whenever it is available, it is my preferred drink for the occasion.  Not to be a cop-out, but this is definitely one that must be reevaulated, because Ive finished the beer before I was able to formulate all of my descriptives for taste and aroma.
i really enjoyed this one very similar to an imperial stout and the abv of 12% is no wher eto be found.. malty and sum wood flavor  good beer

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown, almost black. No light coming through and a thin, light brown head that falls into a light wisp. Aroma is extremely oaky with lots of molasses and some dry fruit. Slight coffee and chocolate undertones as well. Taste is full of chocolate, coffee and some lingering dark fruits. Wood comes at the end palate. Mouthfeel is VERY rich and full with a sticky, chewy finish and slight burn from the alcohol.

Pours deep black with a creamy dark brown head.  Aroma of chocolate, earth, molasses, wood and a touch of smoke, cinnamon and raisin.  Flavor is earthy, wood, chocolate, dried fruit, alcohol, molasses.  Finish is almost wine-like, close to a dry, earthy red wine.  Quite an interesting, intense and flavorful brew.

12 oz. bottle- Pours black with a thin tan head, so so lacework, the aroma is licorice and molasses and possibly some kind of wood. The flavor is similar to an imperial stout, but different, it is less sweet than your typical imperial stout. I definitely taste some oaky flavors (or palo santo) and raisins and dark cherries. This is a very complex beer, the alcohol is very well hidden, its there, but not overbearing, much better than I was even expecting.

12 oz bottle into an Allagash chalice. Pours as opaque black as stout. Has a small collapsing dark tan head that leaves a rim of foam and some nice lace. Looks thick and chewy. Aroma is also very imperial stout-ish. Licorice and raisins are dominant. Baked bread comes out as it warms. Taste is bittersweet with a touch of sour. Tastes like an imperial stout, too. Palate is very thick and chewy; full-bodied; medium carbonation. A very flavorful and well-made beer.

Pours near black  with a dark tan foamy head.  Aroma reveals dark roasted malt.  Flavor is sweet like a belgian trippel.  You can really taste the alcohol content in this beer.  Interesting but I couldnt have more than one in a sitting.

Pour a black color with a brown lining and a small brown head.The aroma is of fruit, smoke wood, and light earthy notes to it.The flavor is of caramel, vanilla, and smoke wood.The body was and the aftertaste a nice bitter taste.Overall another good off center ale  for an off center guy like me.

12 oz bottle, poured into a snifter. Pours very dark brown/burgundy, with minimal head. Aroma of dark fruits (raisins and dates), very sweet malt, and smokey wood. Taste of vanilla, caramel, raisins and dates, brown sugar, and toasted wood. Very syrupy and smooth mouthfeel with minimal carbonation. Definitely a sipper, but very tasty.

Pours deep black in color with a thin tan head. Chocolate, alcohol, slight coffee and licorice notes in the aroma. Medium to full bodied with definite spice, wood and slight chocolate notes. Surprisingly drinkable and enjoyable when sipped over time. Finishes smooth with a slight dryness and light unsweetened cocoa.

Pours a nice dark chocolate hue with a tan head. Aroma a nice sweet smell hints of fruit. Taste is wonderful, nice carbonation hits you with a nice cherry like finish very small notes of alcohol . Medium body a very delicious beer. Highly recommended.

Nice floral aroma.  Dark brown almost black pour with thin brown head that leave quickly.  Light sweetness that continues throughout the beer.  A little alcohol flavor with some unknown flavors.  This is a very good beer.

Nose is sweet with dark chocolate, dark fruity, caramel, residual sugars, some roasted dryness, and earthy qualities as well. Black pour, khaki creamy head and some nice sheets of lace. Dark fruit, chocolate, caramel, notes of vanilla, earthy bitterness, wood almost like a cedar, and nice bitterness rounds out the finish. Dry and lightly spicy on the palate. Lingering almost black licorice flavor on the palate. Really interesting and enjoyabe.  Full bodied with a touch of heat but hides the 12% rather well. A very nice beer.
Black with a moderate tan head. Wine aroma, red wine & sweet.  Strong sweet malt flavor, fruit, caramel, wine flavors.   Heavy body, all flavors linger.  Very nice ale
Pours dark brown to black.  Notes of caramel, vanilla, malt, chocolate, alcohol and wood. Bitter finish.  Better than ok but not great.
reminds me of red wine and bbq beef ribs. Very strong, You can taste the wood for sure. Excellent beer.

Thanks Jordan (much appreciated).  Pours deep black, with a nice tan head.  Very reminiscent of the world wide aroma (as I just had one), with dark fruits, and malt.  Lots of coffee, with a very roasty finish.  Medium body, and foamy, but not as thick as world wide and warmer.  Very enjoyable beer. If you cant get your hands on a world wide, definitely grab this.

Pours black with a large, dark tan, lasting head.
Nose shows loads of sweet caramel and heavy roasted malt. Pretty complex with lots of liquorice, chocolate, coconut, vanilla and alcohol.
Flavours are pretty full-on with lots of sweet malt and alcohol vying for attention. Roasted malt, caramel and vanilla provide a bit of complexity. The alcohol is a bit too noticeable.
Slick body, the carbonation could be higher.

I bought the bottle at the brewery in October of 09 & its been in my cellar untouched since then... Pours a deep brown basically black with a small espresso swirl head and some small fleeting lace. The aroma is raisin and plum with a fair bit of booze in a rich almost wine like way, not like the cheap vodka booze aroma you get from many high gravity beers. This blends well with the whole bouquet and compliments the notes of vanilla and aged rum. The flavor is nutty and a bit spicy, quite a good bit like the spices in anchor Christmas ale (woody, zesty, potpourri like in a way) As the glass progresses dark fruits show up with some nice roastiness and a good bit of heavily toasted French oak. The palate seems a tad think for as big as the flavor/abv is. Really a very nice sipper.

Pours black with a small light brown head.  It has a sweet malty aroma with chocolate and alcohol.  The flavor has some dried fruits, alcohol, chocolate, and espresso flavor.  There is also a wood characteristic that follows through to the finish and lingers for a few.  Very full bodied and a another great beer from Dogfish!
Very impressive beer and highly drinkable considering the 12%. Maple syrup, vanilla and spiciness from the wood. Awsome.

June 2010 Bottling: Really interesting beer style. Would have picked as a young and fresh vintage port had it not been for the soft carbonation. Wonderful sweet smokey woods, rich red fruits and licorice from the not insignificant abv right across the nose and palate. Drank quite cold early, giving the beer some structure) but it fattened out considerably as it warmed up. Id give it a couple of years to settle. Strays into barley wine as a style.

Tasted from a 12 oz bottle purchased in Fort Collins, Colorado.  Deep brown/black body with a dark brown colored head that looks a lot like an Imperial Stout.  Intense dark malty aroma with a unique wood smell thats also pretty sweet.  Tingly mouthfeel and intense beer though alcohol isnt necessarily that obvious.  Big brown malty flavor with a very unique wood flavor.  Theres also a bit of chocolate and coffee in there.  Very full bodied, very unique, and a very interesting beer.

For me there is nothing like this beer.  Points for unique.  

Aroma is of, to me, a cedar tree.  I think shade in summer or the only scent in winter.  This must be the Palo Santo barrels.  Musty, dank, rich, roasty and sweet.

Appearance is stouty--black.  The alcohol is apparent in the pour.  Very little head.  

Taste is slightly sweet and slightly sour--overridden by earthy.  It evokes solitude, woods, and cold.  And theres a hint of bite from the alcohol.

Syrupy, sticky feel, but thin.  Tingles the tongue.  More oxidized than you might expect a beer that otherwise leaves a syrupy feel on the mouth.  The taste and feel linger long.

This is a unique beer.  Not for everyone.  Palo Santo presents a taste like no other.

Very dark brown pour with a perfectly sized, creamy brown head.  Aroma is of wood, vanilla, molasses and cherry.  Full bodied with great carbonation level.  This beer has a lot of roast flavors but they arent too bitter or distracting.  Definitely a bourbon/whiskeyish flavor with some currant, smoke, vanilla and caramel.  Finish is long, bitter and sticky on the palette.  Alcohol is there but not hot or distracting.  A great beer to sip on with full-bodied cigar I imagine.  Nice.
Pours dark brown with a large off white head. Aroma is of oak with some molasses notes. Taste is similar with some slight chocolate notes and a boozy feel.

Clear dark red-brown pour with a short, tan head which leaves minimal lace. Sweet vanilla, raisins, caramel, chocolate and licorice flavors in a medium-heavy body with light carbonation. Wood flavors are very subtle but decidedly superior to the ubiquitous oak. Finish is long and sweet with an alcohol warmth. Lovely sweet ASA, perfect as an after-dinner aperitif.

Wow, what a unique brew.  The pour is a dark, dark brown, nearly black with an aroma of roasted malts and sweet dark fruit.  The flavors of this complex beer are vanilla, roasted malts, wood, bourbon and dark chocolate.  At 12% this beer is a monster, but the layers of flavor hide the heat.  Very delicious.

pours black like coffee with a thin mocha head.  aroma has fig and loads of roasty malts...touch of chocolate, coffee, tobacco...notable alcohol.  flavor follows suit without the notable alcohol and is slightly sweeter than expected.  mouthfeel is somewhat thick and lively with a long roasty finish that highlights the woody flavors!  nice!
Very dark roasted beer. I was expecting more of a wood taste. Its got a lot of kick to it and very complex flavors. Will be drinking this beer as long as they produce it.
Quite a good dark strong ale.  Though not normally a fan of the style, I really enjoyed this one.  Recommended!

Pours dark brown with a very slight red tinge around the top of the glass. Big off-white head dominates the glass. Aroma is a lot of oak, molasses, roasted barley, and a tad of alcohol. Flavor is very dark, almost like an imperial stout but heavier on the oak notes and not nearly as much chocolate. Mouth feel is very viscus, but not in a bad way, with a slight alcohol burn the entire time.

12oz bottle pours a very dark beer that is almost black. Aroma is very sweet with srtong notes of dark sugars and fruits with a slight alcohol finish, Appearance is very suprising for being called a brown beer. Body is a very dark beer that is almost black, and a slight tan head that turns to just a ring around the edge of this beer. Taste is somewhat sweet with carmel and coffe notes that are well balanced with the sweetness. A slight alcohol finish rounds out this beer that is different but pleasing.

355mL bottle.  Pours oily black with a thin tan ring.  Trying to rate this on an empty stomach seems to have been a bit of a mistake.  Roasty aroma with some caramel, chocolate, vanilla and lots of alcohol.  Sweet and roasty with chocolate, some dark fruit, some wood and maybe smoke, lots of alcohol, mildly acidic.  Medium-full bodied, below average carbonation, slightly smooth creamy but with a bit of a carbonic bite.  Lingering alcoholic finish.

12oz Vegas bottle about 1yr old. Much darker than expected with a thin brown head and spotty lacing. Nice aroma that reminds me of a quad or Belgian strong ale. Very nice flavor of caramel, smoke and wood. The alcohol appears in the finish. Suprised this was not over the top. Nice

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2013 Blackish pour with a tan head and minimal lacing. Aroma of wood, chocolate, whiskey-like booze (though mild), vanilla, and smoke. Taste is sweet, roasty, and woody: whiskey-like, and the alcohol is evident thou not overly so. Some light fizzy carbonation and fairly full bodied. Solid; like a barrel aged stout on the thin side.

Original: 8 5 7 4 15 = 3.9
Dark pour. The aroma is similar to a stout, a roasted and earthy smell. The flavor contains roasted coffee and lots of chocolate. Alcohol not hidden. Lingering aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2011 Looks like a stout smells like a brown ale mixed with a scotch ale. Taste is a little sweet and too wine like. Not bad but Id rather have something more roasted and less like wine or whiskey.

A: Very, very dark with a medium brown colored head.

S: Lots going on here. Chocolate comes out as well as a lot of dark malts and their adjoining sweetness. The vanilla-type flavors from the wood definitely come in.

T: Similar to the smell, with hints of some dark fruits coming in here. Very, very complex and interesting. 

M: Very full-bodied and creamy.

D: Definitely one to sip. Glad Sam sort of went crazy with this one--it really worked out.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-27-2009
typical brown ale background, with a hint of smokiness. the wood flavor is perfumy and unique. could use a bit more sweetness for balance.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2011 Pours a very dark brown, looks black, and has a medium sized brown head. Smells of the wood it was aged in and of roasty, sweet malts. Tastes dry, almost sweet, and quite a bit woody. There is a faint alcohol smell and flavor that wraps up this beer. Full-bodied with an almost creamy texture and mild carbonation this brew finishes dry and long with a little bitterness. I drank it slowly.

Notes of vanilla, black licorice, alcohol in the nose.  Black appearance with a tan head that fades and dissipates quickly.  Alcohol is quite dominant in this beer, almost too much.  A good sipper for a cold night, but Im not sure I could have more than one of these in a sitting. Solid.

WOW. Intense earthy aroma with full malts, alcohol, coffee, chocolate. The pour is beautiful dark body with a finger or so of delicious looking frothy head. The beer is intense and strong with a large alcohol taste and burn. The vanilla, chocolate and soily flavours make this beer unforgetable.

Draft at the Euston Tap, London. Pours opaque black, with a dense, creamy, multi-shaded brown head. Strong malt nose, with vanilla, alcohol and wood. Very sweet flavor, rich, with heavy wood and booze notes, along with some caramel and toffee. Full in body with creamy carbonation and much warmth. Finishes sweet, with spicy wood notes, light, roasted peat and some lingering alcohol burn. Wonderful beer. Has great depth.

Bottle.  Pours a very dark brown (almost black) with a thin brown head.  Sweet aroma, notes of caramel.  Tastes very malty; notes of molasses, chocolate, coffee, toffee, some oak, and a little bit of an earthy bitterness - also very warming, very full-bodied.  Finishes with a warm woody taste, with bit of an earthy bitterness.  Very complex, lots of flavour here.  A very good brew!
This is an incredibly unique and complex brew.  Picked it up from the bottle and was blown away - its almost too much.  More of a single bottle kind of brew - too complex to be easily drank.

From a case that has been aged a year. Have had when fresher. The oak has tamed this Ale!!! Much easier to drink now without losing its maltiness. The alcohol is there, but not as pronounced. If you can age any bottles you have, Please do!!

Pours dark caramel with an aroma of molasses, alcohol, raisins and a hint of chocolate.  Its slightly creamy with light carbonation.  The flavor is chocolate, alcohol and spice. More bitter than sweet, but nice.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2010 Snifter draft at the brewpub in Rehoboth.  Drank at lunch as the first beer of the day.  Despite being 12%, goes down smooth.  Great flavor.  Recommended for later in the afternoon. Maybe for round 2!

Draught at the Euston Tap. Huge alcoholic bite, loads of liquorice, wood and old wine, black treacly notes, very heavy body - almost but not quite overly syrupy, very bitter liquorice aftertaste with just a weird hint of embrocation.

Bottle, 
has a dark brown-ruby pour, it is hard to see through this beer, even at the edges or the bottom of the glass, gave a small dark (chocolate shake)  colored head, left some spotty lacings as I drank, I think the alcohol may have washed off the lacings, no sediment in the bottle, 

I got various alcohol-liquor aromas right off, there were roasted malt, faint coffee, wood-brandy liquor fragrances with Wine and Port, 
this beer somewhat reminds me of a coffee alcohol Impy, there is a sweetness that resembles vanilla and brown sugar, 

there were flavors of liquor alcohol, roasted malt, some brown sugar sweetness, faint coffee, there is a little dark fruit and berry flavor but the alcohol seems to engulf or dilute these flavors, maybe some burnt dark fruit to, 
alcohol is evident on the palate, the alcohol grows a little as the beer warms, and the alcohol dries the tongue after the finish, 

mouth feel is a more than medium, carbonation is soft and stays that way, even as the beer warmed up to room temperature, gives some warmth on the mouth and throat with each sip, and gives a little tingle in the nostrils with some sips, 

this is a strong Winter Warmer sipping beer, I think this beer is better when cool (not cold) but gets a little too much on the alcohol side when it warms up, I found my self getting a little twinge when taking a sip, if you do not mind a lot of alcohol you may enjoy this drink.

It pours a crazy dark brown color with a tan head. It has a medium amount of carbonation.

The aroma is very nice. I am getting some strong vanilla,chocolate and a little woody notes

It has quite a bunch of stuff going on in the flavor. Some good vanilla,carmel,dark fruit, licorice, chocolate,coffee. Also there is some wood and a little smokiness. It has a pretty high abv so obviously there is a strong alcohol taste. Its pretty complex so you want to sit back and savor and enjoy this. Not something I think you would want to be drinking at a baseball game from a plastic cup.

It finishes with a slight bitterness and a strong alcohol presence that tends to linger around. One of the best I have had from Dogfish. But having said that not something you could make a session. Glad I bought a bunch of these to age and retry later. I have a feeling this is something you will have to try numerous times.

On Mini Cask at The Royal Oak, Wantage. Jet black with tan head. I feel totally unworthy about describing a beer like this, so its just my experience I am putting down. There is a massive roasty flavour kicking off at the start, liquorice, bitter coffee. The beer smooths in to a tarry note, quite heavy on the palate and distinct alcohol note. The palate was cornered then as there was no way I could taste anything else for an hour. Marellous experience, many thanks to Paul of The Royal Oak.

Bottle. Trade by Hopscotch. Pitch black pour with a creamy tan head. The aroma is heavy woody with spicy notes and lots of caramel and roasted malt. Light coffee and chocolate notes. The flavour is roast, tobacco, caramel, dark fruit, spices, vanilla and wood.
Fra flaske , dufter dejligt syrig træ,vanillie puder sukker,smagen er dejlig af syrlig træ vanillie og sukker dejlig fylde....en super dejlig american strong ale....

Bottle to glass.  Pours a dark, dark brown with a off yellow dense head.  Has a lot of fruity / woodsy.  You can taste the high alcohol.  Lots of malt flavors.  Pretty good, but I think I prefer a stout.

I had this beer a while back and from what I can remember I enjoyed it.  Ive had this at the pub/brewery so it was fresh.

Nothing special about it is popping into my head at the moment.

This is my first DFH beer, thanks to my cousin Kasper for picking up a bottle for me when he visited the states. Pours a really dark brown color (though it looks black, the brown color is revealed during the pouring) with a frothy tan head. Aroma is of vanilla, wood, roasted malt, dark fruit, liqourice and some sweet malty notes Flavor is really complex. During first sip it is very sweet and filled with vanilla notes. Then you get some dark fruit like raisins and figs, roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and wood which tastes quite unigue compared to e.g. oak aged beers (which is because of the palo santo brewing vessels its brewed in). Then some smoke, soy sauce, liqourice and some very faint alcohol. The body is full with a thick and oily mouthfeel,  the beer completly coats your mouth. Overall a fantastic beer! After having this i would LOVE to try more DFH beers, and luckyly my cousin also picked up a bottle of their World Wide Stout for me.

On tap at Maduro in Madison, WI, poured into a snifter, pours a deep black color with a nice tan head, the aroma is of chocolate, nuts, coffee with sweet malt, the flavor is intense with malt, chocolate and raisin, this is an experience!

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a nonic pint glass. Bottled on 06/21/10 printed on bottle.

Pours an extremely dark brown, almost black, color with a 1 finger creamy light brown head. Minimal lacing.

Smell: Dark fruit, chocolate, wood, alcohol and a light hint of something I can only explain as the smell of grocery store produce department.

Taste: Toasted malt up front followed by a complex mix of chocolate, dried fruit, spices, pepper, smoky oak and burnt toast in the middle and ending with caramel malt and alcohol. The alcohol is kind of similar to cheap vodka. The aftertaste is mostly dark chocolate.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied with a decent amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: Good drinkability. The alcohol isnt overwhelming, though you wouldnt want to drink too many considering the ABV.

Overall: This is a very good beer. Its not what I would consider a brown ale but Dogfish Head doesnt fit within typical categories most of the time anyway. I would recommend checking this out if you have the chance.

I picked this up at Archer Liquors in Chicago, IL, enjoyed on a random Thursday night.  This one is packing a punch.  Aroma of dark fruit, wood, cherries, and malt, definitely a lot going on with this one.  Appearance is pitch black with a thin tan head.  Taste is of alcohol, malt, dark fruits, molasses, and vanilla.  Theres definitely a lot going on and it tastes more like a stout than a brown ale.  Fantastic stuff though, definitely a sipper.

Pours black with thick brown head and foamy lacing.  Notes of roasted malt and raisins.  Taste is a bit strong and on the sweet side with an alcoholic tilt; takes some getting used to.  Smooth and creamy.  Careful; this stuff packs a punch.

Thick, dark brown pour, with a brown head. Aroma is hickory, whiskey, and alcohol, which makes sense since this is 12%! The flavor is more hickory smoke, alcohol and caramel. Mouthfeel is chewy, with a lot of smoke in the finish. Wow.

Nice deep brown pour with some tan head.

Aroma is sweet malts with a hint of vanilla. Flavor follows the nose closely - very very tasty.

Smooth and creamy - this is amazingly easy to drink considering the 12% ABV... you really dont even notice the alcohol.  Very very tasty.

Will definitely be drinking more of this.

Poured a black color.  hints of vanilla aroma.  Creamy head, bitter sweet taste.  Medium to full body, creamy/oily in the mouth.  Very complex taste, enjoyed the wood undertone.  Very noticeable alcohol flavors.  After taste bites you.  This is good to drink only occasionally.  But you have to try it because it is so unique.

330mL Bottle into snifter. Aromas: Coffe, leather, molasses, caramel, roasted malt, chocolate. Flavours: Intense mocha up-front which develops into a creamy caramel/oaky finish. Palate is very smooth. The 12% Alcohol is only detectable as a warming feeling on the way down. This is amazing beer. Concentrated, powerful and balanced flavours coupled with amazing mouthfeel. Avoids becoming flabby. YEAH!

Appearance:  tarry, syrupy pour the color of black licorice with a tan/reddish head.  Aroma:  strong malted caramel/molasses, vanilla, wood, bitter chocolate and an alcohol kick.  Taste:  bitter chocolate and caramel, with some sweet vanilla and warm wood notes; malty sweet toast; strong alcohol.  Finish:  long and dry, with hints of vanilla and bitter chocolate.  Notes:  A little too bitter, a little too rich, a little too much alcohol.  Definitely a sipper.  Like Old Engine Oil, but not as drinkable.  The finish is actually better than the taste.

As dark  brown and opaque as can be.  One finger mocha head shrinks quickly to a rim of foam around the too.  Aroma is toasted malts, caramel and vanilla bean, blackstrap molasses and some EtOH.  Mothfeel is very creamy, with all the elements of the nose also alerting the buds.  This is a bitter coffee bite, some wood tannins may be adding to the hops.  This is both very unique and enjoyable.

Looks good in the glass, dark brown body with tan head. Dark fruits and chocolate on the nose. Chocolate comes through moreso in the taste, don t really notice the alcohol cos the full flavour and body gets in the way.

Pours a dark brown with thick brown head. Aroma is smoked wood, malts, vanilla and brown sugar. Taste is very malty with the vanilla and wood coming through nicely. Nice mouthfeel with the sweetness lingering at the finish. Nice job Sam and DFH

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2011 im a bit torn on how to rate this. this is a unique beer, definitely worth trying. for what its trying to be, id say its probably worth at least a 4.0 rating. the low drinkability almost makes me want to give it a 3.0.. it has all the attributes of a great imperial stout: the looks, the smell.. + lots of wood, and an almost cabernet red wine-like finish.the red wine finish also borderlines on a cough medicine finish. it all may be a bit much for my tastes. the wood leaves my tongue numb, almost reminiscen Rt of cocaine numbies. very interesting beer. sipper. RE-RATE 6/11/11 -- much different than last time. More drinkable, less medicinal finish.
Woody, dense, deep , dark, flavors, strong aroma, strong, muscular body..................

Pours a deep ruby brown, almost black. Very little head. Aroma is chocolate, wood, and cherries. Taste is burnt, sweet chocolate. Medium body; clean finish. I really liked this one; will get this again.

Rich thick sweet aroma of rosepetals and vanilla. Jet black in the glass, thin crema head. Palate is rich and hot. Shows it,s 12% boldly like the stout Fat Controller. Flavours of sweet malt syrup with some choc malt notes. Finish is dry and then you get a second hot kick about 3 swallows later. Intense and amazing. Wood leaves a little sourness in the finish, this is one of the most unique beers Ive ever had.

Very dark brown, I guess. Big aroma of wood, lightly roasty and sourish chocolatey malts. Based on appearance and aroma, Im not sure I wouldnt have guessed this was an imperial stout. Flavor is where it stands apart some. Initially lightly sour, then a quite dusty and complex hay malt flavor. Some light soy notes as well, but really, Im amazed at how the dusty and hay/straw notes prevail here in the flavor. Almost nasally irritating. Very complex and unusual. Moderately bitter finish with some rough-hewn carbonation.

Tap at Church Key. Black, hints of brown, bubbly off-white head. Chocolate and roasted malts in the nose, with a cool alcohol nasal feel. Mouth is tasty, chocolate, plummy, vinous at times. Vanilla from oak. Alcohol burn strong at the end, and evident throughout. Good beer, but the alcohol dominates.

Pours a crazy oily dark brown almost black, no head, no carbonation. Aroma is tough to handle being overpowered by alcohol, this is the main fault of the beer. Other notes are roast malt and wood. Taste is dominated by roasted malt and caramel malts with some earthy woody essence in there as well. This is a thick syrupy beer, delightful for fall.
Bottled sample at kellehers in Peoria. Bit too much alcohol for my liking. A great strong ale
Pours a black body with a thin, light brown head. Sweet with chocolate, dark fruits, vanilla, and coffee. Mild alcohol burn. Good.

Bottle pour.  Black body with a tan head.  Aroma is sweet, malty, and nice.  Very nice smokiness goes along with it.  Flavor is nutty and smooth.  Im not usually a fan of malty beers, but this is different.  Its fantastic!

Pours a dark brown with a small head. The aroma is dark and rich. Chocolate coffee, wood, plum, smoke and leather. The flavor had chocolate, wood, licorice, plum, rasin, coconut, and leather. Really heavy and nice.

Bottle. Pours deep brown, like rich mahogany. Thin tan head, very spotty lacing. Still a sharp looking beer. Nose is woody, sweet, vanillin, rich and rather profound. Flavour is oaky and vanillin, notes of coffee, and chocolate, light tannin and caramel,  also smoke. Long and drying finish. Very nice.

Pours deep brown with a slight purplish hue on the edge.  Slight coffee-stain head that slips down to a ring around the dark pond.  Sweet aroma that packs malt up the nostrils, bringing caramel and a tinge of chocolate.  Almost nutty at first taste with a woody middle and nice, crisp finish.  It is tight in the mouth.  Dark bitterness like robust chocolate and the swallow of coffee hits and then mellows after a drink.  This is great beer.

12 oz bottle. Pours dark brown/almost black, completely impervious to light, with a small tan creamy head. Aroma is licorice, molasses and charred wood. Alcohol is also quite noticeable. Thick, heavy palate with a strong warming sensation in every sip. Soft/low carbonation. Flavor is rich with sweet, roasted malt made more interesting with a smoky, earthy quality. Flavors of wood are also present. This was a luscious, wonderful brew.

part of a mix a six from the local liquor store.  Pour is dark, almost black, in color with a solid brown head that has a decent lace.  I drank this right when i got home from work, before the Cincinnati @ NC State game (GO BEARCATS!) and it pretty much felt like I drank 6 beers, or 12 bud lights.  Taste is chocolate and is think and creamy.  Im glad i only got 1, because id be hungover as shit at work tomorrow if i didnt.

On tap @ The Cheeky Monk, but Im pretty sure it wont be there for long, so dont go there expecting to find it (but if its there, youd be wrong not to).  Dark plum in colour, almost black.  Tan frothy head.  Smells like oak and spicy hops, with a dose of soy sauce.  Tasted like wine-fermenting wood (hence the South American Palo Santo), and very roasty/earthy malts.  Chocolate is there too but only fleeting.  Quite sweet but also pretty boozy, yet a very creamy mouthfeel.  Bit of an oily finish, but I didnt mind.
Inky black with a coffee and cream colored head. Aromas of chocolate and burnt sugar; oily, bitter with a rich chocolate taste and a alcohol burn finish. An outstanding beer. Delicious.

Clear brown pour with a short, tan head which leaves no lace. Sweet vanilla, raisins, caramel, chocolate and licorice flavors in a medium-heavy body. Wood flavors are very subtle. Lovely sweet ASA, perfect as an after-dinner aperitif.

Poured from the tap with a deep, dark mahogany brown color but only a thin, creamy head. The aroma wasnt too pronounced, but I definitely smelled some of the sweetness and maybe a bit of nuttiness that youd expect from a high-octane brown ale, and only a faint whiff of earthy wood. 
The wonderfully unique woodsy sweetness is much more dominant in the flavor, though, but it isnt so potent as to overpower the other flavors. An underlying nuttiness comes through as well, along with a bit of chocolate and a hint of vanilla. Being fairly finely carbonated, this one has a silky texture and goes down much smoother than would be expected at 12% alcohol.

Brown ales hardly set tongues awagging; the style simply doesnt define itself on extremes.  But this one goes up to eleven.  For colour, its the darkest brown can be without turning black.  The head is off white and quickly lowing, leaving behind some protracted lacing.  On the nose the wood is first to impress.  It does share some of the vanilla qualities of the more commonly used oak, but the palo santo imparts a resinous cherry characteristic that seems particular to it.  The malts are of chocolate and burnt caramel, or toffee.  And then theres something of a fortified wine, a certain vinous element that puts me in mind of chewed grape seeds.  In the mouth the wood is fragrant and adds a bitterness to the malts.  Here the alcohol forms part of the taste profile rather than acting as heat alone.  Chocolate and tobacco round the flavour.  Its syrupy and sticky with a soft carbonation.  The wood develops on the finish to a strong cedar or pine and right at the end theres a nip of cracked black pepper.  Towards the bottom of the glass its like chewing down an old galleon - but as the man said: Its the wood that makes it good.

Its black, a lot of hype over the special wood ageing, but I dont think it makes that huge of a difference.  A deep rasin, molasses nose with some alcohol.  A smokey wood, even a little burnt, taste. a dry woody finish with some alcohol burn and a little wine, too. Its good stuff, but not that special.

Good heavens. Pours opaque black. Darker than many stouts. Has a permanent tan head, but almost no aroma to speak of. Tastes of malts, wood, and vanilla. A litle pinch of raisin, even. Want to buy many more.

Dark, opaque pour with a sweet, toffee bouquet.  The taste is full-bodied in terms of mouth feel and the warming tingle of alcohol is quite palpable in this malty, woody brew that smacks as well of caramel, chocolate and roasted malt.  The intensity is high and the finish is medium to long.  As reminiscent of an imperial stout as it is an American Strong Ale.  Im aging a couple of these.

Brandishing a bold dark deep ruby colour and bolstered by a firm dark tan lacy head, Dogfish Head have created a solid, respectable, and highly interesting beer (yet again). The smell on this thing is very nice with hints of cherry, chocolate, cocoa, and fig. The taste is complex and slightly boozy (it is a 12 percenter, after all)...yet the mouthfeel is not cloying or syrupy at all. Bourbon, whiskey, oak-aged berries, smoked lavender are just a few of the many waves of taste that I experienced as I drank this. Personally, Im gaga over any beer that opens to me as it warms up...thats why me and Palo Santo Marron are going fishing together this weekend!

Wow! Huge aroma, I cant even come close to picking out all the flavours. This is a 2008 bottle I believe. Extremely smooth beer, a light sweetness, very full bodied. Perfectly balanced, woody, and with plenty of flavours I have never tasted in any other beer before. This is phenomenal, pick one up to split with a friend and you wont regret it for a second!

They call this brown ale. After pouring a glass it seems more appropriate to label as black ale, this thing is dark as any stout would be. Unlike a stout though, my pour produces only the smallest heads that I have to watch quickly dissipate. The aroma is quite strong from the get go. Featuring sweet roasted malts, figs, burnt coffee and intensified by an elegant wood aging scent. The flavor profile is constructed from the Palo Santo wood the beer aged in. Vanilla and caramel notes come off the wood giving way to a dynamic roasted malt concoction. Its bitter sweet and plays off lots of dark burnt malts. The body is silky smooth and juicy. The 12% ABV is hidden pretty well at first, but comes through more pronounced as it warms displaying a brandy like quality to the flavor. Overall, I found this beer to be a delicate sipper, one that needs to be slowly enjoyed to get the full range of flavors. The Paraguayan wood adds an interesting twist to a brown ale displaying a complexity of different flavors. Dogfish Head are so good at taking a normal beer and adding a unique element to give the beer more life, character, and meaning behind it. I would love another of these, particularly one that is several years old.

Pours black, small and quickly dissipating head. Aroma is roasted malt and alcohol. Heavy palate, nice carbonation. Sticky mouthfeel, surprisingly sweet, with a good balance of hops that dont show up until well into the finish. A very nice brew.

(12 oz bottle) Pours nearly black with 1/2" tan head-pillowy on top.  Aroma of booze, cherries, and wood.  Taste is dry roasted/bitter with some sweetness peeking in.  The wood is evident in the dryness that it imparts.  Full bodied with creamy and thick texture.  The finish is dry and roasty with some bitterness joining in.  This is a very big beer.  I thought Id had this before, but I would have remembered this one.  My initial thoughts, as it was still fairly cold, was that it is too dry-as I find many oaked beers to be-however, as it warms, the beers sweetness comes out and really balances things out.  As usual, DFH is able to take unusual ingredients and infuse them into the beer for an extraordinary complex and sometime subtle flavor.

Had this gem courtesy again of Jim at a great concert. Aroma of dried fruit and chocolately nuttiness was pulling my nose into the bottle...yes, beer snobs, I drank this straight from the bottle. Put your stones down, I was at a concert and if a great friend is gonna offer me a great beer, and I happen to lack the proper glassware, then Ill just have to "suffer" and drink it as it comes. All kinds of flavor happening in this one, trailmix, smores and campfire come to mind. Would have had more than the two I drank but I wanted to make it home alive. Will definitely revisit this one.
Another delicious smelling beer from dogfish head, with a taste to match.  I aquired a case of this on my last birthday and decided to finally rate this great beer.
The nose on this beer is amazing vanilla, chocolate, caramel, and frankincense.  Big complex malty flavor seemingly changing with each sip.

12 oz bottle. Wow what a beer! Its like drinking a chocolate raisin bar. Thick beyond belief with a brown head lacing the glass as you drink. Very VERY good offering from DFH and another entry into the always different American Strong Ale category. Wow is all I really can say to this one.

Bottled. The aroma has some chocolate, raisins, caramel, roast. Dark brown coloured beer with an off-white head. The taste is sweet, has raisins, prunes, nuts and a hint of choclate. Well bodied beer. Nice one.
Bottle @ kloneo. Black colour, small off-white head. Aroam is roasted malts, coffee, dark fruits, prunes. Flavour is roasted malts, coffee and prunes. Nice stuff.
black color with moderate head, couldnt help but notice the high alcohol, granted very rich and flavorful but ovepowering to me
(bottle)  A gift from Keg_Juggler.  This is like Heavy Metal music in a bottle. Intense vanilla aftertaste.  Noticeable alcohol.  A bit too intense unless used after dinner. Similar to a port.

Looks great with a black color and thin tan head and spotty lacing. Burnt aroma and you can smell hint of alcohol. I can taste the vanilla in the aftertaste. You can taste the alcohol, but I like the flavor a lot. A lot of body to this beer.
Black colored brew. Coffee and chocolate in the aroma. Flavor has coffee, chocolate, dried fruits, raisins, a bit boozy.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12oz bottle into a tulip glass. 

Appearance: It has an almost opaque dark brown body with lighter chestnut highlights near the edges of the glass. The pour is deep, dark and thick, making a small light brown head to sit on top. This head fades out quickly however and leaves a thin ring of tan foam lace. A quick swirl gives it a wispy thin film covering and slick lace. 

Smell: The aroma has toasted bready malt, roasted grain, sweet brown sugar and molasses. This gives it a sweet overall character but there is also some fresh cut pine, resin, hops, dark wood and leathery notes. Its alcohol is noticeable as well. 

Taste/Palate: There is a lot of complexity here in this big full bodied beer. There are sweet notes of brown sugar, vanilla, molasses, raisons, and prunes. This is balanced with some floral/woody notes, pine resin, leafy hops and dark hard wood. It also has notes of toasted bread, roasted grain and warm alcohol that give it a bit of bite. This all comes on a heavy, slightly viscous texture with smooth carbonation. 

Notes: Its big and complex with a bit of bite, which should mellow nicely with age. This is a big winner in my book.

Dark stout-ish appearance, good charred foamy head. Sweet malty fruit aroma. Not too heavy on the palate for a beer of this intensity. Noticeable charred/smoky flavors and alcohol. Heavy hop in the finish. This is a decent hefty beer; surpirsed to see it as a brown ale when it plays more like an imperial stout. Impressive but could have used a little more subtlety or style in certain areas.

12 Oz, Pours an oily deep black brown with small head that subsides quickly leaving good lacing. Aroma of strong ripe fruits, and alcohol. Taste is strongl wine like sweetness sweet with slight warming taste of alcohol. Full bodied but not too rough on the palate, high alcohol is well hidden.  Excellent!!
Very dark with a dark brown head, has very roasty flavors and aromas backed with a subtle, sweet oaky flavor with plenty of alcohol.

Pours a thick, viscous dark brown-black.  Aroma is enticing, dark, stout-like malt background, dry and earthy with a sweet, raiseny belgian-like background.  Taste is initially sharp, tangy and strong dark malts, an unsualy background taste, almost like soy, plenty of dark fruits, a distinct spiciness and oaky sweet background. The finish is dry, spicy and quite alcoholic finish.  Complex and interesting, slightly reminds me of pannepot.

Bottle. Bottled on 6/21/10. Pours a DARK brown alomost black color into my tulip glass. This has got to be the darkest brown ale I have ever seen. Very slight dark tan head. Big roast notes coming from this one. Big whiffs do burn the nostrils a bit with the booze. Much smoother in the taste than I would have thought after the aroma. Notes of coffee and dark chocolate come to mind. Alomost an iron taste to it as well, not sure where that is coming from. Woody and earthy too. The alocohol is surpisingly not that noticeable in the taste. This could be an IRS judging by the looks, so dark with a slight head. The wood flavor becomes more apparent as this warms a bit and tastes like a mix of oak and very subdued cedar. Very much a sipper type of beer. Medium/Heavy mouthfeel.

12 oz bottle, 12%abv, Pours extremely dark brown with a slight quick head.  Aroma is roasted malts, wood some chocolate with a slight dried fruit smell.  Very rich malt with wood and sweetness coming through.  nicely balanced and doesnt over power you with booze.  Will have to have it again.

I tasted this beer for the first time last night and was completely captivated until the last drop. I poured the beer, as I do most beers of this character, into a wine glass meant for Barolo. Although I knew this was a brown ale, I was taken aback by just how opaque this beer actually was. Only mildly carbonated, the beer had a thin, brown head that dissipated after a few minutes.

On the nose, this beer was massive, intense and complex. I got tons of near-burnt toast, a bit of vanilla, caramel and dried dates (think a rich brown ale with a bit of Amarone della Valpolicella in it) along with the typical coffee notes you get in beers brewed with roasted barley.

This beer had an amazingly rich mouthfeel and definitely had a sweet character to it, though never going out of balance. The ageing on Palo Santo wood no doubt helped to add richness, depth and that vanilla character to the beer. There was also a slight nutty aspect on the finish that was simply gorgeous. Had I brewed this beer, I would have dry-hopped it more: Im glad I didnt brew it. To me, this beer was absolutely perfect and, even though Im just back from a month-long micro-brew binge in the US, it was one of the best things Ive tasted in a very long time.

This beer held the high alcohol like a champ and there was no burning sensation, nor did it taste overly alcoholic. Dogfish Head have shown once again that they can brew very high gravity beers while managing to hide the alcohol under layer after layer of rich deliciousness - (certain Belgian brewers should take note).

6.25 is no small price for a bottle of beer, but if this were a wine it would be in the 40-60 range without a doubt. As such, this is a definite buy. Bravo!

Dark pour black with a tan creamy head decent lacing...  great looking beer aroma of vanilla, oaky and some dark fruits..... very rich taste of caramel and roasted malts, dark fruits, light chocolate molasses, nutty and a vanilla oak touch with a bitter warming finish..... a complex and pretty thick brew ...... loved every sip of it an awesome brew

Pours a opaque black with little to no dark caramel head. Smells like chocolate, roasted malts, wood and booze. Taste of chocolate and roasted malts with a grainy, woody boozy finish. Leaves a bitter aftertaste that lingers on the tongue. This is definately a sipping beer.

[355ml bottle, Beers of Europe, Kings Lynn] Pours extremely dark, like a glass of soy sauce. Very little light comes through it. Heavy alcohol aromas, with plenty of wood and liquorice on the nose. On the palate the first hit is syrupy sweetness, not really caramel but a confectionary sweetness. As the flavours progress the alcohol comes to the forefront akin to a sweet sherry. Quite well balanced, hints of desert wine on the aftertaste which has that rising sweetness. Interesting stuff. [03/06/2010]

Aroma is mineral, soy, chocolate, cocoa, wood, lots more soy, some maple-ish alcohol, and a slight sourness.  Wow!
Pour is a low carb, ominous rich mahogany.
Taste is absolutely beautiful.  Rich dark malts, caramel, soy, mineral, cocoa powder, light, astringent bitterness, roast, wood, and a bit of alcohol.
Wow!  Insanely complex and well integrated.
Finish is slightly bitter, roasted malts, cocoa, and an astringency from the oak. 
Incredible beer.

Bottle. Pour is black-brown with a quick kahki head. Aroma is booze and malt with hints of rasins and prunes. Taste is is booze upfront with dried fruit and malt. Palate is sticky feel which finishes dry. This is good in small amounts and probably will get better after time.

Served in a trappist glass.  Pours an opaque, dark brown, with a thin tan head that dissipates relatively quickly.  Copious amounts of lacing remain behind, however.  Aroma is dense, but alcohol absolutely dominates.  Lets be clear, however, the alcohol is not indiscriminate; rather, it is strongly characteristic of brandy or cognac.  Beyond that, some toasted caramel malts are barely discernible.  Flavor is, again, driven by alcohol.  But as the beer warms, other flavors become more apparent, including some sweetness associated with burnt sugar and vanilla.  Mouthfeel is somewhat thick, but not overly viscous, with a mild hint of carbonation.  

In all, this is one of Dogfish Heads finest ales.  Its absolutely strong, but imminently drinkable.  The alcohol is definitely front and center, and yet, other aromas and flavors (esp. caramel, sugar, vanilla, and even a slight smoked wood) are able to come forth, ensuring that a balance remains.  Strongly recommended.

Poured black with a dark tan head.  Smokey wooden aroma with cherries, dark fruit, and caramel malts.  Full bodied and full of smokey flavors.  Dark fruits, caramel malts, vanilla, coffee.  Very well balanced, the flavors blend together really well.  Slightly sweet throughout.  Alcohol is hidden relatively well.  Finish is mostly dark fruit and wood flavors.  Very unique and tasty.

355ml bottle.  Pours extremely dark brown with a light brown head.  Aroma is vanilla, wood, caramel and alcohol.  Taste is vanilla, some smoke, malt and alcohol.  Very thick in the mouth with a good level of carbonation

as usual DH makes another crazy beer. its scary to pour, like oil almost. aroma is heavy on the alcohol. taste is hard to describe, like a belgian crossed with a nut brown. burns with a strong alcohol flavor, which honestly is the only thing i dont like. i know "extreme" beers are supposed to have a lot of alcohol, but it would be nice if the flavors would be allowed to come through without all the burn. still, a unique beer in a world full of dull brews.

Appearance - Brown head with a very dark unfiltered body. Barely any light get through, some mahogany at the edges

Aroma - Alcohol, raisons and other dark fruits, bit of wood and smoke, sweet roasted malts, some molasses as well.

Taste - I get a bit of alcohol burn up front, followed by the dark fruits and some smokiness. Mid way through the sweet malts take over with some roasted malt and molasses notes. The finish has chocolate, some vanilla and caramel as mentioned on the bottle with enough bitterness from the hops to keep it from being too sweet. No alcohol burn on the mostly dry finish that leaves a bit of a chocolate caramel coffee flavor.

An unbelievably complex yet drinkable brown ale, Palo Santo Marron takes the standard brown ale in a completely new and different direction. It makes a fantastic desert beer or night cap.

I received this in a "sampler 6-pack" so I only had this one,,, but WOW! It was poured into a broad-mouth Coca-cola fountain glass. It pours an opaque, rich, dark brown with a thin tan head. The very pleasant aroma that smelled like sandalwood. The taste was immediately thick and luxurious, with a complex flavor of caramel and maybe a hint of vanilla, but not sweet. Very neutral in that regard. A full body with extremely thick texture, yet creamy. There is no hint of the alcohol in the taste, aroma, or finish. This is a very complex and satisfying ale. So creamy and satisfying that it could be used as an after dinner drink. I got to get more!

Caramel, roasted malts, oak, slightly alcohol aroma... Dark brown in color with tan head... Flavor is oak, scotch, caramel, tobacco, and toffee.... Maybe some vanilla... Vanilla and oak on the finish... Maybe some scotch too... Great beer, super complex

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Glossy pitch with a filthy mocha head becoming a halo. Bludgeoning high alcohol aroma; brandy drizzled on bonfire cinders and Neopolitan ice cream. Tongue-numbing alcohol and burnt wood; big burn and carbon without the expected malt softness to cushion it; a displaced synthetic berry/Red Bull note like that weird BrewDog beer with kola nut and guarana; Benylin Chesty Cough hints, apple and cranberry juice deep beneath the roast and burn. Too hot by half. Some decent charred, high cocoa impy notes , but in the context of the DH beers Ive had before, I was just expecting....more.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2013 Paid $3.75 for single 12oz bottle - One of the most unique beers I have tried in a very longtime.  The palo santo wood refuses to be ignored in this malty monster.  Heavy caramel and roast and a host of other flavors: its complex.  Im digging this.  Alcohol comes through as well, but is pleasant and anticipated.  Syrupy on the palate and a little thick.  Overall: Happy I tried this one, but would never try to consume two in the same session.  
***re-rate more than three years later*** Damn, I want to enjoy this, but a little unbalanced.  I think I tricked myself into liking this 3  years ago when in fact this beer becomes too big for its style.  I have to say, a commendable experiment.
A brown ale that looked like a stout, beautiful aromas, lots of roasted notes....and then too sweet.  Wood, cherry, alcohol....and sweet.  Too sweet.  I couldnt get past it.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2010 Served at 51F from bottle.  Smells very sweet.  Fruits and vanilla.  Also a woody aroma.  Pours dark, almost black with a slight amber hue w/ very little head to speak of.  Solid mouthfeel.  Can definitely taste the wood.  Stronger than I expected.   Really cant get past the woody taste. The alcohol does show at 12% - big beer.  Almost a dry, pulp-like feeling left in my mouth after swallowing.   Not into that feel.  Overall, different, but not my favorite and nowhere close.
Lovely tasting brew.  Pours out dark brown with a thin brownish head with a sweet woody taste.  Very Good Stuff..

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2013 Is this still beer?  very interesting drink;  complex aroma - wood, vanilla, alcohol/bourbon?  Pour was black with no head.  Taste was also complex; no way to hide 12% alcohol, but they made it work.  Again, not sure this is beer, but it was good to sip on and I enjoyed

Appearance - This beer poured a dark amber with a tan head that dissapates quickly. Lacing is present throughout.

Smell - Nice smells of chocolate and cedar.

Taste- The taste is of sweet malt and smoky wood. Nice dark fruit taste as well.

Mouthfeel - Thick beer with medium carbonation.

Overall- Great beer. Very interesting beer. DFH does a great job with this one.

Bottled 355ml. It pours a very dark beer with ruby reflects and a nicely remainig small lacing beige head. Raspberry and ginger components are rather prominent in the nose. Sweet, vinous with notes of raspberry and vanilla throughout. Full bodied. Smooth. Decent bitterness to balance the sweetness out. Remarkably fruity and extremely pleasant. Medicinal in a pleasant way. Wonderful long finish (with very little residual sugars) which is reminiscent of demerara, vanilla, tobacco and blackberries. Excellent.

Bottle from Ritzkiss, thanks man. Very dark brown pour with a thin brown head. Heavy malty aroma, chocolate something floral (lavender I think), something leafy woody too, must be the palo santo wood. Taste is quite roasty and woody, lots of winey, vanilla, cherry and toffee flavors. Palate is rather heavy, low carbonation, quite a bit of alcohol heat, not the best but OK considering this beer is a wood aged, high ABV monster. Definately one of the good DFH in my experience.

Aroma is roasted malt, some coffee, hints of smoke and wood.Taste is really smooth for a 12% beer. Flavor is sweet with a ton of malt up front,  vanilla and cherry flavors. Nice sweetness hiding the alcohol with big malts, vanilla, and a mellow warm finish. Tasty and subdued.

Black body with tannish head.  Aroma is rather sweet, kind of caramel sweet.  A bit of alcohol and dried fruit in the nose as well.  Flavor is chocolate sweet with wood and licorice notes with a biting boozy finish that I for some reason kind of like today.  An interesting beer to say the least.

Draught. Smells of molasses and alcohol.is a very dark color with a brown head. Not what is expected of a brown ale but still a nice appearance. Body is very creamy with a sweet taste. Alcohol is very psresent in the taste! Aftertaste is sweet and creamy.
