Chocolate and molasses nose with cherry and dark fruit notes. The taste is very sweet, lightly bitter (the DFH recipe for success!), theres a ton a raw wood, its like chewing on a table or chair leg, some chocolate and prune juice to help wash down the chair leg dinner.

Nitro tap at Manderes.  Mahogany brown color with a surprisingly big brown head.  Incredible nose.  Huge with chocolate, coffee, burnt wood.  Flavor is roasty and fruity, reminiscent of a big Cabernet as much as a brandy.  Excellent mouthfeel.  Like brushing your teeth with motor oil!  Great beer.  Much preferred to the CO2 version.

Love this beer, my favorite brown ale of all time. The Paraguain wood barrells make all the difference. The woody taste is evident at the tip of the tongue, but the aroma is more noticeable than the tongue senses. not overly hoppy, and the slight raisin undertones are nice. The east india brown ale was my favorite brown until i tried this.

Wow what a nose..Vanilla, raspberry, gingerbread and lots of alcohol. Quite thick pour too. In the mouth its a bit thin and the flavours just dont jump out like the nose. Woody, residual sugars and dark fruit though they are a little muted. Alcohol is quite noticeable. Will age my other bottle for a year or two, as this could develop in to something very special.
Not my cup of tea but a good beer no matter how you dice it.  A bit too sweet and packs too much of a punch.  True to Dogfish Head style...

Bottle. Pours jet black with a decent size tan coloured head. Head hangs around for a while but leaves minimal lacing. Aroma is dominated by malt aromas including dark caramel, choclate and a little toffee. Plenty of alcohol and vanilla there also. Flavour is super sweet thanks to all that malt. Lots of alcohol burn near the finish. Mouthfeel is very full and syrupy. Not really to my taste but a good beer all the same.

355ml bottle 
12.0% ABV 
I tried this beer on June 18, 2010 at "The Beerbistro" in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a very dark brown with a thick light brown bubbly head.  The aroma was roasted malt, coffee, and molasses.  The mouthfeel was medium bodied with medium carbonation.  The flavour was sweet, but not too sweet, lots of roasted malt, some chocolate, and a bitter finish.  A great beer.

Had out of the 12oz bottle from warehouse wines. Pours a dark brown with a light brown head. Aroma is vanilla, wood, with a faint caramel smell. The alcohol hits you first, vanilla and cocoa notes are present. caramel with a woody aftertaste. There was too much of a alcoholic bite at the end for me though. Medium mouthfeel with a good warming ability. Pretty decent beer from Dogfish.
UPDATED: AUG 2, 2011 Wow. High alcahol hidden by great flavor. Caramel, chocolate, roasty, brew. My favorite. Always have some on hand

Medium head thick type of drink very dark aromas caramel chocolate vanilla slight nuttiness liccorice flavour pine note caramel is well brought out vanilla liccorice such a good tasting ale alcohol well hidden finish good malt tastes a mild bitter a rewarding aftertaste so good

12oz bottle.  Pours a dark reddish brown body with a dark tan head that left a bit of lacing.  Aroma is alcohol, some vanilla, "woody" and just a bit of carmel.  Flavor is oddly metallic (at first), medium sweet, caramel, wood and licorice.  Medium mouthfeel.  After the beer warms up, that metallic flavor goes away and things smooth out quite nicely.  Very complex and deserving of more space in the fridge.

Poured into a pint glass.

A: Very dark brown, almost black. Little to no head. Appears full bodied. 

S: Woody and sappy. Hint of coffee. Smell rather weak, but pleasant.

T: Extremely malty. Wood really comes through. Toffee to a lesser extent. Liquor aftertaste, though complements woodiness.

M: A little thinner than I expected. Nonetheless, feels good.

D: One bottle was plenty, but I wouldnt have wanted any less. Very good sipper.

Serving type: bottle

Bottle.  Pours dark brown with a short-lived head.  Nose is caramel, vanilla, rubbing alcohol, spice, some dark malts.  Smooth and medium-bodied, sweet, alcohol, vanilla, caramel, wood, nice dark malts.  Long warming finish, slightly bitter, caramel.  This is another one that grew on me throughout the glass.  Really enjoying it towards the end.

Black with very thin tan head, slight oily look to it.  Medium whiskey/bourbon nose and similar flavor, mostly bourbon, wood notes, and slight alcohol, grains not really noticeable.  Nice, not strong for a 12%.

This is the definition of a malt bomb.  One of the most malt forward beers I have tried.  Pours super dark and syrupy.  Aroma is dominated by roasted malts, some caramel and coffee.  First sip is somewhat sweet but not too sweet with a nice bitter finish.  A different take on a style I am usually not too fond of, bit this one is quite good.

Bottle. Very dark brown, almost black pour with a short-lived bubbly tan head. Aroma is quite roasty, with notes of caramel, coffee, vanilla, wood and iodine plus a hint of dark fruit in the background. Flavour is pretty similar except for the raisins, dates and other dark fruit that are a lot more prominent here than in the aroma. Mouthfeel is moderately thick and oily, with fairly low carbonation and a lingering roasty, woody, bittersweet finish. This is a fantastic strong ale; complex, well balanced, delicious and woody!

12oz., bottled 04/20/2010.  Pours more black than brown with some ruby highlights and a minimal darker tan head.  Aroma is woody, with spice, molasses, and some vanilla and bittersweet chocolate.  Flavor is more spicy wood, chocolate and molasses.  The ABV was well hidden, and overall this was more interesting than I was expecting.

355ml bottle, 14C. Black with a bare coat of tan head. Roasted malt and molasses under heaps of spiced wood. There are notes of wine barrels, cocoa, vanilla, cinnamon, licorice, hot ginger, mace - but its all quite together. The taste is quite sweet: lots of chocolate with accents of coffee and sweet-shop spices. Significant alcohol burn at the finish to go with complex sweet-shop spice/ herbal wood flavours. Reminded me a fair bit of Islay malt whisky. Intense and complex but still open - its not a crushingly loud beer and although the mix of flavours is unusual, they dont fight each other. Really good, but after a hundred mls or so Id had enough.

12 ounce bottle, bottled on 2/11/2008.  Served in a nonic pint glass, the beer pours dark brown with about an inch tan head.  Head retention is decent, but with a good amount of lacing left on the glass.  Aroma is very malty, it smells like vanilla, wood, molasses, roasted malt and some caramel.  Taste is pretty much the same as the aroma, but theres also some licorice and a nutty flavor noticable too.  Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, its creamy and a bit coating with moderate carbonation.  Drinkability is pretty good too, its very smooth and enjoyable to drink.  I dont think the 12% ABV is very noticable at all.  After 2 years, I think this is just as good as the first time I tried it.  Aging it certainly hasnt hurt this beer!  Dogfish Head has done a great job with this brew!
sample from crown-a cloudy brown pour-tan head-aroma and taste of caramel, roasty, woody, sweet molasses-super sweet wood finish
Almost black color with no head.  Pours viscous with aroma of vanilla, wood, caramel, and a hint of roasted malts.  Big flavor!  Vanilla, roasted malts, and wood dominate the taste.  Impressive beer!

A dark muddy brown color pour with a small soapy tan head , short lasting , leaving loads of lacing all the way down the glass , lively carbonation . Aroma is malty and sweet , caramel , wood ,toasted nuts , brown sugar , spicy hops and a hint of alcohol . Flavor is big and malty , lots of caramel,toffee and earthy roasty nutts , just enough of the wood coming through , light smoke , vanilla and alcohol notes with a nice warming effect . Full body with a creamy smooth mouthfeel , slightly boozy finish . An all around great brew very drinkable and enjoyable , nice work DFH .

On tap at the Rehoboth Beach Brewpub. Dark brown with a thick tan head. Sweet smells of vanilla and alcohol hit you first. My first impression was that it smelled like bourbon or spiced rum. It tastes like it smells at the beginning, but the sweetness of the vanilla flavors become more dominant as you drink more of it. If youve been on the DFH tour and had the chance to smell the Palo Santo wood, you can easily see where the aroma and taste come from.

Served from tap into standard pint.  Poured a dark dark brown (almost black) with a one-finger off-white head.  Maintained decent lacing throughout.  The aroma contained a nutty hint with malt notes as well.  The flavor of this one was malty, nutty, and sweet.  This brew was medium on the palate with low carbonation.  Overall this was a nice stout with a nice welcomed sweet flavoring.  Very nice stout and was not aware of the ABV until checking here on the site.

On tap at the Sunset Grill in Boston. Dark brown color with nice tan head. Malty sweet, brown sugar aroma. Toasted malt, sugar, vanilla and wood flavors. Alcohol warming but not overpowering. Thick, full bodied viscosity. Nice lingering aftertaste.

Pours black, small and quickly dissipating head.  Aroma is roasty, alcohol, and some woody tones.  Heavy palate, nice carbonation.  Sticky mouthfeel, surprisingly sweet, with a good balance of hops that dont show up until well into the finish. A very nice brew, though a bit one dimensional in flavor.

Pours reddish black, with a tiny brown head that dissipates quickly.  My nose detects many scents, dark fruit, molasses, and a few other things Im not sure about. This is a THICK beer, Im practically chewing it, which isnt such a bad thing. Lots of flavors present, its got a vanilla/wooden taste to it with hints of caramel, and a kick of alcohol at the end. A great beer.

No head on test subject this time, but ah, the more that can meet my nostrils! Superb mollasses and boozy nose. You get the wood as well. Maybe I should have dated black girls, cause I sure like the dark beers...and this one is a beautiful dark brown. Malty to the core, with alcohol, wood, molasses, and a slightly bitter oily finish. Great beer! tasted from the bottle @ 55°F. I realize this is a bit cold, but I just couldnt wait. LOVE THIS BEER!

12 oz bottle . . Ill be honest, I figured I would find a love/hate vibe when it comes to the reviews on this beer . . honestly, it is somewhat sweet, but you have to applaud Dogfish Heads unique approach with this one . . I really enjoyed the flavor of this beer, a lot.  That being said, I believe it is extremely overpriced but a very delicious occasional beer.

Brown color is actually deep red when held to a light. Small tan gray head forms in a ring and stays that way for the duration. Nose is sweet w/ raisins and red wine w/ a bit of roasted character in the background. Some chocolate and more varied dark fruit notes come out once tasted. A bit sticky and thick but w/ some slightly overzealous carbonation that contrasts oddly. This doesnt finish well, leaving a medicinal, slightly sour old coffee bitterness lingering on the tongue. I could see where there is a good beer in here somewhat if there were some minor adjustments made but this is about one more flavor flaw away from a drain pour as it is.
Jet black pour from bottle.  Has a port like nose, with a woody taste backed-up by sherry, black licorice and smoke.  Mild alcohol kick to the finish.  Decent.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2011 This is a revision of my rating of the bottled version from 2010-05-08. On tap at the brewery, served in a tasting glass. Pours very dark chestnut with a small tan head. The head fades slowly to a thin remnant and leaves a small amount of dense lace on the glass. On the nose, there are strong notes of wood, coffee and molasses, along with whisky, vanilla, earth and a hint of peat. The flavour starts out moderately sweet with molasses and a touch of bitter coffee. There is a hint of herbal hops for balance. The finish is long and roasty, with coffee and lots of hops. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, creamy-oily texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a beautiful, woody strong brown ale with plenty of roasty notes. It has a beautiful aroma and a delightful malty complexity with lots of vanilla. The Palo Santo wood takes the aroma to a whole new level. An amazing experience. 2011-05-10
The biggest weakness of the beer is the high abv. The sweetness masks the good wood flavor I was hoping for leaving just the malty sweetness. Still a good beer though

Bottle, 12 fl.oz. Pours somewhat like treacle, with a similar consistency, though darker. Tan head quicky dissipates, but reappears to sit smugly atop as the beer warms up a little. Aroma of smoked malts, molasses and bourbon. Very sweet on the palate, of caramel, vanilla essence and more bourbon, but with a fairly marked bitterness in the tail. A decent ale that would grow on me, but definitely not a session beer.

Is Dogfish Head running a candy shop? This beer was also AWFUL. What is up with the reviewers on this site liking things that are so sweet as to be sweeter than a trifle? Pours dark brown. Nice yellowish brown lacey head. Aroma is nutty and alcoholic. Taste. Well lets just say people at Dogfish Head are clearly into unbelievably sweet beer. Starts like maple syrup with attendant texture. Finishes with a harsh alcoholic bite. Might as well drink maple syrup mixed with Everclear. Awful. Just awful. Any rater that tells me this tastes good will be on my ignore list.

Bottle.

A - Very dark brown, almost black, with ruby brown hues on the edges. Large, thick, frothy, and creamy light sandy beige head with very good retention and a good sized layer of creamy sticky lacing left.

S - This is definitely interesting to smell as it as a number of aromas, some I dont know really what they are. There is a good amount of dark malt smell with caramel and molasses in there and hints of smokiness. There is also some overriding tart/acidic aroma that I dont know what it is or how to significantly explain it.

T - Starts with a bit of dark malt with just hints of dark bread and even fainter hint of chocolate. That quickly gives way to a subtle dark fruit tartness. This then quickly opens up into a smokey, charred wood flavor. Underlying this is some burnt brown sugar and molasses. The finish has a strong peaty/charred wood tasting bitterness along with a fair amount of alcohol, and just the faintest underlying of dark fruit. The peat/charred wood really lingers on the tongue for quite some time. Reminds me a bit of a whisky really.

M - A touch more than medium body with slightly under moderate carbonation. Pretty smooth.

D - The alcohol and wood/peat can get to be a bit heavy after awhile. Definitely a sipper. Probably a good beer to have on occasion, but I dont think Id make a habit of drinking it regularly.

Notes: Bottled on 05/27/09. Definitely an interesting beer that has a strong wood presence. Really this beer was a bit of an enigma for me whether it was trying to determine the aroma or trying to determine if I like it or not. At times I was really enjoying it, and at times I wasnt so sure. Its a beer that Id really have to be in the mood for to have again. The wood/peat and alcohol were a little strong for me, but at times they worked. Those being so prominent reminded me of a whisky at times. Definitely worth a try to see how you feel about it.
Huge brown with spice notes.  Wood.  Licorice.  Thick malt character.  Alcohol in the finish.  Sip; dont gulp.
From the bottle in a chilled pint glass.  Has a ve
From a bottle. Crazy beer. Midnight black poor. Every taste is a mouthful. This is definitely NOT a session beer! Excellent craftsmanship from Dogfish Head again!
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Big sweet malty aroma, very dark brown (almost black) colour with brown head. Complex strong smokey sweet woody flavour with a smooth oily texture. Too strong for me.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2010 12 oz bottle from Whole Foods Pasadena, CA. Color almost black. Nice light brown head, fine. Aroma is fruity (forest fruit, raisin), malty sweet, drop (licorice) (or soy sauce) and alcoholic. Flavor is rather sweet. Long aftertaste, a bit bitterish. Wood becomes more detectable as glass get emptier. Quite delicious.

Bottle. Appearance is black with a thin ring of light brown head around the glass. Aroma is roasted malt, vanilla, caramel and rum. Taste begins with strong dark roasted malt and molasses flavors followed by caramel, espresso, vanilla, brown sugar and bourbon. Mouthfeel is sticky and syrupy with low carbonation. It finishes malty and woody with some alcohol burn at the end. Overall flavor is dark and malty with the complexity that you expect from a barrel aged beer. The high ABV is prevalent throughout so each sip should be slowly savored since one bottle is plenty for an evening.

This pours thick and black with almost no carbonation.  After a vigorous pour I managed to get out a half a finger of medium brown, fine foam.  smells of raisin, brown sugar, soy sauce.  Taste is similar.  Super thick.  Some mild sap comes through in the end, and in the long finish the wood can be tasted.  Incredibly malty for an American Strong Ale.
Smoky brown ale. Heavy wood undertones. Thick and strong. High abv is noticeable, but not distracting. Very nice. Rated 8/3/09

Muddy complexion capped off with a superb toffee head. Tastes liked it was pumped with brown sugar and pureed coffee beans. Pretty gaudy and loud tasting, with its vigorous mouthfeel, but its one hell of a sipping beer. Has a bit of a sharp bite, sort of like hard alcohol, at the end of it. There is a ton of cataclysmic flavor in this bottle. Hail the holy tree.
Bottle. Brown and very full bodied. Smoky wooden flavour which impacts on you as soon as you sip at it. Some traces of liquorice  as well plus a gentle sweetness. Distinctive and impessive.

Poured from bottle. Pours an amazing inky brown, almost opaque; much darker than most stouts or porters, let alone brown ales. The nose is dark fruit, spice, and a decent dose of booze. The flavor is...not quite indescribable, but...cocoa, maple/molasses, vanilla, licorice, and dark roast counterbalances an almost citrus sweetness. I am reminded of the American tradition of serving espresso with a slice of lemon or a bit of lemon peel. It also drinks hot and boozy; you can sense that 12%. The texture is thick, oily, and almost tongue-coating; it drinks like dairy, not like beer. Overall, I like it -- and I cannot imagine a situation where I would ever drink more than one, and that rarely.

Pours near black with a mocha colored thin head that fades to a lasting ring. Aroma is very complex and very appealing. Strong vanilla notes with chocolate, coffee, licorice, and woody undertones. Flavor was certainly sweet but I enjoyed it. Full bodied, thick, syrupy mouthfeel. Quite tasty!

Aroma is vanilla, cedar, licorice... tons more but i cant quite pick out all of the smells... super complex. Pours an opaque brown/black with a decent mocha head. Tons of flavor here. I get a lot of licorice, some tobacco, oak-like qualities, and some spiciness. This is a tasty beer. It hides the alcohol incredibly well and goes great with a cigar!

Big, sweet, medicinal, woody. The ratings on Ratebeer led me to believe this beer is was a great beer. While it has some interesting tastes and aroma it is way too sweet. To the point that I could only drink one at a time or I had to dilute it with an Arrogant Bastard.  This beer is overrated and over priced.
LOVE it.  Intense wood armoas.  Dark and smooth.  A fixture in my fridge.  Another winner from Dogfish.

From a 12 oz bottle into a snifter.  Pours dark as midnight with about an inch of head which dissappears very quickly.  Nose is of cough syrup, berries, alcohol and wet wood.  Mouthfeel is SUPER thick and heavy.  Taste is straight up cough syrup.  Some cherry, wood, licorice, sherry and tons of alcohol are present.  Mmmm not my favorite.  It is to hot for me and to mediciney.  On the  other hand oz for oz, its cheaper than NyQuill and just as effective!  Im aging some and will update the review once Ive opened one up.

first id like to say this is not a seasonal or a special but one of dogfish heads year round beers..taste is reminiscent of a glass of chocolate milk with other subtle flavors of caramel,roasted malt and caramelized sugar,not much bitterness but the wood gives it an unusual mellow flavor also a bit of subtle dark fruit and perhaps sweet wine..tastes more like an impy stout than brown ale but whos complaining powerful,strong alcohol well hidden so be careful,thick and lightly carbonated,yet somehow drinkable,to me kind of a world wide stout lite if youre familiar

355ml Bottle via trade with Lithy, thanks Justin! Very deep dark brown to black colour, pours almost like syrup, thin light brown head. Aroma of caramel with chocolate and hint of coffee, vanilla, alcohol, and wood. Flavour is sweet, malty, lots of caramel, a bit of burnt sugar, chocolate, slight coffee notes, roast, light spicy, alcohol, vanilla, light fruity and hoppy bitter finish with a sweet and sticky aftertaste. Fullbodied, almost flat in carbonation. Good stuff.

12 fl. oz. bottle from Party Source (Syracuse), served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 
App.:  Deep brown-black with a so-so mocha head.
  
Aroma:  Difficult to describe, quiet sweet, floral, perfumed, some chocolatey-vanilla notes, nice roasty malts, some slightly minty herbals, somewhat boozy, fruity, quite interesting.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, fairly sparse yet prickly effervescence, a bit syrupy.
  
Flav.:  A bit darker than the nose, still lots of that sort of rose water, perfumed floral sweet fruitiness, rootbeer-like mintiness, chocolate and vanilla, some molasses and hints of licorice, a definite woody/cedary/cigar tobacco note; quite sweet with decent bitterness and a slighty boozy, slightly tangy fruity malt finish.

Quite interesting.

This is a vision among brown ales, although I feel that it drinks more like a stout.. Rich malts and some toffee sweetness round out the intriguing Palo Santo wood while wrapped up in a boozy wrapper. At 12% it packs a punch and the palate is thich and chewy.

12 oz. bottle. Pours very dark reddish-brown with lasting beige lacing. Great aroma, lots of rich wood and raisin. Taste is caramel malts, more rich palo santo wood,  with resinous hop notes. Alcohol comes through a tad in the finish.

Bottled 12/28/09. Consumed 4/3/10. [A] Dont think Ive ever given a 10 in aroma. Not even BB Expo/Double Cream. This is worthy. Very pleasant rosy, woody smell. Better than oak. Caramel, vanilla, licorice, banana, chocolate, coffee, malty brown, spirity aroma. [A] Slick looking pour, sitting very black in glass, completely opaque, with a tan/brown head. Impressive for a brown/strong ale. More of a stout look. [F] Sawdust. Licorice most noticeable. Followed by caramel. Coffee, and roast malts. Wood. And bourbony vanilla here. Touch of smoke. Lovely. [P] 12% ABV is not overly apparent under everything else. May be quite hot on booze to alot of people. The mouthfeel is wonderful. Medium-heavy. Milky. Bitter on end, with a dry woodiness, and spirit. [O] This is a huge brew. Quite a treat. Just as great as I remembered it. Highly recommended.

Ha - one of my favorites now. I have to give it a 4.9, so there is room for Thomas Hardys et al at the top. But--wow--DFH really nailed it with the Palo Santo. I highly recommend this to all "non beer drinkers"... this beer would be enjoyed by wine lovers, whiskey lovers, etc. The wood really comes through with deep mellow roasted chestnut and malt. Beautiful!

Pours a nice dark reddish brown color. Aromas of wood, and some other hints, maybe fruit, some caramel. Flavor is a bittersweet, malty, and thick as hell. Can really taste the alcohol in this one. This one would be better served in the fall or winter. Damn fine beer, none the less.

Big, sweet, medicinal, woody. Im a little put off by the sweet medicinal flavor in this beer. Thats my main thought, but I probably had my hopes set too high. Palo Santo Marron isnt a bad beer, but the unique woody flavor suffers from its sweetness for my palate. There is some dryness from the wood, but the mouthfeel is still fairly cloying. The flavor is complex, and there are some good notes in there. Its just all a bit too much. The alcohol is a bit forward for the sweet syrupy feel. I enjoy the beer, but at the price, I probably wont buy one again soon.

On tap at brewpub.  Poured dark brown with a thick dark tan head and light lacing.   Aroma of dark roasted malts, burnt toffee, and some lighter dark chocolate and coffee scents.  Flavor is big and malty with dark, roasted nuts, dark fruit, maple syrup and a woodiness. The finish is long and strong, with mainly coffee and dark chocolate flavors.  Full bodied, thick and rich.

Rich dark mahogany color with lots of lace. Lots of woody malt vanilla and alcohol in the aroma. Rich malty flavor moderately sweet with caramel and oaky tones. Finishes with vanilla, and a pleasant but noticeable alcohol presence. Very smooth and drinkable for such a substantial beer.

Bottle (Bottled date 11/11/09 ) served in a large Dogfish Head snifter glass. Jet black, opaque color, thin head that recedes quickly and a little lacing on the glass. Boozy alcohol aroma hits you hard up front with hints of vanilla. A malty sweet flavor initially followed by a woody charcoal sensation. Very long lingering pleasant aftertaste with alcohol, rum, bourbon, charcoal and earthy wood flavors from the wood. Very complex and interesting. Very thick and syrupy. The alcohol flavor, although pleasant dominates this beer at this age. I have some aged and this will be a great beer to buy year by year and do a vertical tasting. This is a one and done sipping beer. Its complex enough to match any cabernet or fine wine and would be great paired up with a big steak or roast.

Bottle date February 17, 2009, poured into a wide body Dogfish Head snifter, 13 months in the bottle.

Appearance is near black, extremely dark, would need to be in a shot glass to see any real color density and clarity, with a vigorous pour the head is an inch and a half light brown.

The aroma is very malt forward with a cocoa character, some dried fruit, touch of currants and raisins. Vanilla bean, dark rum and touches of maple sap and raw honey. A wave of alcohol and then earthy wood tones. No hop aroma really to speak of. There is a resinous character that I cant quite put my finger on that can only be realistically attributed to the Palo Santo Wood and it mingles with the alcohol as almost raw tobacco leaf.

The flavor on this beer is just incredible and difficult to wrap your head around, there is a huge warming alcohol that washes the tongue and hits the back of the throat, unlike any other beer I have ever had. The alcohol sensation is akin to chiplote peppers. Usually a heat like this is abrasive or offensive in a beer, but is extremely well received. I pick up some chocolate character, big notes of dark rum, bourbon, raw earthy wood tones, pine sap, maple sap and espresso. Tobacco and slight smokiness. Hop flavor is not something found in this rich complex brew. Bitterness is apparent upfront but washed out by the residual sweetness and the alcohol, leaving a touch in the finish. Touches of roastiness as it warms.

The mouthfeel is full bodied with a very creamy silk smooth texture, semi-sweet finish, but the alcohol warmth provides a counter balance.

This is without a doubt one of the most unique beers you can experience. At this point, a year into the bottle the flavor has so much depth, it will be a fight to keep these aging. It has the character of a imperial stout, but not as thick and sweet. Anything else you drink in the same evening will be mute and meaningless.
Pours out a really dark brown, almost black color. Nose is caramel, vanilla and some oak as well. Flavors are sweet, raisin, vanilla, and finished smoky. Medium bodied and finish last for a bit.

On pour this is an impressive deep, deep brown ale with an almost caramel colored head. The nose is massive and complex with malt, caramel, vanilla bean, campfire, hardwood, and alcohol. As it warms in the glass it becomes more complex. This ale pushes the upper edges of medium bodied. There is plenty palo santo wood on mouth with massive amounts of smoked malt. The finish is a velvet yet chewy with an almost chocolate feel.

Bottle. Deep dark brown pour with a good beige head. Smoked aroma. Tastes incredibly rich, roasty, caramel, malty, dark fruit, hint of vanilla. Quite smooth and relatively easy drinking. Tasted stronger than 12% to me!

Dogfish Head Brewing Company--Palo Santo Marron--Malt Beverage aged on Palo Santo Wood--2008 12 oz. Bottle.  12.00% ABV--45 IBUs?  (4.6 / 5.0)  Brown Ale--Imperial--Light tight sediment.  Mild lace thin espresso head.  Clear dark ruby brown color.  Rich aromatic Palo Santo roasted chocolate hop front.  Mellow sweet creamy smooth chocolate vanilla toffee rich malt body.  Smooth mild hop spice clean malt ester end. Complex Tasty Rich Brew.  Sampled 5/25/2009.  3 @ $4.49 Each.

Eventhough the comercial description does not say it, this is much like a barley wine.  The sweet and figgy flavors are noticable on the nose.  There is a small but noticable cabrenet flavor.  Overall the sweetness overpowers the alcohol, hops, and malt flavors.  This is unfortunate because dogfish head places so much care and effort in every brew.  I salute the attempt, the beer is good but came off too sweet.

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours a very dark, opaque brown with a tan lacy head.  The nose is very pungent with a hint of diaper.  The high alcohol is very powerful.  The flavor is likewise powerful.  Sweet n sour with simultaneous notes of caramel and vanilla and soy sauce, which combined with all the other flavors does nothing to detract from the overall experience.  The palo santo wood, whatever it is, gives this beer an amazing richness and makes it one of a kind.  Combined with a good creamy mouthfeel and you have quite a beverage.

Aroma:Caramel,chocolate,coffee...
Appearance:Dark brown,good head...
Flavor:Strongcaramel,chocolate...
Raisin aroma with hints of a woodsy finish. Very dark appearance - bitter, oak taste, lasting on the palate, good finish - outstanding.

Looks like a stout but tastes like a strong ale. Extremely dark, with an off white brown foam head. The aroma is somewhat earthy, with tones of barley, wood chips, and oak scents. The taste is smooth and goes down very smooth.

12 oz bottle served in a tulip.  Pour was opaque with an inch of mocha head.  Nose is prunes, cinnamon, wood, smoke, and soy sauce.  Taste is wood, smoke, raisons, and soy sauce.  The wood lingers on the pallet right through the finish.  The woody taste reminds me of the taste a tongue depressor at the doctors office left when I was a kid; the wood is much strong however.  There is a slight warming in my chest after taking a sip, but that is the only way that I can detect the 12% ABV.  A very strange brew that is very tasty, but I have never sampled anything quite like.

Brown bottle, 12 ounces, gift from Luc Bourbonnière (merci!), savoured on September 10 2000; eye: black, tiny ring of beige head, opaque, no lacing; nose: roasting, chocolate, light smoke, liquorice, candied fruits; mouth: roasted malt, light burnt, candied fruits, liquorice, warming alcohol and quite a bit of it, molasses, soya sauce, light woody, not much carbonation, full body, light acridness, liqueur-like texture, lightly salty; overall: quite good

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 12 onces, cadeau de Luc Bourbonnière (merci!), savourée le 10 septembre 2009; il : noire, petit anneau de mousse beige, opaque, pas de dentelle; nez : torréfaction, chocolat, léger fumé, réglisse, fruits confits; bouche : malt torréfié, léger brûlé, fruits confits, réglisse, alcool réchauffant et pas mal, mélasse, sauce soya, léger boisé, peu carbonatée, corsée, légère âcreté, texture liquoreuse, légèrement salée; en résumé : bien bon

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2010 Pours dark brown with a red tint where the light shines through. A light brown head that gathers in large bubbles in the center and on the edges. Distinct aromas of vanilla, caramel, and wood. The palate is smooth, almost creamy as it is swished around the mouth and finishes long. The taste is mostly sweet- caramel malt and vanilla and a fruitiness underneath. It finishes with a warm and puckering tartness.  At 12% ABV, the alcohol is really well masked.  This is a great evening sipper.  Will definitely drink again.

Pours a dark brown with thick brown head.  Aroma is smoked wood, malts, vanilla and brown sugar.  Taste is very malty with the vanilla and wood coming through nicely.  Nice mouthfeel with the sweetness lingering at the finish.  Nice job Sam and DFH.

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2010 Bottle. Pours almost jet black, actually a very deep brown.  Light brown foam. Sweet caramel and coffee aroma. Tastes of malt, of coffee (not too intense), but sweetish with a hint of stout. Amazing malty palate, very smooth and wonderfully balanced, with just light carbonation a slightly hoppy tone but little bitterness. Stays on the tongue for ages after. Like drinking a shed varnished with dark treacle.
Just didnt cut it for me. Sort of like stale Chex Mix... floating in a warm IPA. Lots of flavors but none worth hanging around for. Given the price Ill stay with their 90 or 60 IPA.

I loved this beer - almost pitch black, smelled like burnt wood and toasted caramel. Comes on big but isnt thick and overwhelming like some over-the-top strong ales. Dogfish Head is always experimenting, and some work better than others. This is definitely one Id seek out again.

Imagine that you opened the door of my Fast Eddy Barbeque and stuck out your tongue. Reached your noggin inside the smoker and licked from the very bottom to the top. The unscrew a cap of Kitchen Bouquet liquid browning agent and drank it down. Smack your lips and this is what you get when you uncap a bottle of Palo Santo Marron. Woody, smokey, dark brown, opaque, thick. It does have something bright in the flavor profile, just a tinge. Not a terrible beer....Im undecided. Hard to rate it right now. Its something......not sure what...but something I havent quite tasted before.

Very deep brown with a thin brown head that laces a tad.  Aroma of odd wood  its very different and spicy almost cedar like, roasted malt, alcohol, caramel, vanilla, earthy hops, wet wood and a touch of smoke.  I could just sit and smell this thing all day, its do damn interesting and appealing!  Taste of the odd spicy wood mixed with alcohol up front followed by vanilla, followed by warming.  Spicy wood, caramel, vanilla, brown sugar dominate the flavors and it finishes up with spicy alcohol.  Every now and again Ill have a beer thats a bit out there and interesting and this one is as good as it is unique.  Another dogfish head winner!

Pours dark brown with a 1-2 finger chunky mocha head that has great retention and leaves nice lacing. Aroma is huge on rich, darker caramel, light roast, sweet woody notes, sweet cereal grain, sweet white bread crust and chocolate truffels. Flavor is rich roast and bunches of dark, rich caramel right away, milk chocolate, light planty hops, herbal cola notes and some playful smokey leather notes. Palate is pretty heavy bodied, slightly slick and syrupy with an oddly high carbonation, dries out a bit and leaves a sticky feel on the lips near the finish. I really dig this stuff, it could use some work in the palate department and its a bit too sweet, but I still like it alot. This is a big beer that pairs really well with a multitude of foods.

Low roasted malt aroma with some notes of vanilla & dark chocolate. Tall tan head that lingers with fine cascading bubbles that cling to the glass like a sheer curtain. The spicy notes of the Palo Santo wood come through, reminiscent of sandalwood or of incence, creating a playful balance between the roast, vanilla & chocolate. The long finish ends with a peppery or of a middle eastern spice. Quite yummy.

Pours very dark brown to black with a thin brown head that fades quickly.  Substantial legs.  Aroma is of vanilla, chocolate malts, and alcohol.  Malty coffee taste upfront, even more malts kick in on the back, with an alcoholic warmth in the throat.  Mouthfeel is very thick with no bubbles to speak of.  Very good.

This one pours a deep, dark brown with a nice off-white head. The nose is vanilla, cotton candy bubble gum, sweet fruit, raisins, a nice woody character, some liquorice and a lot of alcohol. Similar in the mouth more alcohol. This beer is really smooth and overly sweet to the point that it hardly tastes like a beer. Definitely not my thing.

Bottle. Pour was dark clear brown with an aroma of brown sugar, sweet malt, wood, alcohol, some dark fruit, and roasted. Flavors were real well blended together with a nice, lightly sweet full body complimented by toasty and roasted malt flavors, hidden alcohol, more mellow wood, and a little toffee. I got some mellow, almost vanilla extract character in the finish that was nice and smooth. Real nice brew that had a great brewing process. Ill look for this one again.

Draught.  Pours a very dark brown with a light brown head.  The aroma is wonderful and fills the nostrils with creme brulee, vanilla, molasses and sweet malt.  The flavor is creme brulee, vanilla, molasses, and raisins and is decidedly sweet, which is not a problem for me as I enjoy sweet beers.  Rich and dense on the palate, which is appropriate given the characteristics of this beer, but not cloying.  Very tasty brew!
Complex flavor, balanced with a great hops bite. Fine, bubbly carbonation with a vanilla undertone that makes this one of my favorite beers.
Very mild cherry aroma and extremely dark appearance of this beer dont really stand out, but the flavor is amazing - rich, but very well balanced given that it clocks in at 12(!)% ABV.

Pours dense and black with a dark brown head. Fades to moderate lacing that clings beautifully.  Nose is strong with the aged woody notes of the Palo Santo and alcohol.  Those two dominate and crowd out the other aromas.  The taste is all malt, wood, and alcohol.  I know that Dogfish was trying to go bold here, but it just ends up one-note.  Its not bad, its just not good enough to justify the cost.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2011 Aroma of smoke, grass, spruce, caramel with a floral bouquet.  Pours a dark chocolate color, with a thin tan head.  Has a smoky sweet taste.  Chocolate flavor on the aftertaste.  Little carbonation.  A bit sweet for my taste, but tasty in an interesting way.

June 26, 2010 - On tap at the Milton Brewery.  Out of the tap the added carbonation better balances the sweet.  The creamier mouthfeel really bumps up the experience with this brew.  The smoky flavor is more subtle.  I am aging a few and will see how that affects this brew.  But I have to rate this beer higher than before because I really enjoyed this on tap.

July 5, 2011 - On cask at the Rehoboth Brewpub.  This brew was meant to be enjoyed in cask condition.  It loses that biting sweetness out of the bottle.  On cask, just a creamy smooth dark ale with some nice chocolate notes, dark fruit, and gentle bitter layer.  Just amazing.
This is totally over the top. It is like drinking herb-infused burnt molasses with grain alcohol. I couldnt finish the bottle.

Thanks to Gypsy19 for this one!!
~Aroma of milk chocolate, dark cherry, caramel, light vanilla, hint of coconut, alcohol, and smokey wood.
~Pours a very dark brown opaque color with small creamy off white head.
~Chocolate cherry in flavor with woody notes, vanilla, light alcohol, and caramel.
~Full bodied, low co2, creamy, woody chocolate aftertaste.
~Wow! This beer is rather impressive. The balance of all scents and flavors blend perfectly together, yet they can be picked out individually and enjoyed.

12oz. Bottle from VBM in Buffalo. Wow what a nice beer thatll kick you in the ass. Pours a deep dark opaque brown body with a one finger dark tan head. Aroma is complex cherry, vanilla, raisin milk chocolate, sweet woods, and alcohol with a general caramel malty overtone. Flavor is much of the same. Great balance of sweet and bitter. Decent carbonation, fuller bodied mouthfeel. Long lasting aftertaste. Alcohol can be felt, but doesnt take away from this superb beer. Great!!

If it werent cheating I would copy the text from Unstrops review and say "yeah ... me too ..."  Nose of dark roasts, malt, chocolate, coffee.  Brown to almost black, pretty much opaque, tiny tan head, lacing but less than I would have expected from the body, more than I would have expected from the head.  Taste of burnt malts, chocolate, coffee, alcohol, and wood.  Yeah, Palo Santo provides serious wood.  And alcohol.  Like so much from DFH, this one is an alcohol slam, and like so much from DFH the alcohol is hidden.  Drink a second one at your peril!

Dark Brown ale.  Aroma smells of chocolate, hops and wood.  Tastes of malt and barley.  Heavy mouth feel.  Careful because the taste masks the 12 % ABV.  My new favorite brown ale.  I have yet to have a bad beer from dogfish head brewery.
To date, other then Youngs double chocolate stout, this is my favorite beer!

pours a murky-dark brown.  aromas of molasses and coffee.  Heavy-mouthfeel with a mix of flavours including vanilla, coffee, hazelnut and caramel.  clearly a sipping beer as tough to get through this chewy creation.   high points for its originality.
Very dark brown or black with a tan head.  Aroma of chocolate liquer or Khalua.  Taste of dark fruit, slight smokiness, and spices.  Finish is short and earthy.

Draft.  Geez I like this beer.  It boasts all of the gentle, bitter and malt characteristics of a brown with the aged, red wine tint of aging on wood.  Aromas are plummy and rich fruit, chocolate and bread.  Flavors are extremely complex, well-integrated into the beer, and long on the finish.

Pours a beautifully dark brown to black w/ caramel head, aroma of coffee and dried fruit, taste is cedarwood, roasted malts and chocolate, very interesting and complex, one of my faves, 12 percent kicks your butt too!

Solid brown, thick creamy light brown head. Aroma of chocolate, alcohol, butter, vanilla, dark fruit. Taste is sweet fruit with some milk chocolate and bitter hops and coffee bean. Medium body, soft carbonation.

My my. Well at last Ive found a brown beer that I really, really like. Pours out with a real oily texture, gooey and thick. Despite being called brown I have to say if it is rown at all it is VERY dark brown pretty much black in fact, with a small but persistant, creamy, mocha coloured head. Wow! What a nose, loads of compelxity. Roasted notes up first, then a distinct savoury cherry characteristic, then a really spicy woody sent that almost reminds me of subtle sandlewood, spices take over with dark chocolate and fruit. Flavour is amazing, such balance. Hits with earthy roasted malts, then some toasted nuts, more bitter chocolate, some hint of the alcohol - but it still remains impecably contrled for the abv. Then in come more vinous notes, some fruits of the forest. Mouthfeel is faltless, palate-wise it feels like creamy velvet, almost like irish cream, LUSH. Finish is long and smoky with more spiciness, chocolate, wood and grapes. Really great beer and pleasignly unique.

On Tap at the Trion.  Not bad.
 Nose is a blend of roasted malts, brown sugar, earthy doughiness and alcohol... hops are present but take a back seat.
 Pours a rich dark brown, almost opaque, with a thin tan head. Not much lacing to speak of.
 Taste is sweet and slightly alcoholic, with some chocolate flavor that didnt come through in the nose.
  Palate is full bodied with an oily, slightly sticky texture.  Carbonation is present but does not overwhelm the style. A long bitter finish that draws more on the dark chocolate that is hidden from the nose... the alcohol makes itself know here at the finish, but is not overpowering for a 12% abv.
  Nice beer, wouldnt mind having another one.

Bottle at co-worker tasting club. Slick and silky black with initial ballooning tan head.  Settles steady.  Nose of burnt toast and caramel. Some stone fruit tendencies in strong sweet finish.  Next time a whole one will grow on me I am sure.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2010 Dogfish Head Palo Santo Marron
12 oz bottle 12 ABV
Pours dark brown, almost black with little head. No lacing on the glass. Aroma of hops, roasted malts, alcohol and molasses. My wife says it smells of vegetables. Oily mouthfeel. Flavor of sweet nuts, alcohol, woody without being synthetically smoky. Smooth bittersweet dark chocolate aftertaste lingers for a bit. Interesting flavor and aroma. Hides the high ABV decently, but we like the flavor of alcohol.Good but not great.

12oz bottle.  Pours very dark brown, almost black with a small brown head.  Reduces to a whispy covering and leaves a little spotty but short-lived lacing.  Aroma is roasted malts, brown sugar, vanilla, and the wood is big on the nose, also some spice.  Flavor is vanilla, molasses, malty, and spicy.  Long spicy finish.  Mouthfeel is on the thin side, medium carbonation.  Interesting.  Pretty good, but Im not sure if its worthy of the high price.  However, its intriguing enough that I think it would be great with a number of years on it, so Ill probably pick some more up to cellar.
Thick like blood with about as much flavor.  Insanely rich.  Really nutty and sweet.  Intoxicating.

Pours a nice dark, dark brown colour with a nice beige head and lacing. For me it smeeled of caramel and anisee and tasted the the same way. Dont worry the anisee taste is very mild! i liked this one alot! Its heavy and thus a sipping beer, but its really good!

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2010 A very good if not rather aggressive beer from Dogfish Head. Courtesy of Ang. Shared with Ang. I enjoyed this Complex; bourbon, oaky texture, woody, tough doughy yeast strain, good lacing. A bit ott though.

A very powerful beer and not one for downing. Take your time to enjoy and feel the complex malt character. Edited - 15th May 2010. Bottle bought from Utobeer.

12oz bottle, pours very dark brown, almost black, with a small tan head. Aroma of caramel malts, sweet fruit and vanilla. Complex flavour of vanilla, roasted barley, wood, malt, bourbon and alcohol. Great brew.

12oz bottle.  Wow.  Very unique beer here.  Poured dark brown with tan head.  Nice aromas of fruit, citrus.  Taste is very very different for a beer.  Very sweet with tons of flavor.  I really liked this beer.  Very high ABV.
12oz bottle, very dark brown with a moderate dark tan head with some lacing. Roasted barley and wood.  Somewhat sweet with a hops tang. A bit pricey but well worth the experience.

On tap at Mexican Food Factory in Marlton, NJ. Amazing, complex in flavor and aroma, lots of sweet fruit and vanilla as well as some darker flavors such as roast malt and a little chocolate, really really well hidden alcohol flavor considering the abv. This could sneak up on you if you werent ready for it.

Overall, just too sweet for me, but its still a good brew, lots of Vanilla, woody flavor, just abit too sweet for me, the alcohol is VERY well hidden, didnt know it was so high until now, decent, would I drink it again? Sure, on occasion.

12 oz bottle. Had this once before, but forgot to rate it, so I got another bottle to try. Pours a dark dark brown with a small tan/brown head that dies quickly. Smells bourbon, wood, alcohol, malt, and vanilla. Very impressed by the smell, as it was multi-layered, and very potent. The taste is also quite good; light bourbon, oak (I think), some malt, and a vanilla aftertaste with an alcohol warming to it. For a brown ale, it is quite well-bodied, and it is one of the best Ive had. Better this time than last time, I think.

Bottle: &nbsp Heavy brown, thick, thin light brown head, sparce lacing. &nbsp Wow, quite the complex aroma. &nbsp Soy, bubblegum, ash, charred wood, fig, minor anise. &nbsp This thing has a lot going on. &nbsp Warming on the tongue, feels quite quite fig/date based. &nbsp Does have a slight soy aspect. &nbsp Otherwise woody, both ash and charred wood, along with a young fresh cut wood. &nbsp Full bodied, moderate mouthfeel. &nbsp Further warming on the backside. &nbsp Not alcoholic, but you can tell its a high ABV beer. &nbsp Lingering wood and soy aspects. &nbsp Very minor brown sugar and maple syrup. &nbsp Pretty good stuff. &nbsp Definitely a unique wood aged style of beer. &nbsp Pretty damn unique, and tasty!

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2015 Pours black with a lasting tan head and spotty lacing.  aroma is alcohol, leather, wood, smoked meat, nuts and roasted dark malt.  syrupy with low carbonation and a prickly, boozy mouthfeel.  taste is whiskey, wood, almonds, and a sensation of grilled meat.  finish is a similar sensation to actually eating a kernel of dark roasted chocolate malt.  This is a formidable and delicious beer.

Dark brown pour with a small head. Aroma is sweet, slightly earthy, some wood and molasses. Flavor is sweet, some alcohol, wood and faint spice with the caramel sweetness. Nice and malty overall just what I like.

Bottled. darker dark brown with thin head. sweet chocolate and coffee dominate nose and flavor keeps these notes and adds booze, wood, and caramel and lighter citrus. End is weird and original with dry feel leaving a filmy feel in the mouth. Big bodied and oily texture. A weird but definitely creative offering.

Shazzam! Whoaaaa, nelly bell! Stupendous beer! Not exactly a brown ale as friend Euel says, its brown and its an ale. Ok. nuff said on that. But it pours with a small tan head and some lace. Color is an opaque dark, almost black, brown. Aroma is very rich and earthy, fecund, licorice, old leather, and bittersweet. Flavors the same but more full and luxurient. Kim Jong Il would love this beer. Hail, feerless leader. Body is velvety smooth and enticing. Almost too rich. Not a session beer. Atlantic Monthly had a great article on brewmaster.

Bottle. Pours black with a thin brown head. Aroma is composed of roasty, coffee, and woody aspects with just a little alcohol. Taste is fairly bitter accompanied by a high alcoholic mouthfeel and a little carbonation.
Poured pitch black. Sweet malty aroma. Very sweet. Roast malt and caramel taste with notes of oak and vanilla. A bit boozy, but very well done.

bottle from midway mart in denton, tx.  poured a maroonish black/dark brown with a tan head leaving some lace on the glass, also had some decent legs.  aroma was caramel, red wine, grape, raisin, and what seemed to be a woody character.  flavor was chocolate, grapes, other dark fruits, alcohol, and a nice little dry bitter on the finish.  body was medium with about medium carbonation.  all in all i liked this one.

Deep, dense brown pour with a head the colour of a fishermans arms.  Huge aroma of roasted brown sugars and alcohol.  Everything about this brew is shades of brown.  Brownies, toasted brown sugar, dark sweet dried fruits, and Pacific hops all found here in abundance.  Wonderfully creamy and intense meant to be savoured sip by sip.  DFH has a challenge to Stone now.  Where can I get some of the wood?

Very dark brown from a 12oz, with med. brown head, fast light lace. A lovely candy-malt aroma, very pungent with an edge of tree sap. Flavor is very original with bold malt filled with a sweet tangy woody, cedar-like flavor. Cuban coffee comes to mind. The palate is a bit oily and the finish hangs on like woodsmoke. Overall very pleasant

Bouteille de 12 oz. Arômes de caramel brûlé, dalcool et de bois. Robe brune foncée, pas de mousse et effervescence faible. Très sirupeuse, une touche boisée et vanillée est présente, mais demeure réservée et est bien supportée par un beau malt caramel et une touche de réglisse. Finale sucrée et très alcoolisée. Il sagit dune bonne bière, mais lalcool est vraiment très présent.

Black color; thin creamy head, brown. Light aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and alcohol. Smooth and quite strong body; strong chocolate character, with some sweetness, light liquorice; the Palo Santo probably leaves a light wood touch, light astringency and light sourness. Correct bitterness; the final is warming but not too alcoholic.A chocolate brew, powerful but not too complex.

Pours the consistency of dark brown maple syrup out of the botela. Has a half inch brown head that settle to a film before enjoyment can begin. Looks alcoholy in the liquid. Nose is roasted malt with brown sugar maple and alcohol. Taste is punchy brown roasted malt with sage and whatever. Gives a bad headache the next day. Are we done with this yet?

Very dark brown from a 12oz, with med. brown head, fast light lace. A lovely candy-malt aroma, very pungent with an edge of tree sap. Flavor is very original with bold malt filled with a sweet tangy woody, cedar-like flavor. Cuban coffee comes to mind. The palate is a bit oily and the finish hangs on like woodsmoke. Overall very pleasant

12oz bottle from Winooski. Pours pitch black with a small brown head. Nose is very rich. Sweet, fruity, alcohol, quite malty and roasty. Hints of liquorice and molasses. Some vanilla. Woody and a bit peppery. Taste has lots of alcohol, some dark fruits, lots of malt and some vanilla and barrel. Woody. Slight bitterness. Nice sipper, awesome winter warmer. A bit too boozy. Texture is oily. Finish is warm, liquorice, vanilla and roasted malt. Delightful. Gets a bit spicier at the end.

Bottle. Was really looking forward to this. Nice aroma of malt, wood and some spice. Dark appearance. Taste was chocolate, leather, dry, spice but seemed overwhelmed by the alcohol. Nowhere near as complex as some of their other brews. Palate was as dry as a can of Nestles Quik. Perphaps, it was a bad bottle.

When this beer is poured it is almost black in color, with little head. Aromas are woody and robust. Light lacing, sips are loaded with many different flavors and warmth from the alcohol but most predominant taste is the lingering wood that comes from the wood used in aging. Good american strong ale, not a personal favorite, probably wont buy again.

Salty alcoholic aroma. Pours dark black with little head. Taste is strong and starts sweet and ends with a warm alcohol feel in the mouth. Be sure to sip as that a big gulp will destroy the palate and likely make you hate this beer. Huge flavor, but takes some getting used to.

Pours nearly stout black with a mocha head. Very wood like aroma. Tastes highly roasted with chocolate woody flavors blending with a thick alcohol taste. Aftertaste sits thick on the tongue. Very big beer. Reminds me more of smoked porter than American strong. Aging one to try later.

Bottle 12oz. - Poured dark brown with small tan head.
Aroma - rich dark chocolate, what must be Palo Santo wood, raisins and booze....Very nice!!!
Flavor - Dusty woodsy chocolate taste mixed with nice balance of alcohol. Definite sipper with high ABV., finishes with roasted almond taste and slight alcohol burn!
Palate - medium/full bodied with velvety texture. Average carbonation, finish is smokey and lingers a bit.
Overall - Kick Ass brew, Tastes more like a stout or brown ale but still a fantastic beer. One of DFHs best brews!!

Aroma:
Sweet and slightly alcoholic

Appearance:
Dark, deep brown

Flavor:
I was really expecting to get a very strong woody flavor, but was pleasantly surprised to get a nice chocolate creaminess. The alcohol wasnt too present despite being 12% ABV. Theres also a subtle hop finish. Overall, it has a very similar flavor to New Hollands Dragons Milk Ale. (A good thing in my book.)

Mouthfeel:
Medium thickness and viscosity. Coats the mouth nicely, but doesnt leave your chest burning.

Overall, its a surprisingly drinkable beer: creamy, hoppy, and packs a punch. Palo Santo ranks as one of my favorite Dogfish brews, though I wouldnt quaff it often.

12 oz bottle, pours dark and opaque like a stout with brown head. Aroma is intensely alcoholic with prominent roastiness and maltiness. Taste is bitter and you notice easily the 12% ABV. Balanced out somewhat by the sweetness and maltiness toward the end of the drink. Body is very full and overall is a satisfying drink. Good strong ale.
This is a great one DFH. The pour is dark with an off white head...maybe a fingers worth. The nose is booze, chocolate, nutty. The taste is sweet malt, wood, raisin. Great one DFH.

Quite unique. Pours thick black similar to a stout with a thick chocolate colored head. The aroma has hints of booze swimming in chocolate, coffee, and dark fruits. Tasty dark roasted malts, vanilla, dark fruits, and molasses stand out. The flavor changes as it warms with notes of coffee becoming more pronounced. Goes down very easy for 12%, I was amazed. Lots of complex good stuff going on here and I like it, a lot.

12oz 2/17/09 - Banana is the first thing I noticed at the crack of the cap.  Dark black pour with a thin, tan head.  Not much of a nose, licorice maybe.  Vanilla and booze on palate with a burning astringency at the end.  Good but it seemed really out of balance.  Im not interested in a retry.

Served from a bottle into a tulip.

A: Little head, though it clings well to the glass. A soft brown head, almost cappuccino colored. Very dark in character with red and light brown hues around the edges.
S: A musky smell is in the foreground with a lot of burnt malt scents accompanied by a caramel fragrance. Smells boozy as it warms.
T: There is an initial balance of banana and caramel with a very robust smoky component. Im also getting a sweeter pumpkin spice aftertaste with vanilla.
M: Very thick for a brown ale (reasonably thick for a porter for that matter). Medium carbonation helps this brew attain a creamy quality.
D: Considering the abv this is a highly drinkable brew. I think the mustiness of the beer detracts from this slightly, though the sweet aftertaste brings you back for more!

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2010 (12 ounce bottle) pours an opaque dark brown beer.  Aroma is boozy but over all pleasant.  The taste of this beer smokey, has vanilla and chocolate tastes.  This beer also is also woody.  It also has a coffee smokey taste to it.  Great mouthfeel and finish.  This beer is thick but not 12% thick.  Excellent beer.

BOTTLING DATE: 09-09-08

Truly, this is a very, very dark brown liquid, through which no light shall pass. The best you can hope for is a dark ruby tinted brown highlight, at the edges.
Medium pour produces one finger of creamy coffee colored foam. It hangs around for a little bit, but doesnt overstay its welcome. Lacing is pretty darn good, if only a little spotty.

The smell is, well...different. I dont think that Ive smelled another brew quite like this one. All of the charateristic notes are there, they just combine to make a totally unique smell.
Nice maltiness is what got me first. Big notes of caramel and vanilla. Nice big oakiness. Slight booziness. Dark fruits are in abundance. Figs, dates and cherries, mostly. Slight hints of chocolate covered bananas. 

Huge malty sweetness. Burnt coffee. Big dark fruits. Brown sugar and molasses. Nice smooth oakiness. Slight hints of smoke and chocolate. Caramel presence is fairly high. 
There are so many things going on in this bottle. Its really hard to nail it down.
Very tasty and very well done brew.

Very good medium to full body. Nice and oily, in the mouth. Carbonation is low, but just right for this type of beer. It provides a nice level of creaminess, without getting in the way of the flavors.

Excellent dessert beer, here. You probably wont find yourself with the urge to drink a six-pack of these on Friday night, or anything. Its much too big of a beer for that.
Very, very good beer, but mostly for special occasions.
I want to get a bottle or two of this to cellar for a good length of time, to see how this changes. I imagine that it will become extremely tasty.

12 oz bottle to pint glass. Pours dark brown but by no means opaque, with a healthy tan head that fully dissipates over the course of a couple minutes. Brown sugar, raisins, molasses, and fruity, peppery alcohol make up the aroma. Flavor is burnt raisins, maple syrup, sugar, alcohol, dark fruits, and some chocolate. Rather sweet. The booze is obviously noticeable but actually not that distracting. Mouthfeel is sticky and thick, drinkability is above average.
10.23.09  A beastly bulging ale fit for any fall night.  Very dark, very woody and thick.  Delicious

12oz bottle.  Reddish brown body, topped with an apricot-colored head, creamy, spots of lace, lasting.  Big malty aroma with lots of dried fruit, wood, caramel, alcohol fumes.  Full bodied brew with creamy carbonation and a surprisingly dry finish for such a big beer.  Flavor is sweet with lots of fruit, roasty, lots of wood, almost smoky, tons of warmth, frighteningly easy to drink.  A very tasty, fruity, woody, and bold brew.
Excellent.  Almost black pour.  Sweet aroma of chocolate and dark fruit.  Complex flavor includes chocolate, nuts, fruit, malt and vanilla.  Drinkable and delicious.
Seriously thick and complex beer.  A little bit expensive, even by Dogfish Head standards.  This was definitely different than your average beer.

bottle...Jet black pour,thin off white head,good lacing. Aroma is sweet with notes of chocolate,coffee and wine.Flavor is sweet with notes of coffee, alcohol , caramel, mollasses and wood.Thick,slick and delicious.Full bodied and low to medium carbonation.Excellent beer .

A dark black beer with no head. The aroma was dark fruits, & alcohol giving it some characteristics of wine. The taste was grapes & was more like the peels of darker fruits. A sipper for sure for after dinner.

Draught.  Snifter.
Appearance was very black, medium chestnut colored head with good staying power and nice lacing.
Smell was chocolate chips, the bitter kind that you use for baking.
Taste was slightly sweet, started with cocoa and progressed to coffee and then finished with a bit of smokiness.
Wonderful body.
This one should definitely be sought out.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2009 11th May 2008. Jet black beer with no real head. Soft and smooth palate. Distinct banana and bubblegum tones riding over a lighly toasted malt background. Aromatic, almost minty vanilla note riding alongside. Different.

5th Aug 2008. On tap at GBBF. Lovely raspberry and blueberry sweet start with aromatic malt. Sourish woody finish. Liked this a little better than the bottle.
Whoa! Thought I would like this but whew its strong....and too sweet for me. Gave to the wife and she loved it and rated it.

[Bottle] Pours a viscous looking deep brown with a medium frothy tan head. Aroma is slightly woody, lots of sweetness and alcohol, chocolate, and some ancho pepper. Flavor is super thick and quite sweet, like drinking thick, dry cocoa power, super chocolatey beer. The pepper is in there too, along with plentiful malt sweetness and alcohol.

[12oz bottle] Dark brown with a low tan head - this beer looks thick. Oak, vanilla, sweet dark fruity nose with some alcohol notes. Sweet and malty taste with little hop influence. Smooth and heavy mouthfeel, warming down the throat from the alcohol but quite drinkable.

Deep, dark brown color with a medium brown head.  Sweet aroma with roasted malty smell.  Definitely a boozy, sweet alcohol aroma that carries over slightly to the taste.  Also a lot of sweet dark fruits and chocolatey bitterness.  This is kind of a big beer but pretty drinkable I thought.

Poured into awesome Welchs jam Curious George cup.  Bottle thanks to my awesome brother and split it with him.  Dark brown rootbeer colored pour but more opaque.  No head really but a dark tan ring.  Aroma is sweet malts.  Flavor is the same plus a bit of bitter hop background, the aftertaste and the medium body is sweet, rosey and roasted tasting.  Only very slightly warming down the throat given the high abv.  Such a cool idea - I love that theres a tree in the world you can shoot with a bullet and it wont even penetrate it.

Pours very dark.  Aroma is not as pronounced as other brew styles.  Quite thick.  Not much in the way of hops, which I prefer.  Very malty beer.  I grabbed this one to try because it looked like a limited time only brew and I wanted to at least giveit a shot.
user_location: The United States of Texas, Texas, USA

text: I thought this big brown beer was amazing.  Off tap at their Ale House.  Nice and thick, just enough hops, a very smooth flavor.  I could drink this all day.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2010 Bottle. 12 oz. Pours deep brownish amber, with a thin, yet creamy beige head which lingers around the edges and leaves beautiful lacing. Aroma of figs, oak, slight bourbon, raisins, plums, and hints of chocolate, toffee, bread, and malts. Smooth, creamy, rich moutfeel with a nice warming in the finish. Excellent American strong ale. Very reminiscent of Port Old Viscosity.

Sweet and spicy aroma that reminds me of carrot cake, molasses, and vanilla.  Tastes better than it smells, including notes of: birch, sassafras, and espresso.  Heavy body, and a pleasantly smooth aftertaste.  Slight warming, and notes of alcohol present throughout.

Bottle Pours out black topped with a small tan head. Aroma is of rich roast malts, some chocolate, that 12% and brown sugar. Taste of sweet milk chocolate, light wood, dark roast, and some pit fruit. Very nice mouth feel.

almost opaque. tan head. smells of malt, milk chocolate, heavy cream. Flavor is more sweet milk chocolate, cream, pruney, with a little cherry and a wet wood really showing at the end in a strong way. Huge body with a creamy fizz. Very compelling but somewhat sludge-y.

Bottle from Bellingers, Jet Garage, Grove Nr Wantage, Oxon consumed at Kolding City Campsite, Kolding Denmark, 24-10-09   Pours black with a light beige head, there is some liquorice and wood on the nose. Quite a tarry taste in the mouth, with sticky bitter toffee, soft in the mouth also. The alcohol is quite noticeable, some vanilla and dark sticky fruits.  A7 A4 F7 P4 Ov14  3.6

What a unique brew!  Dark and aged in some kind of wood that I dont know a lick of what the hell it is, but it IS good!  Very viscous, sweet (almost cloying but not quite), heady!  OMG! Drink three of these and youl be down for the count!  Expert carftsmanship has gone into this unique offering! Syrupy delight!
Opaque brown with a clingy head. Woody, fruity tastes in a big thick body. Currant and dark raisins emerge, particularly as the glass warms. Alcohol a-go-go. Big and sophisticated brew. Excellent.

This beer pours a pitch black with a thin beige head.  The aromas are black currant and cherries with wood accents.  The flavors are cherries, chocolate, wood and black currant.  This is a very interesting beer.  A little unbalanced but good nonetheless.Cheers!
Dark brown with a thin biege head.  Aroma of rich, toasted dark wood and brown sugar.  Flavors warming, creamy, but not my style.  A bit heavy on the wood-aging process.

Pours a motor oil black with a short lived beige head. Aroma is sweet, chocolate, raisin, maybe some cherry, alcohol, light roast coffee. The flavour is a reflection of the aroma spot on, anise in the finish rounds this delicious beer of nicely. Warming alcohol sensation. Top notch, god bless you dogfish head.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2011 Re-rate 4/25/11: Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks Lee. Black with a brown head. Aroma of wood, licorice, roasted malt, some chocolate, vanilla and some hoppy notes. Sweet flavor of malt, caramel, a bit of vanilla and a bitter hoppy finish. Medium to full-bodied. 6/4/7/3/13=3.3

Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks David C. Really dark brown with a light brown head. Strong aroma of sweet chocolate. Sweet and alcoholic flavor with chocolate, some nuts, some licorice and some slightly strange fruitiness. Full-bodied and boozy. Decent but overpowering. 8/4/6/3/13=3.4

At a tasting, thanks David, quickly dissapearing beige head, colour is dark brown and quite opaque but with some lightish taints, aromas of maple, dried frutis, and some oxidised notes, flavours of dried fruits, charcoal and chocolate. Much too sweet and alcoholic, and quite unbalanced.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2011 Bottle courtesy of brentfresh. Dark brown pour. Sweet aroma. Fruit and sweet plum. Taste is sweet dry with heavy malts. Tingle on the tongue. Flavor finishes sadder than the Belgian strong I had previous. 3.2
RE-RATE 4/14/11 Bottle from Central Market.  After I let this beer warm on the counter for half an hour or so, I poured it elegantly into my Dogfish Head oversized wine glass. Im so glad I finally get to use this bad boy! It pours very dark brown with a nice tall tannish-brown head. The head lasts for awhile before finally dropping into the drink.

The aroma is pretty strong. Heavy with dark malts and a spicy wood with some light vanilla and aging raisin. Definitely smells like it will be higher in alcohol.

Flavor is sweet flavorful malts and grains, with a candied sugar type flavor. There is a big tingle/warming sensation on the tongue and in the throat. A wood-like flavor is met near the finish of the drink that has some light chocolate and a gentle toastedness. The finish stays with you thoughalmost a burn.

All in all its a pretty good beer with a punchy finish and some very unique flavors. Not an everyday drink, thats for sure!
Very dark, very strong. This is a very deep-flavored ale with a lot of coffee, raisin, cherry, and smokey textures. One to be enjoyed slowly on a cold evening

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2017 At a tasting, thanks Lee, pours black with a small beige head, aroma of dark chocolate, coffe, vanilla, wood and American hops, flavor of coffee, cherry and chocolate with some raisins and smokey notes, highly carbonated, medium to full body.  7/4/7/4/13[3.5] Thanks David for sharing this one, pours brown opaque with a chocolate color small head, aroma of chocolate, grapes, raisins, cherries, burbon and wood, thick texture, flavors of coffee, cardboard, cherry liquor, scotch and bitter pleasant finish, medium bodied, alcohol is a bit too high. Nice beer 8/4/7/3/15[3.7]
Bottle from Cavie.  Dark brown pour.  Fruit and chocolate aroma.  Roasted malts, chocolate, and a little smoke flavor.
Pours black with foming head like expresso. "Huge beer" best spit among friends. Complex flavers of licorice,anisitte,coffee and smoke meats. Palate lingers and leaves you fulfulled.
Pours black with foming head like expresso. "Huge beer" best spit among friends. Complex flavers of licorice,anisitte,coffee and smoke meats. Palate lingers and leaves you fulfulled.
A beautiful dark black with little head and minimal lacing. the carmel, chocolate ,vanilla and a roasty flavor are so well balanced. This beer is awsome, expensive but awsome.

pours very syrupy and very dark with no light penetration and very little head that leaves decent lacing.  smells of sweet rum raisons.  taste is a little fruitty and sweet to start and ends with a nice smokey taste.

Dark brown, thick, viscous, tan head that recedes quickly but laces nicely. Lots and lots of oakiness from the bespoke palo santo. Doesnt make much of an effort to hide its alcohol content, but that isnt so much to its detriment.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2010 I WAS SLIGHTLY INTIMIDATED BY THIS BEER WHEN I RECEIVED IT FROM THE DOGFISH BREWERY IN A VARIETY PACK, NOT ONLY BECAUSE IT IS 12%ALC BUT ALSO BECAUSE IM NOT SUPER HIGH ON OAK AGED BEERS NOR IM I THAT FOND OF MALT BEVERAGES. HOWEVER, ONCE AGAIN DOGFISH HAS PLEASANTLY SURPRISED ME. AND OVER TIME THIS HAS BECOME ONE OF MY FAVORITE BEERS AND POSSIBLY THE BEST BROWN ALE IN THE WORLD IN MY OPINION. IT POURS A ROUBUST BLACK WITH NO HEAD IT ACTUALLY LOOKS LIKE FLAT SODA AND HAS A STUNNING RAISIN TYPE AROMA ALMOST LIKE  A WINE. THE FLAVORS, LIKE THE SMELL AND LOOK, IS ALSO QUITE ROBUST YET NOT OVER POWERING,THE SWEET FLAVOR IS OF ROASTED MALTS, UNSWEETENED CHOCOLATE, SLIGHT VANILLA AND TANGY LICORICE WHICH IS WELL BALANCED WITH CARBONATION THAT ADDS A LITTLE BITE ON THE TOUNGE , IVE HAD A FEW OTHER BEERS THAT WERE SIMILAR TO THIS ONE (EX: THE BEAST) AND THIS ONE IS BY FAR MORE ENJOYABLE.. NOT RECOMMENDED FOR A NIGHT OUT AT THE BAR, BUT QUITE A GOOD AFTER DINNER BEER.

Tingling orgasmic sensation on the nose and poured a surprising dark red, almost black color with minimal lacing. Initial taste of roasted nuts, then had a finish of oak, coffee, and the slight warmth on the way down of the generous 12%. Very impressive, and I will defiantly be picking up more of these brews in the future. Cheers!

A deep dark ale with a thin moka head. Aroma of chinotto, chocolate, licorice, coffee and spices. In mouth, a  dark fruit sweetness, with some peated notes, licorice, molasses, chocolate, with anis, herbal roots, sweet rhubarb, and warming alcohol. Wow! . Bottle, shared with probstk, Sept. 12 2009.

Bottle. Poured dark brown with medium brown head  Strong woody, roasty and malty aroma.  Woody flavour, with much roast malt, a bit of anise and chocolate.  Lasting chocolate and pipe tobacco finish. LEKKER!
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: In the bottle from Downtown Johnny Browns in San Diego. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Im not sure that I understand this one. Somewhat oily with an unusual off flavor, that I can only assume comes from the wood resin. Roasted chocolate as expected. Thick body helps to stabilize these odd flavors of anise and tobacco and leather. Very earthy.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2013 Deep brown appearance with a blooming tan head that recedes to a lasting ring. Nose is caramel, chocolate, spice, and vanilla. Flavor is similar, but theres a pervasive (and delicious) graham cracker quality, and the finish is extremely long. The body is thick (but not too thick). It reminds me of Goose Island Bourbon County Stout, but not bourbony, and a little less sweet, and more drinkable. Great stuff!

Bottle from Kegs & Barrels in Plano, TX. Pours a very nice deep, dark brown with tan head. Aroma is very interesting and odd at the same time, Alcohol, an odd wood I am not familiar with, roasty, I think I detect pine as well, also a little chocolate.....just very odd. Flavor isnt much different, with alot of alcohol spice and strange woody bitter. Mouth feel is heavy body with medium carbonation. Overall, this is one of the oddest beers I have tasted and I am glad to have had it...simple but yet complex and very strong. I need to age one for a year to see what it is like. Its really fresh at the moment....

Bottle thanks to bman1113vr. Opaque brown pour with a dark beige head. Aroma is chocolate, dirt, alcohol, licorice, pepper. Flavor is cedar, tobacco, wood, pine, smoke and slightly bitter. Very interesting flavor. Syrupy mouthfeel.
A little ho-hum for me.The saving grace was the obvious "wood" presence- very interesting.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2010 12 oz bottle from Casanova.  Deep dark brown pour with a tan head.  Boozy, caramel smell. Thick sweet mouthfeel, flavor is a complex mix of caramel, hint of chocolate, almost a sherry like flavor.  Huge beer with a wonderful finish.

Noire opaque avec reflet rougeâtre. Très peu de mousse. Arômes de malt chocolat, de boisé et de brûlé. Bière complexe, offrant des saveurs de chocolat, de boisé, de brûlé et dalcool qui est bien présent. Légères touches de caramel et de vanille également présentes.
Great stuff. Very distinct malty roasted flavor. Not over powering flavor and very drinkable.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with a small light tan head that diminishes 
quickly to nothing leaving decent spotty lacing along the glass. The aroma is 
a strong roasted malt and alcohol with chocolate and cherry. Thin mouthfeel with a roasted malt taste and chocholate and brown sugar. Alcohol well hidden making it very easy to drink. A very impressive American strong ale from Dogfish Head.
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 BOTTLE: thick black pour, offwhite head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted coffee, and port. Medium body, taste is coffee, bourbon, and vanilla. Awesome.

Pours thick and a deep mahogany with a stout like creamy head. I smell chocolate, coffee and of course the wood. Picking up licorice as it warms Medium to full body like a porter or stout.  tatses sweet with espresso, cocoa and dried fruit. More like a stout than an American ale. Pretty intense flavors mask the alcohol well.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Dark brown and very malty. very harsh on the back end with alcohol.  almost competing against the lovely malt taste.

Bottle. [thank you Skortila/ceasar]
Pours deep brown with a small, staying, frothy, beige head. Lovely woody aroma, nicely roasted, chocolate, raisins, tobacco and coffee. Medium carbonation, fine lightly creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is rather sweet and sugary. Coffee, roasted, chocolate, oak, bourbon, vanilla. Warming alcohol sensation at the end. Very nice sipper, but it just a tad to sugary for my liking.

12 oz. bottle from Cork n Bottle in Covington, Kentucky.  Pours almost black with a small, uneven, bubbly brown head.  Aroma of wood, chocolate, dried dark fruits, coffee, brown sugar, malt, menthol.  Woody flavor (the bottle doesnt lie) with dark fruits, chocolate, vanilla, coffee, molasses, menthol.  Nice balance despite the complexity.  Rich, sweet, and slightly bitter, with a motor oil consistency and warming alcohol.  This is an interesting, satisfying beer that I love to try with a few people.

Bottled, SBWF 2009. 
Near black colour with brown head. Rich, spicy nose: fünf kräuter, menthol, eucalyptus, ginger, juniper, clove, very complex. Flavourwise like a stout with menthol och variation of x-mas herbs. Mouthfeel is very rounded. Not sure what the Palo Santo wood did to this beer, except for an elegant woody touch along with a mature flavour.

Newer Bottle. 
Pitch black with a thin, bubbly tan head. 
Aroma of chocolate, dark fruit, wood, a bit of coffee and cream. Also raisins. 
Woody, chocolate and fruit flavor. Cherries and raisins. Coffee and vanilla. Very woody and roasted. Very fruity into the mid-palate, and quite sweet, with vanilla, then this is all washed away by alcohol, which leads to a well-roasted, bitter finish. The mid-palate fruitiness is very niceapproaching a real German schnapps or a grappa. Lovely palate, thick and smooth but not too heavy. Barely carbonated. Fantastic and complex. Best beer Ive had from them to date.

Bottle, provided and shared by Kestral.  A dark brown to near black colored body, topped by a low, brown head. Delicious malt aroma; gently sweet and peppery with a fine, rounded rostedness. A whiff of of cream-caramel, wood and subtle spices. Taste is full malty, has a pure sweetness, and again, a well rounded roastedness. Notes of wood, dark dried fruits and Christmas spices. Full-bodied with a pleasant alcohol warmth in the mouth. Spiced, malty ending. Complex, powerfull and very tasty.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2011 From the bottle. Poured a very dark color, darker than most imperial stouts in fact. There is some moderate carbonation with a half finger of head.
