The taste was much more typical of wood barrel aged beers than the smell.  I got a dash of vanilla, some sweet gummy flavors, a little chocolate, and a sour finish.  I was somewhat disappointed that the alcohol was not hidden at all.  I think this has some rough edges still which beg to be smoothed out by more aging.  The mouthfeel was creamy and oily and the body was a little thicker than I was anticipating.  Not a bad foray into wood aged beers, but more time is needed to mellow this baby out.

Pours out a nice slightly reddish hued dark brown with a small brown head. Aroma is earthy with some caramel and wood. Flavor is very complex, vanilla, roasted malt, slight chocolate, caramel and wood. Leathery notes here and the finish. I liked this one.

12 oz bottle shared by Odeed; nose is spicy with caramel, and a veryl ight vanilla note (woody); the woodiness being unlike any other wood aged beer I have tried. Odeed thought cedary but i have had cedar aged sakes and this was different; cloudy very dark brown with a medium beige head; flavor had vanillin (wood), light hop bitterness, spices, and a chocolate background
brown with red highlights.small brown head.aroma of cinnamon,and cedar wood.flavor is cinnamon,allspice,and cedar wood.strange and not very tasty.

Thanks to a few people for sending me bottles of this.  Pours brown with a tan head.  Aroma was faint,  but I got woody caramel and vanilla.  Flavor carried the same quality with vanilla and roasted chocolate as well.  Slightly boozy,  but a clean finish.  Interesting enough.  I might set one down for awhile and see what happens.
Indian Brown with bigger alcohol(though not that noticeable) and some light woody notes. A groovy brew that might age well. Nice DVD too.

Courtesy of Naka. Pours a very dark brown with faint red hues and a thin tan head. Spicy and woody aroma with strong molasses notes, and hints of brown sugar, soy sauce, dirty change, roasted malts and coffee. Super potent molasses flavor, with brown sugar, coffee, woody, smoky, vinous, and fruity notes. Incredibly complex, but incredibly delicious. Oily and slick mouthfeel. Basically a head on crash between a baltic porter and a foreign stout.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2008 Wetn to pick up a cheese steak and stop in the store next to the place and saw this in the fridge. Dark brown with small fizzy mocha colored head. Malty, vanilla,maple, and wood aroma and tatste. Light banana and alicohol in the finish. This is a good beer, however, the woody flavor started to make me sick.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark blackish-brown with a chocolatey head that quickly recedes to a thin collar.

The aroma is sweet fudgy chocolate and some wood, coffee and alcohol.

The flavor is baking chocolate, vanilla and fudge and a slight hint of fruits followed by a slightly bitter, strongly alcoholic finish.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied with a little sharp carbonation.

Overall, the alcohol is a bit harsh.  If it was as noticeable (or high), this would be a pretty decadent dessert drink.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2009 Bottle. Pours a deep dark brown with a tan head that begins thick, but dies down quickly. The glass is coated with an oily lace. I know that they call this a brown ale, but I dont think that it can be put into a specific style(brown ale, imperial porter, stout,???) Aroma of sweet caramel malt, coffee, vanilla, and dark fruit(almost like a Belgian influence). Flavor is vanilla dominant, with tastes of coffee, molasses, and dark fruit. The wood is definitely having an effect on things. This is a truly unique beer, but at 12%, and overly malty sweet, consumption will be very limited.

Bottle - Pours a dark coffee like brown color with a medium brown head. Nice malted coffee aromas, with the slightest hint of fruit. Smooth coffee/chocolate flavor with hints for fruit and definitely some woody notes. Very drinkable considering the 12%, only a hint of alcohol at the end of a sip. Very enjoyable overall.

12 0z. bottle courtesy of Naka.  Pours cola-esque with little, soda-like head.  Nse is roasted malt with chocolate and some woody notes.  Very Stout-esqe, export to be specific, lots of roast and chocolate, some caramel with some fruity undertones, touch of plum and raisin.  There is interesting woody character.  Nice oily, slick mouthfeel.   Slight alcohol throughout and in after.  Pretty good.  Could use a bit more bottle aging.

From bottle courtesy of Naka. Deep malty aroma, with woody character, sandalwood spicy. Light cinammon (sort of) and mild sweetness. Alcohol vapors, rubbing alcohol, and a dirty nickel. Dark, dark brown-black, clear, with thin foamy lacing light-tan head. Medium-heavy body, with medium carbonation. Starts spicy, with malty goodness, oak chips and sandalwood. Malty, chocolate, alcohol, pepper. Lots of body with fairly complex character. Dry, like a porter or foreign stout. Chocolate dry nutty finish, with mild coffee-anise undertones. A bit hot yet, but fairly tasty.

12oz, @ 4bucks a bottle, i thought this would be superb. however, this one pours a deep brown almost stout like color, yielding a traditional brown ale type flavor, fruits and malt however there is something more here,  a sort of woody finish.... exhale reveals some alcohol presences, although sippable not slam-able... needs about a year or 2 methinks.

12oz bottle.  Deep black color.  Sweet, fresh, and spicy aroma.  Flavor is sweet and unique.  Lots of different flavors going on.  Raisins, coffee, cocoa, brown sugar..very interesting pungent brew.  Very mellow for 12%, but after a few sips the alcohol warming becomes noticeable.  An innovative, impressive beer.

12oz bottle. Pours a very dark, opaque brown (almost black) - like espresso. The head is brown, thin, and short-lived (though it leaves lace on the glass). The head blossoms into a full foam after swirling the beer in the snifter, releasing the aromas as well as the dissolved carbon dioxide. The aroma is strong and very dessert-liquer-like: alcohol, fruit (banana, plum), malts, and subtle notes of roasted grain (dark chocolate). Swirling to release the aromas causes slightly acetic notes to come forth. The flavor starts strong with alcohol and strong with dark grains - dark chocolate and coffee. There are some vinous qualities to the strong, fruity malts that the front of the palate encounters. The middle of the tongue finds more residual sweetness and flavors of chocolate-covered caramels - but more decadent thanks to the complex esters and high level of alcohol. The finish is full with lots of roast and sweetness and warming. The mouthfeel is unexpectedly bubbly - almost stinging from the combo of high alcohol and high carbonation. Swirling in the glass releases more carbon dioxide until the beer has a nice, creamy, more subtly carbonated texture. Overall, a decadent and delicious brew. It tasted more Baltic Porter-ish than strong brown ale-ish - though 12% is way higher a typical Baltic Porter...
dark brown with tan head.  huge flavor of a rich brown ale, with caramel malt predominate, finishes with a roasted oakey finish.  very powerful and hides the alcohol very well.  very good

12 oz bottle.  Very dark brown, if not black pour.  Minimal head.  Tons of wood and vanilla in the aroma with alcohol, and coffee.  The flavor is quite nice.  A dark full bodied brew with plenty of malt with fruit notes, coffee, and roasted grain.  There could be some other flavors in there but they are subtleVanilla and cola come to mind.  Carbonated lingering medium moth feel that has a some what semi-oily body.  This is pretty good.  I bet it will age like a champ.

Pours black into a snifter.  Mocha head recedes leaving tears as it recedes to skim surface. Sweet caramel and oak aromas.  Sweet dried pit fruit and cocoa with a charcoal oak finish.  Like an old ale.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2008 12 oz bottle from Bev4less in Santee. This one pours an opaque black color with a small tan head. The aroma is big and bold with cherries, plums, brown sugar, dark chocolate and butterscotch. The flavor is more subdued as compared to the aroma. I taste plenty of dark fruits, a goodly amount of black walnuts, tobacco and biter chocolate. The mouthfeel is smooth, full and creamy. The finish is long with lingering biter-sweet cocoa. Overall:  I’m glad this did not come in a 750ml bomber--this is way powerful stuff. Memorable and Recommended.

like indian brown to the max!!!! pours very dark brown with a medium foamy tan head. aroma - caramel, vanilla, oak, coffee, brown sugar, slight chocolate.  taste - malty sweet, brown sugar, vanilla, butterscotch, raisins, aged wood, hints of smoke, port wine. palate - very rich and smooth - just the right amount of carbonation. alcohol present but not overpowering which is awesome considering its 12%. finish - some licorice and coffee and lingering sweetness. love love love this beer, but considering the price and alc%, ill stick to the indian brown and save this for special occasions.

Bottle. Pours black with a creamy tan head and some decent lacing. Aroma of roasted malts, wood, dark fruit, vanilla, and a hint of smoke. Flavor is very smooth and complex with dark fruit, caramel sweetness, roasted malts, oak, vanilla and a touch of brown sugar. Full bodied with a dry and bittersweet finish. Another stellar beer from DFH

deep brown color, thin tan head.  aroma is rosted coffee, chocolate, smoke.  flavor is weakly reminicent of old coffee.   not much of a trace of the high alcohol.   bittersweet chocolate finish.  not all that exciting to me. sampled in <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=1 

rayboy01s living room after <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/brewers/rock-bottom-c 

Rock Bottom Chicago First Annual <a 

href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Events-Detail.asp ROCK 

FEST
toasty hot dark fruits with coco-vanilla bitter bite.are too green. give it some time

Poured from a 12oz bottle (bottled on 2/11/08) and served in a snifter.  This beer poured a glossy black/dark brown with a thin head of tan foam that slightly lasted throughout the glass.  A decent amount of slippery lacing was left behind.  The aroma of the beer was made up of molasses, charred wood, dark fruits, mild chocolate, and some earthy yeast esthers.  The flavor included chocolate, caramel, wet wood, and charred malt.  The mouthfeel was slick and full-bodied with mild carbonation.  A decent beer, but kind of tame by Dogfish Heads standards of risk taking.  The beer had a nice roasty flavor, but wasnt all that interesting.

Dark color.  Smell of roasted malt, smoke, berries, molasses and minor coffee.  Taste of roasted coffee, chocolate, malt, cherries, plums, raisins, oak, molasses, hops and alcohol.  This really gets you at the end.  Different but enjoyable.

Interesting experiment.  The exotic Paraguayan hard wood adds a moderate oaky quality to the beer, which is sweet and alcoholic...notes of dark fruits, dates, and roasted grains,  Alcoholic finish has a boozy quality to it that makes a lingering  final impression.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2008 Dark brown pour, medium brown head. Aroma is woody. Flavor is lightly roasted malts, a touch of chocolate and a little caramel, all you want in a brown ale but there is a great oak presence throughout with a touch of vanilla. Some coffee lingers and a bit of smoke, but its all brown ale with oak and vanilla. Very smooth and no way would you know this is 12%.

Pours a dark dark brown with a tall light brown head. Very fruity, mainly apple, aroma with scents of coffee, wood, and alcohol mixed in too. Very short but delicious sweet fruit taste at first that blends well into a powerful coffee body and smooth licorice/espresso finish. Very good beer.
Pours black with a fine, tan head. Aroma is slightly sweet and malty. Full mouth feel with a smoky, woody flavor. Sweet and smoky, kind of in a weird barbecue way.

Bottle. Pours black with a tan head. Smell is dark fruit, alcohol, and a hint of wet dog. There is a nice sweetness at first with coffee on the finish. Hides the alcohol well, but the warmth in the belly is there. Hint of vanilla too.

12 oz bottle from South Bay Drugs. This poured as a very dark and black stout color with a fizzed layer of heading. The initial nose was hard to determine what exactly made it smell so good since there was so much going on in my memory of scents. Basically, I can find a medium roasted malt and perhaps vanilla with an underlining presence of the wood used to age this ale. The flavor is robust and difficult to pin point what are the strong characteristics that stand out but it did hold a sweet molasses syrup and caramel malt with a very minor roasted flavor and a brief reminder of the wood again. Certainly an interesting ale? Stout? Malt liquor?

bottle - Pours very dark amber with just a trace of foam around the edge of the glass.  It has a superb aroma with notes of cherry, vanilla, oak, and some alcohol.  The flavor is of roasted malt, vanilla, oak, and some mild dark fruit notes.  Its sweet and full bodied with the ABV that provides a warming finish to this excellent sipper.  This beer is another great example of what makes DFH by far the most creative brewery I know.
12 oz bottle shared by Padrefan98 in the Lost abbey release party line.  Smokey and porterish aromas with roasty flavors too.  Some dark fruits and vanilla.  Pretty tasty.

Wow. Pour is nothing short of perfect. Nice, tight and light khaki head. Beer is black. No light escapes the snifter, negating the claim of a "brown ale". Not that theres anything wrong with that. When you use chocolate and black malts, expect this. Nose of sour and wood (equally), as well as black patent malt notes of cofee and roast. Some mollases in there as well. Balanced and light.  Flavor is more of the same with a surprisingly medium body; expecting the fuller body for the alcohol level, but realizing that the dry finish is a result of the yeast having their way, resulting in a very complex beer. Almost a chili pepper finish. Wow. A fluke Im sure the brewery didnt expect. Different and welcome. A lighter bodied and more drinkable high gravity beer is a nice surprise when stacked up to so many thick, syrupy dark beers these days. Not that I dont love them, but this beer has the complexity, medium body and reputation of the brewery to back up my rating. Should age beautifully.

Huh?  Not an imperial stout?!?  Looks like one, smells like one, tastes more like a foreign stout, but close enough!  Oh well!  Pours a very dark brown with a healthy light tan head.  The nose is sweet and roasty ala imperial stout, but I notice a strong hint of fruit upon further inspection.  A hint of cinnamony chocolate to boot.  Light licorice laced alcohol.  The mouthfeel is on par with imperial stouts.  Full rich and creamy, with relatively subdued carbonation.  The flavor is strongly imperial stout, particularly as it warms up.  Sweet chocoate over raisins, a good dose of coffee.  A bit of alcohol, to but that rich creamy sweetness.  But the finish is much more tannic, sharp, acidic.  Light on the tongue in flavor.  Figgy alcohol really, especially in the drier than expected finish.  Rather enjoyable.  The wood seems subtle.  I wonder how this will age... I hope to find out!

12oz bottle.
Pours an opaque dark brown with an effervescent, bubbly tan head that gradually disappears. Aroma reveals light roasted coffee and grains, a bit of toffee and some raisin. Flavor starts with an intense burst of dry, roasted grain and some wood notes, though Id never know this was wood-aged if I hadnt read the label -- tastes like a straight-up coffee porter. Some malt sweetness and dried fruit comes on later, followed by a slight numbing of the mouth and gums from the alcohol. Palate is thick and a bit grainy/chalky. Interesting stuff indeed.

12 oz bottle.  Pours nearly black with a dark red tint and 1.5 cm tan head that is bubbly and quickly diminishing.  Aroma of wine, wood, and dark fruit.  Initial flavor of aged wine and cherries.  Flavor ends more woody and alcoholic.  Light to medium body, limited lacing, lasting aftertaste, and strong alcohol presence.  Limited drinkability based on alcohol level and personal dislike for wine, but a nice job on specialty beer.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2009 Pours almost black with a thick dark, tan head.  Looks like an imperial stout.  Very complex aroma, with notes of wine, vanilla, licorice, spices, and wood.  Taste is equally rich and complex.  Very smooth.  Velvety mouth feel.   Almost like a cross between a Quad and a RIS.  Hides the alcohol very well.   Finish lacks big bitterness.  Thats about the only complaint I have about this one.  Extremely nice offering from DFH.  Curious why this isnt rated highter.

Pours an impenetrably dark brown body with a dinkus tan head that quickly reduces to a slender ring around the glass.  No lace.  The aroma is dark roasty malts, old caramel, charred wood (Is it really palo santo?), and cold coffee.  Mayhaps some bittersweet chocolate and dried fruit are added to the flavor.  Mayhaps not.  The strong ABV never rears its head during the drinking.  Its not bad, but Im underwhelmed, given DFHs attempt at hype on this one.  Nothing special contributed by the "exotic" wood.  Nothing really special at all.  Just a solid, somewhat murky strong Brown Ale (the notes didnt indicate how DFH had achieved a 12% ABV) with a dark wood addition.  Maybe, as the inevitable <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=1 had voiced, a little aging would help.  Maybe not.  Ill lay a bottle down for half a year or so and see.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL<font size=-1>

Pours a very dark brown almost black with a small brown head. Aroma of Alcohol and wood. This beer tasted inverted to me as the boozy part came through first but ended with a nice bunrt coffee/wood aftertaste.

Definitely young...and literally aging will do a body good.  This beer is dark bordering black with very small caramel head.  Aroma is sticky sweet.  Loved the thought process behind creating a unique brew using raw wooden barrels but their impact on the flavor was minimal at best.  I just didnt get the overwhelming "woodsy" flavor or aroma.  Instead, roasted malt, raisins, and toffee with hints of chocolate are prominent.  Enjoyed the DVD more than the beer.

12oz bottled 2/18/08. pours very dark brown with creamy tan head. aroma has some port wine, toffee, coffee roast, and cherries. flavors are toffee, nutty, mild oak and cherry notes, chocolate and coffee towards the end while a sweet alcohol flavor finishes it out. body a touch thin. this just doesnt sit that well.

12 oz bottle - Pours a dark brown/black color with almost non existant light tan head. Aroma is full of blackstrap molasses, toasted raisens, dates and figs, red grapes, dark chocolate, roasted coffee, definite woody vanilla, hint of cherry and burbon. Flavor is full of chewy malts, faint dark chocolate, notes of raisens and figs tossed in burbon, vanilla bean, fair amount of medium caramel, touch of cherry and oak, hint of alcohol, with a finish just on the sweet side of balanced. Overall a nice brew - strong, woody, complex. I cant say that it truly hides its alcohol, but it doesnt seem quite as strong as 12%.

Pours very dark almost black, with small tan head. Aroma is very complex, roasted malts, chocolate, wood and dried fruits. The flavor is outstanding, initial burst of the roasty, chocolaty malts, transitioning nicely to the woody vanilla and dark fruits. Overall sweet palate, but not too sweet, very smooth and has great balance.  Wouldnt believe that it was 12% alcohol if it wasnt printed on the label. Im usually not a huge fan of DFHs more creative brews but this one is a winner.

(bottle) Wow. Another great beer from DFH. Almost black with very small dark tan head. Faint aroma of roasted malts, dark fruits. Flavor is complex - reminded me of a toned-down version of World Wide Stout - roast malts, coffee, dark fruits. You taste the wood, but it is very different from oak that many beers are now flavored in. Outstanding beer.
Bottle.  Black pour with virtually no head.  Aroma of raisins, chocolate and wood.  Taste of bread, sweet sugar and apples with some alcohol present.

pours an opaque almost black color (dark mahogany at the edges) with a frothy light brown head that leaves light lacing. aromas of chocolate, wood, malt, dark dried fruit, a light alcohol burn, toasted nuts and something vegetal akin to cactus paddles or prickly pears... lots of warming flavors... chocolate, vanilla cream, roasted nuttiness, coffee, caramel/tequila qualities, dark raisins and malt with a very light ash. luckily the palate isnt overly sweetened and the wood character is well integrated. theres a long lingering fruitiness similar to raisins with coffee mixed in. full bodied  with a creamy velvety texture like melted chocolate with a touch of cream added to it...

Bottle. How the hell am I supposed to know what Palo Santo wood smells like? Looks and smells kinda like their Chicory Stout. This one has Dogfish written all over it. Ill tell you what though, Ive had 6% beers that burn more than this one going down. DFH calls this one a brown ale, RB says its an ASA and it reminds me of a stout. Despite that, its not as "unique" as I had hoped. This is a tasty beer, but I feel like I need to find a new favorite brewery.

12 oz bottle sampled at Market Cross Shippensburg: Beer poured like an imperial stout and looked very thick coming out of the bottle.  poured brown with a small tan head.  Aroma was great, lots of wood, vanilla, some roastiness.  Flavor was even better, the roastiness of the grains and flavor of the wood really combind harmoniously in this beer.  Notes of vanilla, toffee, and brown sugar as well.  On the finish the wood really did shine.  Brown sugar enter the aroma very prominitely towards the end of the glass.  Good stuff.

Pitch black, nearly purple. Toasted brown, oily looking head. Smells of coffee, chocolate, peat moss and cedar. Oily taste, with coffee, chocolate, thin but oily, lots of alcohol. I wasnt wowed by this, and not sure what makes this an american strong ale, unless its the +10% alcohol. $10.25 for a 12oz snifter didnt sit too well with me either.

Bottle. Pours rather thick and a very deep brown.  The head is small and dark tan with cascades rolling beneath it from a tilt or swirl. For some reason I was really expecting a lighter bodied brew. I guess I dont know DFH well enough. The aroma is very nice and malty. Suggestions of tobacco, earth, nuts, and a deep woodiness are present. I wouldnt know this actually included wood unless I read it on the label, but it definitely makes sense. The flavor is heavy and malty, kind of meaty even. A soft, caramelized sweetness hits the palate first. Then the brew transitions to complex wooden tones before culminating in a earthy, meaty, almost smoky finish. Drinking this beer makes me think it would pair excellently with a cigar. A few sips brings out faint hints at ripe fruits, but this is still all about the arbor character. 12 % abv is hidden exceptionally well. There are quite a few crazy brews DFH puts out that I just dont care for. This is one of the others that makes me keep trying them anyway.

Strong tangy malt taste with mild and light wood. Very dark brown color with a medium brown head. Deep malt beginning with light tanginess of wood. Moderate bodied. Complex but still easy to drink. 12% alcohol hidden very well.
12 oz bottle of 12 percent sweetness. This was a nice surprise from DFH. Very tasty! Some vanilla and smokey wood. Awesome!

Appearance: Pours a dark brown body with a creamy-looking, tan head.

Smell: Rich, blended aroma of cocoa powder, smokey wood, molasses, black currants, and a beefy Argentina red wine.

Taste: Intense, chewy maltiness with flavors of with chocolate, molasses, and light coffee all with a medium sweetness. Black currant jam fruitiness. Subtle, earthy wood component. The palo santo adds to the complexity of the brew, sure, but doesnt really bash you in the head with wood. Hints of vanilla, green peppercorns, and red wine. Light touch of acidity. Rather restrained hop bitterness. Finishes semi-sweet with a touch of spice.

Mouthfeel: Medium-full body. Medium carbonation. Smooth mouthfeel.

Drinkability: Very enjoyable. The 12% is quite well hidden within this fine beer. The palo santo wood really brings a little some extra to the beer, like when they give you extra peanuts on a flight.
Pours a deep brown color with a brown head.  Aroma is herbal, spicy, malt, roast, chocolate, and some hops.  Flavor is roast, chocolate, herbal, spicy, sugar, and a slight alcohol finish.

Pours a dark brown with a 1/2" tan head. Spotty lacing. Light spice, woody, and light chocolate aromas. Flavors of roasted malts, very light hops, light spice, and chocolate. Smooth, good beer, but you can taste the alcohol in it.
user_location: Mescal Lakes (wherever that is), Arizona, USA

text: I nearly poured this one down the drain, but after letting it sit for a bit, it has improved.  Like all of the DFH beers, this is a big, huge alcoholic beverage.  Flavor is very much dopplebock-like.   Soy sauce is the predominant character.  Kind of reminds me of Sam Adams Triple Bock, although not nearly as strong or putrid as that stuff. This is the kind of beer you simply cant drink everyday.  The flavor is relatively nice, but there is simply too much going on.   Props to DFH for their experimentation, I just wish I could enjoy their beers more.  This would be good on a bed of rice.....

From bottle : Pours a carbonated black color, with a light brown fizzy half finger of head, that lasts about 30 seconds, then falls to a ring, with some bubbles in the middle.  I love the smell of this one.  Dark fruit, wood, alcohol, vanilla...there is some kinda complexity going on here, and it is really nice.  You get something new and different with every whiff.  Taste is roasted wood, chocolate, some alcohol, and more dark fruits.  Medium body with a smooth as hell feel on the tounge.  Aftertaste is slightly roasted with some alcohol notes.  Very enjoyable

Bottle poured an opaque dark brown with a small diminishing brown head. Aromas of wood, chocolate, vanilla, carmel and light fruittiness. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of chocolate, light vanilla, light caremel and a hint of wood with a smooth bittersweet finish.

In some ways reminiscent of an imperial stout, but still so different in so many ways.  It pours deep, deep brown and viscous-looking, with a butterscotch-colored head.  The wood aroms leap out of the glass.  Initial taste impressions are suggestions of caramel. licorice, a hint of chocolate and dates.  And big roastiness at the core.  But the overall impression is more of an "imperial brown ale," with those great, and yet not overpowering, wood flavors.  The alcohol makes itself noticed in a lingering dryness at the end.  Just when I feared DFH might be running out of creative territories to explore, they come up with this gem.  Nice work.  Highly recommended.

Very dark brown with just a glint of chestnut on the edges when held to the light. Modest light tan head that dissipates to a thin, tiny bubble lid. and thicker lace. For some reason I was not expecting something this dark. Earthy darker malts and sweet mild coffee are the base scents that I catch. A few hints of vanilla extract and some dark cherries. Nothing too extraordinary, but now seeing that this is 12%, there is no sign of this being a big burly brew. Now the flavor is another story. Molasses and lightly burnt sugar in the start. Spiced fruit cake in the middle, with cinnamon, plums, dark raisins and just a hint of dark rum. Dry slightly woody finish and linger. Tight carbonation, which works well with the thicker, somewhat chewy, lip smacking, liquid. Long mild spice linger. Touch of warmth in the stomach, otherwise I would say this cant be 24 proof.

Dark brownish black, thick creamy tan head.    Complex toasted woody brown sugar aromas warm to notes of vanilla coated raisins, earthy caramel, and hints of chocolate.  Intense dry wood and nutty earth flavors balance on waves of toasted vanilla beans and touches of roasted brown sugar.  Room temp brings out further chocolate and caramel tones that slowly round into a light hop ending.  ABV is warming, yet it never intrudes.  Full bodied and oily, soft carbonation, Shara dry finish.  This one is hit out of the park!  Well done...

12oz bottle from BevMo Mission Valley.  Opaque in color, head was taken from Willy Wonkas chocolate river........lol.  Poured a lot darker than I was expecting.  Lots of wood, chocolate and dark fruits on the nose.  The beer overall had great balance, another  great on from DFH!!

100th rating of this beer. 12 oz. brown, longneck bottle. No freshness date seen. Poured out a deep inky chocolate brown, with a small ring of mocha foam for a head. Aromas are of strong roasted malts, alcohol, woodiness, not unlike oak chips. Flavors are roasted malts, strong alcohol, wooden whiskey barrels, earthy hops. Thick, rich mouthfeel reveals wine notes at the end.
Decent experimental beer overall.

Bottle.  Pours deep brownish black with 2-fingers of gorgeous dark tan bimodal head...great look on this one.  The aroma is very complex; a meshing of dark malt, oaky notes, chocoff, nuts, dark fruit.  The palate is complex, silky, rich, with very well hidden alcohol.  Flavors of creamy malt, brown sugar, raisins, nuts, and chocolate are apparent, with the raisiny notes increasing as it warms.  The last dregs bring with them a very unique woody flavor that I have not encountered before.  This is a wonderful new offering from DFH, and I give them continued credit for pushing the envelope of beer crafting.

Very unique aroma, pine resin, vanilla, and a touch of red wine.  Pours an opaque brown, with a small tan head that leaves good lacing behind.  Fairly tart flavor, with a touch of residual sweetness giving a fruit balance.  A bit light on the mouthfeel.  Very tasty, but very expensive as well.

Pours beautiful dark brown with tan head.  Aroma of wood... dark, roasty wood.  Also some smoke and chocolate.  Flavor of chocolate, roasted wood, chicory, nutty yeast.  The aging brings about a slightly citrus flavor, or acid of some sort, that cuts through the heavy malts.  A great beer.

bottle.  bought four pack.  it came with a dvd that explains the brewing process, palo santo wood, and DFH philosophy.  Great beer and great marketing.  It was neat to get an inside look at how they brew.  black with thin head.  chicory, smoke, rich sugars, roasted matls and alcohol aroma.  rich, nicely balanced, coffee, dark chocolate bread.  very nutty.  unique woody taste.  peppery bitterness.  Well done.

12oz via trade with OldStyleCubFan.  Pours blackish brown with a thin tan ring for a head.  Nose is sweet and woody, the wood is pretty prounounced.  Taste is very rich, sweet, and malty.  The wood is omniprescent here, and the alcohol is nicely hidden, in a pretty damn nice overall brew.  Taste is really rich and big, and the wood is really there in full effect.

Pretty black with thin head; not too impressive on the aroma but rich taste with smooth malt, licorice, coffee, chocolate; not too much wood flavor picked up; clean finish; well balanced w/ the high ABV.

Black used harley oil appearance. This stuff has a thin choco mousse head.  No ffensive volatile odor considering the ABV.  First taste impression is taste bud rape and plunder. However, as the session continues, it almost becomes bearable on the palate.  Must be some kinda numbing effect. Certainly treading on imp stout territory here. Not quite as terrible as the ABV would predict. But this stuff is till rude and ornery. Will not buy again but I was glad to have the chance to try this brew. Alky bitter medicine linger.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottled, from the PP Shop. Deep black-brown color that pours still, with some fine beige bubbles. Smoky aroma of vanilla liqueur, rich and spicy wood notes, some hoppy pine resin and ground coffee beans. Flavor follows up the aroma with robust blackened malts, vanilla and molasses. The wood aging is not prevalent over the entire taste experience, but its there. The flavors end with a modest, lasting bitterness. I got a bit of a metallic character through the first half of the bottle, but improved with warmth. Alcohol is cloaked really well, tastes more like 8-10% range.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2009 Appearance is brown with a creamy brown head.  Nose of caramel, wood, and alcohol.  Taste is malty with some light vanilla and wood.   Finish is lightly bitter.  Not as good as I had hoped, but not bad.  Probably not worth the 12.99 for a 4 pack. *** Update *** A year and a half later, this brew is drinking much smoother.  The wood has really been toned down, and there is little - or no -  alcohol burn.  Same great wood, vanilla, and caramel notes.  Drinking a little more like an oaked imperial stout.  Very nice.

12 z bottle from Firewaters. First off this beer was served waaay too cold. Poured black with a mocha brown head. Chocolate aroma with only slight hint of wood that maybe was subdued from the frigid temp. Malty flavor with lots chocolate sweetness, vanilla and slight wood. Finishes with slight bitterness and no trace of the 12% alcohol. Nice beer that I will have to try again at a temp that allows all the flavors to show.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2009 Bottle gifted by Dr. McD - thank you sir!  Was nice to check up on this and it was much darker and roastier than I remember.  Color was dark brown, the wood tasted much darker this time - much less green.  The fruit tasted overripe this time, and married with roastiness and wood created a much thicker and stouter bev.  Very unique.

Bottle from BevMo. Pretty much black in color upon pouring. Roasted malty aroma. Some coffee and chocolate along with a hint of vanilla and alcohol. Strong roasted malty flavor. Some bitter coffee. Some sweet sugary milkiness. Some hop character. Finish is a somewhat spiced woody thing. Well hidden alcohol. Tastes like a sweet impy stout to me.

Very complex nose.  Woodsie-type smell, like oak, sweet.  Taste is also complex, very sweet and malty, slight roastiness.  Can tell this is aged in wood.  Slight flavor of tannins from wood.  %12 abv is extremely well hidden.  Wood aging adds a very pleasureable complexity to a typically uncomplex style.  Hints of vanilla or molasses, very smooth and easy to drink.  Id like to try a few more of these with age.

!2 oz Bottle Color is very stout like with a strong smell of chocolate and wood undertone. Flavor was a nutty sweetness with also a wood undertone.For being 12 % the alcohol was well hidden behind the complexity of this beer. When sampled this beer was 20 days old cant wait to see how this one will test in a year or two. Not quite World Wide of 120 but still another home run for Dogfish IMO

Dark red/brown, almost opaque, with a medium sized brown head that doesnt last long. Nose is complicated--salty, fairly sweet, a bit of alcohol, some carob and caramel, and slight tannic notes. Flavor is quite sweet, with a nice banana overtone, marked bitterness, and an earthy aftertaste. Slightly tart, almost oaky hints in there, as well as cherries and prunes. Mouthfeel is a bit chalky, and its overcarbonated right now. Might do well to get a bit of age on this one.

I was expecting something more akin to Jiahu and Fort from this beer, and was grateful not to get it!  I thought this beer was excellent.  Those others I mentioned...not so much.

Appearance of this was a dark red-black color.  Head was tan and interacted strangely with my glass, as if it were trying to eat through it.  Aroma was extremely roasty with lots of great "burned pizza crust" character. Flavor was also very roasty, but had an extremely floral note and some red wine grapiness also.  Most really roasty beers are just that; it takes a lot of flavor to balance with some fruit.  Mouthfeel was quite smooth but not thick...I didnt get the feeling this beer would coat the back of a spoon but it wasnt flat or watery.

I would highly recommend this beer.

12oz. bottle. Black with virtually no head.
Mild roasted malt aroma with a bit of coffee, vanilla and dark chocolate. Little to no wood detected in the nose. The flavor, on the other hand, is big time wood. Sweet, but not overly so, with a more roasted malt presence than the aroma would lead me to believe. Vanilla, chocolate and strong alcohol kick. Odd plasticy, astringent  aftertaste takes a lot away from my enjoyment of this beer.

Tasted at 2008 Woodshop hosted by cquiroga.  A little bit of smoke.  Dark Brown Black Color.  Dryish.  Alcohol nose present.  Roasty. Not as flavorful as I would like.  Decent, but pales in comparison to Immort Ale I just had a couple of nights ago, IMHO.

Bottled on 02/1//08. Beer is very dark reddish-brown. Nearly opaque. Head is large, light rosy-brown frothy/creamy. Diminishes steadily, mostly, but ultimately lasts. Bit of lacing echoes former high-water mark of head.

The aroma has a unique signature. First impression: Reminds me of the way "outside" smelled on Hawaii. Its malty with moderate notes of roasted grain, lighter notes of chocolate and caramel, evocation of starchy rice wine; Hoppy with light-to-moderate notes of herbal resin, lemon zest; Yeasty with a light note of sourdough; Light miscellaneous notes of savory citrus-laced wood, cedar, olive oil, peppery alcohol.

The flavor is moderately-to-heavily sweet, lightly acidic with a long, warm, lightly bitter, lightly-to-moderately sweet, lightly acidic finish.

The body is full, the texture is velvety/creamy and the carbonation is average.

Unique, compelling. A bit too rich to session with, but great to taste.

12oz bottle from SBD. Pours super dark brown, som elight shows through. Crispy tan head yjay fades quick and leaves no lace. Smells dark and roasty along with some dark sweet fruitiness. Tastes sweet and roasty, like chocolate covered raisins, in a good way. Thick across the palate but not too heavy. The flavors really break up the thickness well. Very tasty brew, worth a try for sure.

12oz bottle. Aroma of wood and smoke and a good dose of sweet malt. Black body with tan head and decent lacing. Body texture wos thick rich malt with some cherry and somewhere in the mix of the flavor thought of vegitable beats. Smooth enjoyable brew with some alcohol warming.

pours a dense black color, some red shining through under direct light (jsut barely though), with nice tan head, very stout like in appearance. As the head falls back it leaves some nice sticky lacing around the glass. Aroma is rich and sweet with nice notes of woodyness, slight spicyness of alcohol, and dark fruits. All of the aromas blend together quite well to form a richly well balanced, and slightly hard to pick through,  aroma. Onset is nice blend of woody sweetness and just the right amount of bitterness, not to say that this is any way a bitter beer, just weel balanced. Slightly raisiny, again woody, some smoke, and definite alcohol in the middle. Starts out incedibly smooth and silky, somewhat beefy, then turning into a pleasant woody dryness on the finish. Vanilla and pepper also play a role in this complex sipper. Finsih lingers a while turning to bitter sweet dark chocolate late in the finish. This does need some time to figure itself out and I think it is rating less than its potential as a result. Perhaps DFH should have sat on this one a while before release,m though I am excited to have tasted it at such a young age. I have six more for the years to come... perhaps one every six months. We shall see.

I was very surprised when the beer hit the glass. It ws very dark in color. Very similar to am imperial stout. Not too much carbonation or head. The smell was sweet with hints of bourbon. The mouthfeel was slilky smooth then turned very dry. Thus beer is still young and will gain alot with age. A big brown ale with potential.

12 oz. bottle on 3/3/2008. Opaque brown/black pour with a substantial, creamy brown head and some good lace. Prominent woody aroama thats right up front, with notes of vanilla, dark fruit, and alcohol. Thick, rich mouthfeel with alittle chewiness, but not sticky. Roasted malt sweetness that is balanced by some burnt caramel bitterness. Finishes with a pleasing dryness. Another winner from DFH.

This brew pours dark brown (nearly black) with a medium thin and fizzy light brown head that recedes quickly. Spotty lacing. Lots of roasted malt in the aroma, along with plum, oak and alcohol. Rich body with flavors of burnt malt, hops, toasted bread and dark fruits. Alcohol is present but not overpowering. The finish is oaky and leaves a lingering malt and liqueur aftertaste. Very good from start to finish.

Bottle.  An interesting concept of a beer to say the least, and I know that DFH is very familiar with going out on a limb as far as brewing is concerned.  Pours out a dark brown color without much of a head at all.  The smell is weird, but not in a bad way, just something I am not familiar with.  Sweet smelling, some hops, some wood flavors, almost a chocolate like smell as well..  Taste has a weird aftertaste at first, but once the palate becomes used to it, it works out very nice.  A rich flavorful offering that hides the 12% very well.  Almost like drinking a stout, but it isnt.  I will watch the DVD soon and hopefully enjoy another bottle of this as well.

12 oz bottle.  Around $17 for the 4-pack.  Deep mahogany pour, almost black.  Reddish tanned head, looking somewhat like Im about to sip into a impy stout.  The aroma reminds me of...Dogfish Head actually.  Beyond are light woody aromas and possible cocoa powder.  The flavor is fairly nutty, combined with thick molassesy malt flavors and hidden undertones of wood aging.  The most interesting of all this to me was the very subtle, yet powerful spice notes throughout the body and the finish.  A light burnt flavor is found somewhere after the finish.  Fairly thick on the palate, very sugary (too much), not too carbonated.  The 12%abv is hidden dangerously well.  Definitely another interesting experiment from Dogfish Head...and mostly a successful one at that.
Quite dark color.  Very well integrated wood flavor.  Rich nutty flavor, cocoa and Brazil nuts.  Really good, the ABV is very well concealed.

Very dark brown, almost black, with a thin ring of foam. Interesting aroma - woodsy and a hint of red wine, plus some spicy, cinnamon note. Flavor is similiar to the smell, with a lot of wood, alot of red wine and a lot subtle spicy notes. I had brace myself for a typical DFH alcohol bomb, but was surprised haw drinkable this was.

what a great offering from one of my favorite brewers.  Pours out a deep mohogany color with a small head.  aroma was hoppy with hints of malt, wood, and citrus.  I couldnt stop sniffing this beer.  Flavor was very interesting.  Had a roasted malt body with sweet finish to it.  There were some other notes that i noticed.  I guess that was the palo santo wood.  nice job!

Bottle at the Dilly Deli.  Poured clear brown color with an average frothy off-white head that was mostly diminished with good lacing. Moderate toasted malt and citrus hoppy aroma. Medium to full body. Medium to heavy toasted bittersweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate to long duration. My expectations where met.

Pours a mostly opaque black with mahogany edges and a frothy, wispy-lacing dark tan head.  Aroma of dry toasty earthy malts with some vanilla, wood, and black cherries and plums.  The nose becomes more woody and complex as it warms. Body starts fairly full with a nice dark caramely sweetness, some mild woodsy smoke and ash and good balance of dark fruity complexity throughout.  Finishes slightly drier, bittersweet and mildly warming.  An enjoyable and complex brew that should age pretty well.

pours dark with a tawny read foam. deep rich roasted nose subtle notes of molasseses and espresso.  improves as it warms up.  very nice and the ballance is great you may never know it packs a %12 abv. interesting and wonderful.
Dark borwn, lingering amber head.  Aroma of vanilla and burnt malt.  Rich and flavorful...some burnt notes on the tongue...complex, woody, slight dry, but flavorful.

The beer has a pleasant aroma. A nice malty aroma. I watched the DVD that came with this beer, and they made this huge deal about the wood they used to age the beer. I can say they went way too far with that facet of the brewing process. There is a slight presence of hops, and a nice sugar malt aroma. The aroma is very sweet and very nice. The beer had a decent caramel head that quickly faded away. The beer is pretty much black, and opaque.  Decent appearance, but nothing special . The beer has a very nice roasted malt flavor. I dont know about the special wood that they used for aging the beer, but I have tasted brews that are better that didnt spend $150,000 on a brew tank made of wood. I taste coffee somewhat, but it is mainly the sugar and the malt, a nice roasted flavour. Even though there is a 12% ABV you cant taste that at all. The beer is pretty smooth, but  again nothing special. I like this beer for its malt and sugar aroma and flavor. This beer has a nice ABV, aroma, and flavor, but it looks average and the beer when it is in your mouth feels semi-thick.

deep brown pour with a medium sized frothy head. slightly sweet aroma with a hint of vanilla. flavor had some dark fruit, vanilla, and sweet malt. some smokey ashy flavor comes through as well and balanced some of the sweetness out nicely. alcohol is amazingly well hidden for 12%. nice and definately different. would like to see how this ages.

Bottle Date February 2008; Sampled February 2008
Pours with an almost three-finger thick, light brown colored head.  The beer is a deep, burnt amber, dark brown colored head.  Despite being a clear, rich brown color as I pour this beer, it is completely opaque when held up to the light.  Aromas of vanilla, interesting spicy wood that is not the same as from oak (slightly peppery, cinnamon and a touch of fenugreek), candied caramel malt, almost a bit of smoke, .  A substantial fruit character provides notes of cherries, raisins and red grapes mixes very well with the wood aromatics.  The alcohol is hidden quite well, especially given the 12% abv.  Supporting, toasty malt notes, with ample browned bread and biscuit notes and a hint of roast character; really the toasty, browned bread crust like aromas of this beer are quite distinct if you dig around in the aroma for them.  This has a very interesting aroma, the use of the Palo Santo wood definitely adds a unique dimension that is a derivative, but still uniquely distinct from, the more typical oak.

Thick and viscous, though not nearly as sweet as I was expecting.  A creamy, velvety mouthfeel couples with flavors of vanillin, chewy toffee and dark fruit flavors.  This is pretty well carbonated (with a nice prickle to the tongue at the beginning of each sip), but it is thick enough that it is not noticed as much as it would be otherwise.  Concentrated fruit forward flavors of cherries, raisins and blackberries couple with a very light alcohol presence to contribute a Brandy like finish.  This finishes with a toasted soda cracker note at times, but often this takes the backseat to the sweet, concentrated fruit notes that tend to linger on in the mouth.  The wood components are a bit more subdued than in the aroma; it does provide a spicy backbone as well as a bit of tannic astringency, both of which provide a sharp note in the finish that provides balance like hop bitterness would.

As the beer warms up a bit, the aroma really starts to pick up a complex mix of cherry, mace, and distinctly sweet spices.  The aroma of this brew is a bit more intriguing and interesting than the flavor, though that is by no means a dud.  The malt and brown ale character seems to come through more in the aroma as does the wood.  With the added wood component this is one of the more complex, even balanced big beers from Dogfish Head.

Purchased: <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Tucson AZ

This beer has a dark body with a bit of reddish tint around the side of the glass.  The beer has a ton of nutty caramel and very malty aroma.  The flavor is very nutty and with a bit of spice with a bit of a fruity flavor.

Opaque black with medium caramel head.  Sweet raisiny aroma, but otherwise generically brown smelling with a bit of smoke. Taste is the same, but with brown sugar, and burnt biscuit. Sweet into the finish, and no residual bitterness.  No wood that I could discern. Almost like a DFH WWStout diluted  by half.  $3/12oz

Dark brown, near black color. Dense tan head. Aroma of wood, roasted malt and molasses. Flavors are resinous, sugary, sweet. Very low bitterness. Not really all that much wood character present. Still, an interesting complexity and a massive malt flavor.

pours a thick opaque black that looks like a stout with a medium sized creamy brown head.  aroma is less than exciting with lots of alcohol and only traces of blackened malt and wood.  flavor is chocolaty, with coffee, and some smoke.  full bodied, creamy mouthfeel.  could pass easily as an imp stout.  lots of talk about this special wood.  i only really notice a slight woody mustiness(moth balls, cedar) in the finish after its been swallowed for several seconds.  i gotta say i love this breweries experimentation though.  always trying something new.  nice dvd on the side of the box.  i almost threw it away on accident!  talks about the brewery and the making of this beer...mostly the wood.

12oz bottle shared courtesy of TomDecapolis. Poured a deeper brown color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of wood, earthy, roast, and chocolate. Tastes of wood (although lighter than the aromas), vanilla, roast, and chocolate. Alcohol content well hidden.

Poured a thick dark brown with a reddish hue  and a small light brown head into a unibroue goblet. Aroma of Caramel, Vanilla, Wood, malt and barley. Taste is chocolate, barley, coffee, wood, brown sugar, vanilla and the beer has a creamy mouthfeel. The finish is bittersweet and the 12% alcohol is apparent but not overbearing. I was expecting more wood flavor in this one to be honest, but it is still pretty good. I am interested to see how this one ages.

Exciting to see such an awesome addition to the DFH lineup. This one pours a very dark brown and gives me about a fingers worth of tan head. Some molasses, caramel, vanilla, and an unfamiliar but obviously woody scent in the aroma. The flavor has some brown sugar upfront along with some dark fruits and caramel. Dry woody finish. Great stuff.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2008 Poured dark brown almost black with a tint of red from a 12oz. bottle. 1/8 inch tan head, Aroma of heavy malt with a scent of wine.  Tastes sweet then bitter with a hint of vanilla.  Mouthfeel is very creamy.  Closer to a Baltic Porter than a Brown Ale.  The 12% percent is well hidden.  This is a great beer.  Id love to have this on tap!

The four pack came with a DVD glued to the side.  I almost didnt see it.

Pours a deep brown with a medium creamy/bubbly tan head.  Aroma was woody, toffee, coffee, nuts, chocolate, earthy, dark fruits, some vanilla, light smoke and brown sugar.  Flavor was a lot of the same...woody up front, vanilla, earthy, floral and some pine.  Alcohol for being at 12% is pretty well hidden...woody and dry.
Very rich and creamy with a distinct alcohol character. Lots of spiciness and distinct sugar cane qualities. The lines are somewhat blurred between the hops and the wood resins. Very nice beer.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a slick extremely dark brown with a thin fizzy tan head that disappears quickly.  The aromas are roasted malt, bakers chocolate, a hint of coffee, some dark fruit, and a light whiff of wood.  The flavor opens with roasted malts and dark fruits.  Mid palate the wood and vanilla kick in leading to a smooth yet dry finish.  Some bittersweet chocolate also comes through.  Full bodied, I too am interested to see what this is like with some age.

Bottle. Oily black pour with a fizzy tan head. Aromas of light roasted malt, dark fruits, light dark chocolate, liquorice, and a tinge of smoke. Flavors of unsweetened chocolate, vinous fruits, charred wood, and roasted malt. Thick body, but with a lively carbonation, woody/dry/bittersweet/malty with a coasting dry/bitter finish. Quite an interesting brew, the way the wood and roast dry everything out in the end really finds me going back for more. Im really interested to see how this one handles some age.

bottle from WLV...poured amlmost black and stoutlike with a moderate light brown head.....aromas of roasty chocolate malt, sweet dark fruit, and a faint trace of coffee....flavors of ash that added some smokey flavor to it.  sweet roasted malt and dark fruit. very sprite and lively in the mouth. aftertaste was sweet and woody.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2008 The pour is dark brown, borderline black, with a decent tan head and some hints of lacing.  The nose is caramel, wood, roasted malt and a touch of spice and Frankincense (The resinous  African ancestor to Palo Santo wood.)  The flavor is much the same as the nose, and amply covers the alcohol content.  An extremely nice unique brew.

12 oz. bottle via trade with GMCC2181 - Pours a brown color with a small light tan head.  Has some decent lacing.  Aroma is herbal hops, roasted malt, and a touch of woodiness.  Flavor is a lightly sweetened light chocolate malt, and spice/herbal hops.  Alcohol was noticeable.  Smooth, medium body.  A very nice sipping beer.  Thanks Gabe.

Drank it out of an authentic Dogfish Head glass! Hurray coordination. Really dark color and it looks almost like a porter rather than a brown ale. Head is pretty dark brown and goes down reasonably quickly but leaves consistent lacing until that too leaves us forever. Strong brown sugar aroma. Malty flavor hits the mouth straight to the front. Alcohol is covered over by the rather strong taste. The beer is really, really sweet, but not unbearably so. Chocolatey/molasses taste and a bunch of brown sugar. Maybe some fruitiness, but not quite sure.

Thanks to Pantanap for letting me bring this one home with me.  I am always up for a new dogfish head brew.  Poured a deep brown color with a small head.  Smelled intriquing.  Slight vinous notes, sweet and some unplaceable bitter notes.  Taste was really interesting.  My first thought was, where did they hide al that alcohol?  Some wood, dark fruit and biscuity nuttiness as well.  I tried swigging it around in my mouth and crazy flavors came out.  I finally decided that bananas foster was the best way to describe the flavors.  I would definitely like to try this again.

Pours a black color with a reddish tint and a small fizzy light brown head.  Aroma of very strong roasted malts and toasted nuts.  Taste is dominated by strong roasted malts with hints of toasted nuts, barley and wood.   Alcohol is well hidden and this beer leaves an interesting wood flavored aftertaste.

12oz bottle. Pitch black pour with a thin khaki head producing better than average lacing. Cocoa and vanilla instantly strike me on the nose. Toasted and slightly roasted malt. Toasted nuts and a touch of wood. Flavor has a lot of roasted malt and toasted vanilla. Theres a slight hop pine bitterness and a touch of wood tannin dryness. Mostly full bodied and quite creamy on the tongue. I think this one is too fresh and the flavors might integrate a little better with some time. Thanks Gabe!

pours a black with mild tan head.  sweet coconut vannilla wood aroma.  warming front with oak and wood finish.  charred wood.  vanilla fruitys swwett finish.  complex, hidden.  "burnt popsickle stick already sweet from ice cream dipped in caramel" -Julie

12 oz bottle from Liquor Outlet.  Very dark brown in color, small tan/light brown head that leaves some nice lacing on my unibroue glass.  Aroma is kind of out there, but in this DFH beer, it seems to work so far:  caramel, vanilla, chocolate light  touches of spicy/piney hops, and an interesting woody presence.  Taste is full bodied with caramel and toffee sweetness, with some chocolate and very light roasty notes, the wood is also very apparent and quite up front- especially in the mid palate through the finish.  The Palo Santo wood  as well as a light piney bitterness lingers nicely in the finish.  Interesting beer, that I found more enjoyable than some of their other gimmicky brews.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours opaque dark brown/black with a surprisingly strong and lasting creamy tan head and some lacing.  Aroma is quite consistent with a brown ale - malt-dominated with some roasty, toasty and nutty notes and earthy wood underneath and some cocoa, licorice and a nice piney hop presence.  The flavor is surprisingly gentle and balanced, yet full, with most of the aroma descriptors applicable.  Ill have to add to the choir that its almost unbelievable that this is 12%.  Again, very much in the style of a typical brown ale, with more flavor expression and smoky wood undertones.  The body is medium full and the carbonation is moderate-moderately low, both seeming appropriate for the unique hybrid style.  Delicious and very well done overall.  For another crazy, over-the-top Dogfish Head beer (not a bad thing!) this is surprisingly accessible.

Bottle. Dark brown, with a light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, wood, and brown sugar. Flavor is chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla, wood, alcohol and sugar. Interesting and good. One of the better ones from DFH.

Bottle from TJs.  Pours a dark brown with a good sized tan head that is decently retained and is accompanied by some nice lace. . Aroma is brown sugar, roast, wood, vanilla, and mild booze. Flavor has more roastiness at the forefront, with a slightly sugary, malty and woody aftertaste. Alcohol pretty well hidden. An interesting beer, but definitely not worth $14.49 a 4 pack.  Hot Damn!

UPDATED: APR 13, 2012 Bottle from SL. The pour was deep dark black in color, generous initial chocolate colored head, thinning slowly during comsumption eventually to a nice ring around the edges, lacing ok/splotchy. The aroma was bubblegum, roasted chocolate, light smoke, dried fruits. The flavor followed the aroma, strong presence of the roast/smoke, sweet and bitter (from the roast?) at the same time, along with a sasafrass branch type of spice/wood element. Mouthfeel was full, carbonated strongly for this ABV (forgot to mention, no alcohol detectable at all outside of mouthfeel and malt level, this thing was ethanol smooth in aroma and flavor!), and sticky. A decent concoction, but hard to find anything incredibly novel in the beer from paraguayan palo or santo whatever - in other words, the malts and roast bury the wood for the most part. A nice big huge imperial brown ale. Re-rate, 9/07 at the brewpub on draft: came across much better this time, the wood breaking through all the wonderful (although I didnt think so when I first wrote them) descriptors above. A neat brew, but its a big brown ale indeed. Rating bumping up. Re-rate, at the brewpub, 8/09: Another great outing for this one after a ride to/from Rehobeth from Fenwick. rich and bright in all the aforementioned flavors and all. Great stuff. Re-rate 07 bottle in 4/12: too old. Sticky caramel, dark fruits and chocolate. Past its prime, not dropping rating. Oxidation almost nil, though.
Pours dark brown with thick tan head and a small amount of lacing.  Vanilla and wood on the nose.  Complex flavors consisting of wood, white chocolate, malts, roast, and hops.  slightly dry finish.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2010 [ Batch #1 feb 08] Pours black with a large foamy mocha head.  Aroma is strong nailpolish, woody.   Mild flavor for so much in the beer.  The malt is really hard to taste, just very sugary, woody, and the burn of alcohol.  I can smell some spices but those are also hard to taste.  Something very different, but is really just a tease for an imperial stout. 7.5.8.3.15 . . . . . . . . . . . . .I suppose I was fairly harsh on this beer the first time around, rookie.  Not sure age has treated it that well, again this reaffirms my assumption that dark beers are best after 6-9 months and no more.  The aroma is intoxication, huge licorice, lovely dry wood, slick sweet molasses, seems delicious.  Flavor is marred by soy and light hop oxidation, the wood is pretty good in the first sip, tons of licorice, the 12% was made for this flavor, molasses/syrup, the soy is a detractor.  Medium/full bodied, bit sticky syrupy but not bad at all.  8.4.8.4.15

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2009 Bottle at Jerrys. Black with good, creamy brown head / Winey, woody nose of vanilla, wood, and chocolate / Full, body with big, sweet malts but with good hop balance and finish.  A little hot but big alcohol mostly masked. / Flavors of figs, prunes, milk chocolate, vanilla, and presumably palo santo wood. / A very good, crazy barleywine.

Bottled 2/11/2008 (11 days ago): Deep brown to black in color this poured a thin brown head that dissipated rather quickly leaving little lacing.  The nose showed sweet wood fig, maple syrup and a touch of vanilla crème.  In the mouth it was a full-bodied beer with great palate weight and richness.  The flavors showed off the wood, chocolate and fig with some hops showing in the slightly dry, bitter finish.  The alcohol is well integrated overall with just a touch showing through on the finish.

Pours a dark color with a light tan head.  Smells like alcohol with a hint of malt.  Laces well as you drink it.  Light mouthfeel with very little aftertaste.  Has a medium alcohol taste with some notes of roasted malt character.  Very little hop presence.  Not as much wood flavor as I like in wood beers.  And doesnt taste that good either.  Overall a very disappointing beer.

Woooow. I admit I was skeptical. "Great. Another big over the top overdone Dogfish Head beer". Wow was I wrong. This beer is 12%? This is the first big beer Ive had from this brewer that I can say hides the alcohol beautifully. Aroma of maple syrup and sweet malt. Pour was a deep dark near black with a one finger tan head. Taste was near perfect. Strong caramel and chocolate flavor with a big woodiness. This beer tasted like someone spilled caramel and Hersheys syrup on a piece of wood and you licked it up. Im going to pick up as much of this as I can while I can.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Very roasty malts... much like an exaggerated Dogfish Indian Brown.  Relatively small head.  Charred wood smell and nice chocolate, roast, and wood on the palate.  Slight chocolate covered cherries as well.  Not as vanilla/caramel as many wood-aged beers, but in a really nice way.  Surprisingly tasty.  I feel like I like this more than the numerical rating I gave it...

12oz from a 4-pack (with a DVD!).  Bottled on 2/11/08.  Pours very dark brown with a dark foamy brown head.  Looks pitch black in the glass.  A nice aroma on this one.  Can pick out traces of brown ales (a less hoppyDFH Indian Brown comes to mind) as well as some stout like qualities.  Brown sugar, chocolate covered bananas, caramel.  Alcohol nowhere in sight within the aroma.  Taste is smooth, rich, chocolatey, a bit watery even with the alcohol hidden extremely well.  Not too sweet or cloying like some other high alcohol DFH beers.  This beer hides its abv better than almost any other beer I can think of.  I must admit I was not terribly familiar with Paraguayan Palo Santo wood before this beer and I am having trouble picking out any characteristics it imparts.  Regardless this is pretty good.

This is a dark beer for a brown ale.  It head a light brown head, but it dissipated quickly. It smells a little bitter with sweet and sour hints around the edges.  The taste is a bit sweet with a bit of a roasty finish.  There seems to be a bit of fruit in there as well.  The beer is very smooth in the mouth and you cant really taste the alcohol at all.  Its not a bad beer, but it seems to be missing some balance.  A slight bitter taste might help.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2009 Bottle shard by mmtmatrix.  Poured a deep brown color with a half-inch thick tan head.  Aroma of the Palo Santo wood, caramel, and some vanilla.  Sweet caramel an toffee malt entry leads into a roasty, woody finish.  I really enjoyed the Palo flavor on the finish, it added a nice earthy character and dried the palate nicely.  Doesnt really drink like a 12% beer, it is pretty smooth.  This seems to have good aging potential.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2009 Bottle, smell of malts. Super black, little head no lacing. Really smooth and sweet. I cant taste the 12 percent at all. I love brown ales but this is missing something. I had it in the summer of 07 down at the rehobeth brewery and I remember it being so much better. Maybe it just needs to age. I will re-rate in a year. Still good though.****Update**** Just had it on tap at the brew pub in DE again. (July 10th 2008) Much better then the bottle, even though I hope some age will help the bottle that are resting.*****2nd update**** Just had another bottle from the second batch. Much more smokey then I remember. Really impressed.  Reminded me of HOTD Adam...

Almost looked like a srout poring out with a nice dark color and small head. The notes of chocolate and a aftertaste of the wood were pleasing. For the amount of alcohol they belended this brew perfectly and its a very interesting new beer I would purchase again. Dog Fish nails another crazy brew and hope to see this one around again next year.
(Draft)  Pours a lightly hazy amber body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of caramel, vanilla, herbs, florals, and toffee.  Flavor of orange, caramel, wood, some chocolate, and herbs.

Opaque, almost totally black color with a decent mahogany head.  Soft chocolate and a nutty carmel roasted malt aroma.  Lower carbonation and full body.  Chocolate, vanilla, and coffee flavor.  Alcohol is only detectable as it warms the throat going down.  Great non heavy creamy finish accented by the wood, well balanced.

EBF Night of the Barrels.  I thought this was a solid brew overall, although not quite as good as their other offering.  Aroma was like walking through a forest, mixed with some yeast and vanilla.  Some cocoa hints.  Flavor took some warming up to and it got better.  Did not realize it was 12%; couldnt detect that at all.

Bottle. Poured a light black body with thin head. Aroma is nutty, chocolate, must. Flavor is nutty, oak, wood, chocolate, rich malt. Easy drinking, nice mouthfeel and I could not detect 12% abv in the taste. Strong, yes but not easily shown in the taste or smell. I look forward to trying another bottle after this is laid down for awhile to see how smooth this can get. Well done DFH.
EBF NOTB.  Yeasty vanilla and lightly roasted chocolate aroma.  The flavor was the same, and actually reminded me a little of the theobroma.  Fairly unique beer and pretty good also.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2008 EBF V NOTB. This beer smelled and tasted more like a stout to me than anything else. Amazing they fit 12% into there. Very nicely balanced with nice roast, coffee, hint of chocolate in there. Not overly complex or mind-blowing, but I could drink this any time of the day and be happy as a clam.

From a fresh bottle, very, very sugary sweet for me, but I feel that with age it can achieve what I first tasted, and Im in a generous mood, so Ill let those numbers stand.

GABF 2007:  My very first beer of the fest.  The beer was an almost opaque black with a beige head.  The aroma was of semi-sweet roasted coffee.  The flavor was big and thick with sweet roasted malt.  Some chocolate.  Very warming and full bodied.

GABF 2007.  I was thoroughly impressed by this one.  The beer pours to a black body with a nice dense light beige head.  The aroma is richly nutty with tons of walnuts, Brazil nuts, and wood.  Very unique and very nicely balanced.  The flavor is rich.  Like a chocolate imperial stout blended with a brown ale.  Note of fine wood.  Rich creamy palate with a full body and the wood brings a balance amongst the alcohol.  This one is a keeper and should have some aging potential.

GABF 2007.  Im privileged to be one of the few who have had the opportunity to try this brew.  Exceptional in every way, I kept returning to have more.  Dark chocolate, wood, caramel... sample enough times and youll find a little bit of everything; a complex brew.

GABF 2007.  Ive come to expect less than average beers from DFH w/ more hype than substance, but this one blew my expectations.  It was awesome.  Caramel, sweet malt, and a nice alcohol burn in the throat.  Very good.

Dark pour thick tan head, nice lace.  Oak & alcohol in the aroma over lots of caramel malts and a touch of brown sugar.  a subdued grain note follows.  Full well coated and creamy palate.  Fantastic almost a bourbon w/ tons of vanilla a light brown sugar & alcohol in the swallow, hints of a nut brown in there too.  Delicious.

Deep brown in color with a little off white head. Woody rich chocolatety vanilla aroma. Chocolatety malty flavor. Caramel vanilla notes. Sweet tasting. Finish is bitter. Medium bodied. Very drinkable.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2011 
Date: February 09, 2007
Mode: Draft
Source: Brewfest, Extreme Beer
Appearance: opaque brown, frothy tan head
Aroma: rich chocolate aroma with sweet vanilla
Flavor: lots of chocolate flavor, unique woody character, touch of vanilla sweetness, light bitter finish

Date: April 26, 2008
Mode: bottle
Source: Greens
Score: 3.5 to 3.8
Aroma: picking up some backend woody spicyness in the aroma that was not there before
Body: very creamy body
Flavor: great chocolate flavor, the woody character is well integrated into the chocolate flavor

Date: December 05, 2008
Mode: draft
Words: dans kegerator
a bit more subdued on draft, very rich and chocolatey, touch of dark fruits sneaking out, 

Date: January 10, 2010
Mode: draft
Source: taco mac kennesaw
Score: 3.8 to 4.1
Appearance: black, fine tan head
Aroma: sweet chocolate aroma, dark fruits, touch of wood
Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, lots of fruity character in this keg, wood offers a great depth of character
Overall: the fruity potential of this beer is coming out and giving it extra depth of character, I may have to get a keg of this afterall

Date: April 29, 2011
Mode: bottle
Source: cellar stock
Vintage: 2008
Aroma: sweet winey sherry character showing up in the aroma with the rich chocolate and dark fruits
Flavor: flavor is sweet dark fruits and chocolate, just a touch of the sherry
Overall: ages well and picks up the sherry but not really any better than fresh especially on draft

Date: November 02, 2011
Mode: draft
Source: tmac woodstock
Vintage: 2009
not showing much change with an aged keg, still the velvety rich chocolate with a touch of dark fruits, but none of the sherry that shows up in the bottle after a couple of years, 

Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 17/20
Rating: 4.1/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: ***+ /4

Rating #1075
Draft a couple of 12oz glasses were absorbed!
Pours a dark hue of brown, and a supple tan head. The aroma is wonderful Toffee,

Truly a style onto its own. Saved for dessert or a nightcap. Smells of dark chocolate, molasses, and Palo Santo wood (you probably wouldnt know if you havent smelled the wood first). Little alcohol on the nose. Fine carbonation and unfermented sugars lend to a creamy and smooth mouthfeel. Fantastic on the palate, bursting with chocolate, molasses, vanilla, slightly smoky and spicy from the wood. Satisfying finish that lingers.

Dark, opaque chestnut, thin head and little carbonation. Smells of alcohol, chalk and bakers chocolate. Taste: raisins, smoked wood, caramlized brown sugar, straight alcohol. A beer to end you evening with; great after a couple of 60 Mins.

Poured an opaque, deep, dark brownish red color with a medium sized, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of molasses, roasted malts, chocolate, vanilla beans, and raisins.  Taste of roasted malts, sweet chocolate, some smoke, toffee light resin, light cinnamon, wood, and alcohol as well.  Silky smooth mouthfeel.

On tap - Rehoboth
Not sure how to categorize this one, so I guess "American Strong Ale" is probably the most apt...dont be fooled by the "brown ale" description, which couldnt be further from the truth.
Very chocolatey with a strong molasses flavor as well.  Smooth - not too carbonated.  I found it nicely hopped, but i also had it on tap, on a night when they hook up the little hop infuser tube to the draft, so its hard to say what it normally tastes like.
If i had to compare it to something, Id say its like the littler brother to Victorys Storm King.  (Granted that one is an imperial stout, but this has several of the same flavors, just not as heavy as an imperial stout).
Watch out for the 12% ABV!

Does Dogfish make a bad beer???

On tap-@ Rehoboth Brewpub. Pours a very dark brown color w/a moderate brown head. Deep "woodsy" aroma.  Full, rich deep smoked flavor of peet & mahogany w/some traces of chocolate & molasis. Has quite a kick, this is not one to come in & knock back a few of. Alcohol is quite evedant. This would make a great after dinner/sipping beer; reminds you of a fine Brandy in that reguard. Im sure this would age quite well if they ever bottled it. Long woodsy finish; reminds me more of a Smoked that an American Strong.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2007 EBF draught on 2/9/07Dull mahogany with some light chestnut edges.  Chalky-beige head is medium in size and recedes steadily to partial-cover and ring, leaving little/no lacing.  Clarity is medium to medium-high.The aroma is just steady chocolate and caramel.  Huge, underattenuated malts with a pinch of dry toffee and chewy nougat.  Light vanillin and bubble gum??  Yep, definitely smells of bubble gum or cotton candy.  Very sugary.  Alcohol dosent come out in the aroma too heavily, though there is some expression upon warming.  Pretty monotonous aroma, overall.Though it dosent prepare for the flavor.  Yikes.  What the hell is this?  Its like a bad case of plastics, chemicals and glue all wrapped in to a sugary-sweet mess of a beer.  Horribly sugary, not even thick chocolate/caramel, just fuzzy, sugary adjunct-like flavors with plenty of high fermentation notes (bubble gum, cotton candy, vanillin, sharp fusels).  Cloying quickly.  No real sign of the wood, maybe some light dryness, but its marginal.  Thick, sugary texture as expected, with medium carbonation.Even the brewer of this beer was not happy with the results.
EBF 07 dark brown but as dark as the immort ale. very nice big flavor from the wood i assume. sweet and malty and i really cant tell its 12%

EBF 2007: Dark brown pour with a dark tan head. Aroma, maple, caramel, molasses. Flavor, fruity, some sugary sweetness, very malty beer, and the wood comes through nicely. Medium-full body, glad I got to try it.

Draft at Rehoboth Beach brewpub; listed as 14% ABV on the chalk menu above the bar.  Dark black center; medium tan head with attractive lacing.  Generous aroma: milk chocolate, olives, cedary / woodsy notes; hints of black licorice and cotton candy.  Very sweet, sugary mouthfeel: chocolate, licorice, oaky / toasty notes, hints of marshmallow and slightly buttery; the wood aging seems to add all kinds of flavors to this beer; its a bit hot right now, but incredibly satisfying and complex.  Long, bitter-chocolate finish, showing hints of vanilla.
Had this at the November extreme beer dinner.  Delicious.  The smokey, wood flavor is excellent.  By the end of the glass though, the alcohol really began to stand out.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2008 Draft at Rehobeth Beach, served in a snifter. The board says its 14% and 35 IBUs. Pours deep brown with a nice frothy brown head. Aroma of wood mulch, nutshells, and caramel. Soft carbonation in the mouthfeel.  Initial brown ale flavor of brown sugar and caramel, some hints of cocoa, but then it quickly gets overpowered by the alcohol. Warming and dry woody flavor on the  finish. Boy, this beer had a lot of alcoholic kick to it. I am not sure a brown ale is meant to have this type of ABV, as it really overpowers the beer. The wood aging definitely helped pull this together.  However, I did enjoy this and would have no problem drinking again. This has potential to be an amazing beer.   Bottled version. Sampled at 50 degrees. Pours a deep coffee brown, almost stout like, with a one finger brown head that dissipates to a ring. Very inviting nose of cocoa powder, dark roast, and wood mulch. Short initial flavor of nuts, molasses, and roasted malts that quickly transitions to aggressive plummy and red wine flavors. Semi-dry and oaky finish is warming with a strong vodka like alcohol presence (not quite as aggressive as the initial draft version). I am going to bump the aroma from 6 to 8 and the overall from 14 to 15.
